name: BioShock Infinite
description: Indebted to the wrong people, with his life on the line, veteran of the U.S. Cavalry and now hired gun, Booker DeWitt has only one opportunity to wipe his slate clean. He must rescue Elizabeth, a mysterious girl imprisoned since childhood and locked up in the flying city of Columbia.

reviews.review_text: That moment when a game is so good you would love to wipe out your memory just to re-experience the feeling again,and again,and again.

Having not played any of the prior versions of Bioshock I had no idea what the franchise was about or what to expect. I was disappointed at first because I was expecting the game to be more of an action / fps rather than an action adventure, and there is about two hours of 'story' before any action happens. However I stuck with it and ended up really enjoying it. The visuals in this game are amazing alone, and masterfully done.    There are some minor thing I would recommend users tweak that I found helped considerably.  **The Good**  * Amazing Visuals. * Deep and interesting story line * Good replay value, there is a lot to explore and search through out the BioShock infinite world.  **Needs Improvment**  * Visibility of enemies is very poor, I recommend either using SweetFX or turning up digital vibrance. * Player movments are very 'blocky' with the stock configuration, I found out this was caused by 'autoaim' being forced on. There is a config tweak to modify this:   Browse to C:\Users\YOURUSERACCOUNTNAME\Documents\My Games\BioShock Infinite\XGame\Config Open XUserOptions.ini with notepad or wordpad Find the line called 'bAimAssist=True' and change it to 'bAimAssist=False     **Overall Rating ** 9.5 / 10

I was gifted this game by a friend and it sat in my library for a few years. I didn't know much about Bioshock, but I just decided in my head I wouldn't like it. A couple of days ago, I just decided to load it up, and I can confidently say it's my favorite single player game of all time. Though some have criticized the gunplay, I found it very enjoyable, and the vigors were a blast. But, the world building and story is where this gem shines. With only having a vague understanding of the first Bioshock, I was able to follow the story without any confusion, well, except for the confusion the game wanted me to have. Fully recommended.

This game is breathtaking and absolutely stunning. I highly recommend this game, regardless of whether or not you own the previous two Bioshock prequels. The story is very interesting and I found myself unable to stop playing until sleep nearly overtook me midgame. My playthrough lasted ca 20 hours as I relish exploring the various areas and taking in the beautiful scenery. I pre-purchased this game and I stand fast in my opinion that this was money well-spent.

This is a game that desperately makes you want to think it's smart when it has no idea what it's talking about and knows jack about it's own subject matter. The combat is limiting and repetitive with a two weapon limit with an expensive as hell upgrade system. The 'Vigors' (plasmids with a new coat of paint) all do the same thing with three exceptions: Possess machines for a short period of time (Not the same as hacking from Bioshock 1), charge at enemies with a strong melee attack (comes with a certain upgrade that makes it stupidly overpowered so you'll probably not use anything else), and an ability to catch and reflect bullets (would have been pretty cool if it wasn't given to you at practically the last part of the game), all other Vigors are just the same crowd control effect with a different look.  The story doesn't save the game either. In the beginning it tries to send a message about racial equality and revolution but that's thrown away in favor of theories about alternate-dimensions/realities (which don't make any sense at all the second you start thinking about them).  Also;   why did they feel like they needed to have a twist ending in Infinite? Just because the first game had one? They also did it in Infinite's DLC. Are twist endings now a staple for this series? Do they understand how a twist ending is supposed to work? A twist only works if the audience isn't expecting it, just by making your series the 'Series with twist endings in them' you're ruining the surprise because people will be expecting it. I am impressed. Impressed by The City in the Sky. After finishing Bioshock and Bioshock 2 I thought nothing can ever compete with the world of Rapture. But then I walked in the streets of Columbia for the first time and it was so peaceful, so beautiful, so incredibly atmospheric.  'There's always a lighthouse. There's always a man. There's always a city..' But still.. these two worlds are so different. In Rapture you were stuck in small rooms with very limited ways to escape. It had its own charm. Columbia is just the opposite. It has many big open areas with the possibility to move fast around by attaching sky-hooks to the city's main transport system Sky-Line.  Bioshock Infinite story is, without doubt, one of the best ever made for a game. It tells you the story by showing you things. Do not expect any direct explanation. This part is on you to find out what just really happened.. To put all the pieces together and try to understand.. Fortunately some people already made their explanation and interpretation of this very complicated story and that helps players like me to understand a bit better. And of course it opens more question for discussions.  I have to admit I liked the combat system in previous Bioshocks a bit more. The biggest issue I had was that Bioshock Infinite allowed me to carry only two weapons. Sometimes I felt like I was stuck with what I found around. Upgrading certain weapons didn't feel very satisfying in the end. I never used them as much as I would like to. I was very frequently unsure if I should pick up different weapons around or not, because you never know what will you be facing behind the next corner.  Here comes another But. You can't save your progress in the game. You have to wait for autosave. I understand their intention but it can become a bit annoying when you have to stop playing and next time you can't simply continue from where you were before.  I chose hard difficulty level and it was both, enjoyable and challenging. Despite some of my complaints the fights were still very decent.  To be honest all the negative things I experienced were washed away by the impressive graphics and story. I took some time away from the game before writing this review. My mind was struck and paralyzed by the very emotional and confusing ending.  The good feelings still persist. I must recommend this game and then I must continue with the DLCs :)

Rating 9/10 Overview: First Person Shooter   The Good:  + As is the case with every Bioshock game proceeding this one, the world, setting and atmosphere is the main attraction and this game is no different. The city of Columbia is beautiful and one of the most interesting and unique game settings to play in.   + Graphically both artistically and technically this game is gorgeous. Easily one of the best looking games on PC to date.   + The story is fantastic dealing with major themes such as racism, morality, religion and faith. A game that should leave a lasting impression on you long after you finish it.   + Elizabeth one of the main NPC's is incredibly helpful in and out of combat, providing you with health, ammo, money etc. The developers did a great job making her realistic and helpful and not a hindrance.   + The game introduces vigors (identical to plasmids from previous Bioshock games) that give you special powers such as charging enemies, shocking, possessing etc that give you an advantage in combat.  + Plenty of weapons/vigors to fit your play style. You can charge in and blast your enemies with shotguns or stay back and snipe with a sniper rifle.   + The game introduces skylines for you to ride on adding an extra gameplay element to combat. You can jump on and off the the skylines at will to either attack enemies from above or to escape a potentially dangerous situation.   +The three pieces of DLC are very enjoyable. Clashes in the Clouds is a horde mode across 4 levels and 15 waves each. The goal obviously is to survive each wave and if possible complete the bonus objective. Burial at Sea part 1 and 2 tie in the story of Infinite with the events of the first game. Although the story may be a bit contrived in doing so it was still nice to revisit Rapture from a different point of view. Each episode introduces some new gameplay elements. The first episode being more action oriented while the second being more stealth oriented.   + Great music and sound  Average  - Other than the inclusion of skylines the gunplay introduces nothing new. You can also only carry 2 weapons at one time which feels very limiting compared to the previous games.   - Throughout the game you will find pieces of equipment for you to wear. You can equip a total of 4 pieces. The problem is the vast majority of equipment you find is terrible and offers little to no value. The few that are good can really break the game. There is no balance.    -The last gameplay segment is uninspiring. I got the feeling the developers ran out of time/creative ideas.  Conclusion  You really have to love the world, story and characters to really appreciate this game. If you play it solely for the gameplay you may find yourself a tad disappointed. I personally loved the game I only wish the world was more open ended for me to explore at my own pace.

BioShock Infinite, yet another game in the beloved BioShock series. Or is it? The game is set in the year 1912. Booker Dewitt accepts a job to travel to Columbia, a city suspended in the air, in order to retrieve a girl (Elizabeth) and wipe away his 'debts'. I don't know how much else I can say without spoiling some bits, so I'll just get right into the review. You see, Inifinite not only has a different setting. It's very, very different to the first two games, in fact. So different to the point where one could easily say that it's just a game that only has a different, original setting (as well as some lovely throwback references to the series) in common with it's franchise. That being said, I thoroughly enjoyed the game and find it to be a great addition. The game itself is fantastic. The story was good, combat was quite good, the setting was fantastic and I found myself enjoying the characters (Elizabeth, The Lutece Twins and Songbird were probably my favourites. Yes, even Songbird). One who tries to play this game as if it were the original BioShock (or the second) will not do too well. This game is more of an open-ish world shooter with large areas to move around while in combat. As well as this, the player can utilize Columbia's transport system (Sky-Lines, metal lines that one can traverse with a grappeling hook) to fight foes and move around the city. It's a cool feature in general. When watching the game be played, the main fear I had was that Elizabeth would be constantly forced as a character I desperately needed to care about. While this is true in some respects, I didn't neccesarily find her overbearing. In fact, I began to enjoy her company as well as the character throughout the game. That being said, though, she definitely isn't a companion; more of a follower. One thing to note is that you can no longer carry more than two weapons. Apparently the downloadable-content 'Burial at Sea' allows this once again as the player returns to the city of Rapture but since this is about the main game I'll just say it's a bit of a letdown. I'm not thrilled that the change was made, but it's not something I believe you should focus on. Another thing to note is that the little 'boss' characters that the character finds throughout the game aren't utilized very well. I find that they're nowhere near as memorable as the Big Daddy characters that the player encounters in the first game. It's a letdown indeed. That brings me onto another topic; Plasmids. Plasmids, or 'Vigors' as they are now called, just aren't as memorable as the ones you encounter in Rapture. On top of that, I only found myself using two or three of them on a regular basis compared to the first two games where I would use a wide variety. To sum it up, this is a good game that should keep you occupied. If you're one who likes to play through games multiple times once you get it I'm sure this could keep you entertained for a while. That being said, I still can't overcome my biased attitude towards the first game in the series and would definitely reccommend that, if you're willing to pay for this game, you at least consider getting the first one as well.

This is my opinion: BioInf is a beautiful game, with mediocre gameplay where longer healthbars simulate difficulty, and a story that pretends to be deep while it's really mostly pretentious, chopped up, and doesn't 'handle' and of the issues it briefly touches on. I could write you an essay about all the plot flaws; examples being blatantly ignoring huge character events, having Booker act like a total ♥♥♥♥♥♥ (and I mean extra everything total ♥♥♥♥♥♥ even in game terms) to make the story even more convoluted, and not keeping to their own in-universe laws. They introduce story elements like travel in time and between worlds in the multiverse, but don't seem to take into account the obvious consequences; for example, why does Booker assume that if they pass into a new world, his old deal with someone would be valid over there? And concerning all the deep issues it handles; you get hammered by racism, then all the black people go murderbrawl and you have to mindlessly shoot them all, is that what people mean by the game 'handling big and important issues'?  Now, I don't think BioInf is a worthless game; it can be fun at times. The intro is fantastically beautiful, for example. But if the question is simply: did I think it was worth my time and money spent? then my answer is no. The original idea of this game may have been brilliant, and the story complex and beautiful, but it feels like it's been compromised too many times in development, and consequently can't hold itself together. It may have benefited from not taking up quite so many 'deep and important issues' and not branching out into quite so many things. It ends up trying very hard to be something it isn't: a good story.

'Are you a bad man?' 'I am a bad man' 'No you're not a bad man.' *Killing about twenty people* 'Are you a bad man?' 'That guy is a bad man.' 'That guy is a bad man.'  Bioshock Infinite wants to be a game about the nature of 'what-if' and choice, framed in a story about ex-military officer Booker DeWitt sent to a mystical city in the clouds to rescue the mysterious waif Elizabeth, whose strange world-altering powers and sheltered childhood lends itself to an unfolding narrative of mutual cooperation; encouraging the player to care for an NPC as the two of you battle an unjust world out to get you.  What it *is*, is a game about shooting dudes in the face. Lots of them, in hectic combat where you tend to get disoriented a lot and your low health and lack of carriable healing items causes you to run around from cover to cover like a headless chicken looking for that precious popcorn or abandoned soda to boost your all-too-fragile health. And when the red mist is over you are left with a pile of dead police officers and ordinary, well-intentioned people convinced you are a bad guy. Which, after having killed about twenty of them, you kind of sort of feel like. Racists they may be, but nothing in-game ever convinced me these people *needed* to die, and especially not in such crude, gore-tastic manners.  Bioshock Infinite has a real issue with story-and-gameplay integration: The story and presentation leaves me ill-motivated to care about the main characters or anything they do. The gameplay, even if it had been better (it is certainly the weakest of the Bioshock games to date, sacrificing the last vestiges of System Shock on the altar of Call of Duty) creates a sharp divide between the themes of caring for someone and cooperating with them and killing endless hordes of very human cannon fodder with nary a thought; apparently only the hopes and dreams of the main character are worth diving into. Booker's dismissing of practically everything about this magical cloud wonderland he finds himself in, or his refusal to engage in any form of self-reflection about himself or his actions, certainly don't help matters.  In fact, if I may be so bold I might say this game's core excellence is as a showpiece for the ideas promoted by Spec Ops: The Line. Do I feel like a hero yet? No, Bioshock Infinite. No, I do not.

Despite this game receiving a majority of popular feedback, I find it falls very short as a game. I do however feel that it is a fantastic piece of art. The environments are gorgeous, and exploring Colombia were rather enjoyable. Also the story was well told and quite moving despite some gaps in continuity. However that's the extent of its positive qualities.  As game it fails to be challenging, even on Hard mode the combat is incredibly trivial. Elizabeth can keep you feed with an infinite supply of ammo, health, and salts, which you don't even need because you can just kill everything with the skyhook. Aside from the combat the game was incredibly linear, with very few secrets, and of those that did exist none really provided any substantial benefit because the combat was so easy to begin with.  And again back to the problems with it being so linear, I can't help but compare it to the first Bioshock, which was also linear, however at least had multiple endings. With Bioshock: Infinite there is one ending, and honestly it's not that good. For a game that has a theme of infinite worlds with infinite possibilities you have only one ending? Really?  To sum it all up it's just not a good game; like I said the story was pretty good, but the combat is poor, and the player cannot change the outcome of the ending. In terms of gameplay it's more like Myst or Riven than a shooter. It's just a beautiful enviornment to explore. However, unlike Myst or Riven, Bioshock: Infinate is devoid of any choice or challenge. Overall I'd have to say that you would probably be better off just watching all the cutscenes on youtube, because it would make a better movie than a game.

In that old game, fighting was strategic and varied and the large levels offered tactical choices. Bottomline -- 'Infinite' is sadly a C+ game with an A- story.

Very few games move me enough to have me consider a second play through. BioShock Infinite is one of those games. From the story to the combat, I have enjoyed every last second of the Columbia experience. Please don't compare this to previous games with similar titles... and as such I will not compare them in this recommendation. What I will do is explain what I love about Infinite, and if it jives with what you also love in games, then you will enjoy this experience as well.  For one, without any spoilers, the story is tremendous. Not Dickens or Shakespeare, but for Sci-Fi fans who enjoy stories that try to stretch the imagination, this definitely satisfies.   Columbia itself is nicely fleshed-out with a lot of details. It's nice to see a city that is seemingly pleasant until you see the underlying fanaticism and bigotry. It is almost uncomfortable and off-putting, but makes the experience that much more real.  Besides story and setting, the remaining piece would be combat, of which I found quite satisfying. If you're not a fan of bullet-spongy baddies you've definitely come to the wrong place. I played through on Hard the first time, and the game definitely gave me a challenge. With only two weapons to swap between and a limited amount of Salt for Vigors (read Plasmids), I had to be very careful. It was easy to get myself killed by running out into the open; movement and cover is key.   Most of the weapons are satisfying although at first I was a bit confused by the red and blue ammo (each faction has similar weapons with their own sets of ammo); I think subsequent play-throughs I will focus on upgrading a handful of specific ones instead of spreading myself so thin.   As far as Vigors are concerned, I have to admit I enjoyed some more than others. While many where useful, when I eventually got 'Return to Sender' and 'Bucking Bronco', I was in love. There is a good variety of the usual suspects such as fire and electricity, and some interesting combos you can get (and there is an achievement for finding them all if you're into that sort of thing) by say lighting someone on fire and then charging them to create a bunch of fire-bombs that spread throughout the area.   Character building in Infinite is mostly about what weapons you upgrade, what Vigors you buy and upgrade, but also is a little bit about clothing. There are four pieces of clothing Booker can wear, each with its own passive bonus. A lot of the best clothing is found through exploration, so make sure you poke around the levels if you want to find something good. Over time you will find a set of gear that will complement your play style which is especially satisfying.  For me, this is a game that will stay on my hard drive for a long while. I'm not much for clutter, so usually uninstall games after completion. While not as consistently replayable as Borderlands, I certainly expect to go through this story again as well as the two Burial at Sea DLC packs.   If what I've written piques your interest, then go ahead and buy this game. Still unsure? It's old enough that you can find it somewhere online at a discount, so you really don't have much to lose. It's time for you to go visit Columbia today!

One of the worst sequels ever made. Everything is a step down from the original: Story, gameplay, setting. Everything.  Gameplay is Call of Duty tier: kill hordes of mundane enemies over and over completely lacking any thought or satisfaction in the deed. Guns are terrible. Seriously, there is not one gun in the game I do not reflect back upon with utter distain. In the original Bioshock weapon and plasmid upgrades were bought through separate resource pools. But in this game, EVERYTHING, and I mean EVERYTHING, is bought through the same pool. This means you don't have any room to experiment with the 'Vigor's' (which are just cut & pastes from the older game), and have to invest in solid shoot'em'up tactics because when you get right down to it, Vigor's are just something to call this game a 'Shock' game and not a 'Call of Dutes' game. You can only carry two guns at once, and there is easily 10+ ♥♥♥♥ tier guns polluting the gun pool with their ammo. Which means in certain engagements, your main upgraded guns will likely run out of ammo and you'll be forced to use terrible re-skins in their place. Shooting guns is sticky, slow, tedious and all around not fun.  Story takes a dive 1/4th into the game and from there on its a run and gun shoot'em up, all the way to the end with its exceptionally ill thought out ending (which doesn't resolve anything), but makes scrubs who don't want to feel stupid for not getting the ending shower it in praise for 'depth', when in actuality it's simple, dull & poorly thought out. Ken Levine Scrapped the real Bioshock Infinite when he ran out of time wasting it on MP no one wanted, and was forced to put this ♥♥♥♥ out on the market. Especially in character dialogue.  Setting is un-imaginative and in comparison with Rapture, Columbia doesn't hold any water (no pun intended). In Rapture, the city felt like a living enemy. The ocean and crumbling city always loomed with you, and you were always aware that you were in a tin-can with a sheet of flexi-glass between you and death. In Columbia, you can just jump off the side and insta respawn with no consequences Super Meat Boy style. Enemies lack explanation or purpose in the world of Columbia, (take the fireman & patriot) & those that do are incredibly un-original or just half-♥♥♥♥♥ (crow racist people, Handy-Man).  If you buy this game, I have no sympathy for you. BLEW MY MIND!!  The game itself is linear, bog standard gunplay, generic guns. Plasmids, plasmid upgrades and weapon upgrades whilst helpful play no bearing on progress or the style in which you would attempt to play through the game. This isn't the spiritual successor to System Shock 2, it's not even the spiritual seccessor to Bioshock, it's a Shock game in name only in my opinion...rapture references, plasmids, steampunk and noir stylings notwithstanding.  It excels however in storytelling, serving up an experience drenched in art and design stylings which are arguably as good as it gets. This is flanked by one of the best looking and best optimised engines I think I've seen of late. Cities in the clouds, beeches, shantytowns, factories, Rapture are all brought to life with vibrant lighting and visual effects. Every scene is a picture postcard, breathing.....alive.  Small moments in game such as when you first meet Elizabeth. She's painting a picture of the Eiffel tower in France but after pondering the results of her picture instead decides to open a 'tear' in space and time and as you look through the 'tear' Tears for Fears can be heard blaring amongst the background hustle and bustle of a Parisian street, Return of the Jedi is shown as playing at a cinema on said street. Bioshock Infinite overflows with moments such as this and the result is that it elevates a fairly average, linear FPS to a captivating, involving experience.  The ending pretty much cements any positive opinions I had on the game, it made my head spin, it was unexpected, satisfying, borderline perfect actually.

Most of us have all played the stellar Bioshock 1 and 2, and we've all made the obvious comparisons in our head when we think of Bioshock Infinite: the weapon limit, linear level structure, and a new mind-bending story. Among the top complaints are these three nuances that play an exceptional and pivotal role in Infinite; to some, the streets of Columbia are too linear when compared to the openness of Rapture, to others, the new weapon system doesn't adequately compliment the new baddies, and to a stubborn select few, the story simply either makes no sense or isn't quite as memorable as the first installment. To each his own, I suppose, but when we consider these 'faults' to hold the experience back, we make room for further diminishing of the series as a whole. We have to feel some empathy for the developers at Irrational and understand what kind of thought was put not only into Rapture's cavernous tunnels, but Columbia's banner-ridden streets.  Unfortunately, I won't go into any detail about that stuff, because I don't (or didn't) work at Irrational, I wasn't there for the writing process, and I've never seen how these concepts fly into Ken Levine's head. What I CAN do, lacking this information, is NOT compare Rapture and Colombia at all. Bioshock Infinite is in a completely new setting, with completely new characters, and while it may follow some similar ideas and share a basic plotline, what we know about either game is so NOT subjective, so NOT interchangeable that it makes no sense to start comparing at all. They share the same title, so what? Vigors or Plasmids? Who cares? What difference does it make if Bioshock wants to take us into the sky for an adventure we can't quite explore so well as an underwater palace? There's a lot less room for walking up in the sky, mind you.  If you found fault in the game not because you found inconsistencies regarding this and the 2007 giant, but because you simply couldn't get a grip on the controls, the mechanics, or the story, by all means, you have your victory, and there's no sense in fighting over a cause you've already won. However, I have one message to those who insist to deem such tremendous games to be similar only because they share rather malleable concepts: BREAK THOSE CHAINS. ARE YOU A MAN, OR ARE YOU A SLAVE? I'm not trying to insult, I'm not trying to incite argument, I'm only trying to remove the slight tarnish that comes with a reputation, be it good or evil. When Bioshock decides to move a few miles up out of the water, you COMMIT, you don't QUESTION why it's moved or try to calculate the actual distance between the two.  Again, to each his own, but I don't like sitting back and watching a game become progressively reviled because it is by law a member of the Bioshock series and therefore must be treated as inferior to its predecessor. In time, all things will eventually pass, and I should save my ranting for the future, but for now, I hereby declare that you will find no error in any three of these games. Should you find error in any of them, please make certain that you are judging the game in its own right. While there are some franchises that DESERVE the compare/contrast treatment (Assassin's Creed and Call of Duty are the ostensible ones), Bioshock is NOT one of them.  Buy it, play it, love it. Just don't let the gritty bluish sepia of another masterpiece ruin this one.

This is a long review so if you just want a brief summary of why I recommend BioShock Infinite then skip to  Results  and read from there.   Irrational Games takes what 2K started did and pushes it above and beyond reality. One cannot come to words for how to describe BioShock Infinite as there are no words that possibly capture its essence.    Story:  As you sit in your little office you are given an offer, one that will allow you to be free of all that you owe. Two people, a man and a woman, provide you with an ultimatum with you accept. You are given the opportunity to go to a world in the clouds and retrieve a girl. As you push through your mission you will learn more about yourself than you ever wanted to know.    Campaign:  BioShock Infinite campaign is of decent length. Depending on the difficulty you chose and your play-style you get through this game from anywhere between 10-16 hours. I would recommend taking your time as this game is more about the story than the gameplay and missing the smallest element can result in a completely different understanding. The campaign is divvied up across 40-chapters, all varying in length, some take only a minute, while others you’ll be wondering for at-least an hour. An interesting element in Infinite is that almost all of the cinematics involve player interaction. You control basic camera elements, as well as in some scenes interaction with the environment. This provides a more immersive campaign than traditional games.    Gameplay:  BioShock Infinite does away with tonics, ADAM, and limited weapon upgrades. Instead of Plasmids you use Vigors, which are essentially the same thing with a different name. The only currency in the game is Silver Eagles, most likely based on the US Silver Dollar and Half-Dollar. You can use this money to buy weapon upgrades, Vigor upgrades, and ammo/health/salts. Unlike in the first two you no longer need to acquire Adam to get Vigor upgrades, which means you can customize your gameplay based on what you plan to use more. I was weapon intensive so I spent all my cash on weapon upgrades, and only upgraded on Vigor for the achievement. You also don’t buy Vigors instead you unlock them for free throughout the campaign which means you will have every single one by the end of the game.   There are 14-weapons that you will find throughout the campaign: Sky-Hook, Broadsider Pistol, China Boom Shotgun, Triple R Machine Gun, Huntsman Carbine, Bird’s Eye Sniper Rifle, Paddywhacker Hand Cannon, Peppermill Crank Gun, Pig Flak Volley Gun, Heater, Burstgun, Repeater, and Hail Fire. So you won’t feel limited in this game by your weapon choice, as you have more than you can ever imagine. Although despite all these choices you can only ever carry two-weapons at one time. So you will more than likely stick to what you like, as you may not get it back for a while if you let it go.   A new feature to the series is Infusions; infusions are vials found throughout the campaign that allow you to increase your health, shield, or salts (mana). Depending on your play-style you may find more or less of these throughout the campaign, but you will probably not find them all. Some are in secret areas, while others are right infront of your very eyes. Infusions allow you to customize yourself without limiting your capital.   Results:  BioShock Infinite is an amazingly beautiful game that is aweing and terrifying at the same time. Like all BioShocks you will enter confused and cautious, but as the game unfolds you will never want to put it down. The story is beautiful, the gameplay is fantastic, the music is breathtaking, and the environment is inspirational. As you play you will learn more about yourself that you can imagine through even the simplest choices, heads or tails?  Pros: +Amazing story, amazing doesn’t even breach how brilliant it is. +Beautiful environment, you will stand there just to look at how beautiful the architecture is, how elegant the people are, how clean the world is. +Amazing music, the music is simple but rather still brings much depth to the game. Even the combat music draws shivers up your spine. +Great graphics engine, as well as a fantastic optimization tool.  +Awesome boss battles, which keep you on your toes  Cons: -The enemies are kind of lacking (Most of them are the same enemy with a different gun) -The combat AI is rather limited, I found myself taking advantage of how stupid they were on many occasions. -They got rid of the manual saves (if you have a busy schedule you sometimes don’t have time to find a checkpoint).

Not everyone was entirely happy or impressed with where the developers chose to take this third entry in the almost-legendary Bioshock series, but in my opinion the decisions made were mostly the 'right' ones. MOSTLY.     Let me just say straight up - and this may well be an opinion subject to change given that I've played the first two games twice and this one but once - that this is probably my 'least favourite' of the three games. This is a purely personal thing: I am, on the whole, more a fan of 'horror' than other fantasy-related genres, and while the first two games were perhaps not strictly of said genre, they certainly leaned more heavily toward that side of things than this latest instalment does.    Which brings us to the first two significant decisions made during the development of this game: first up, the change of setting from ruined, claustrophobic underwater city to a city in the clouds rapidly HEADED towards downfall; and secondly, the shifting of the main 'enemy' type from insane, physically-deformed mutants (some with the rough equivalent of supernatural powers) to well-armed soldiers and revolutionaries caught in a power-struggle to either defend or bring down the mad 'prophet' who founded their would-be utopia.    It's obviously a matter of purely personal taste which of these two 'tones' one prefers...but in spite of myself generally favouring the former, I do have to say that they really COULD NOT have gotten away with a third game set in the city of Rapture. So all things considered, I'm conceding that they probably made the 'right' decision. It was due time to change things up a little, and they've done so in a way which is equal parts 'obvious' (moving from a city under the sea to a city in the clouds) and 'inspired' (they really could have just done another POST-apocalyptic scenario, but instead chose to tell an entirely different story...and good for them)!    This said, the actual GAMEPLAY is remarkably similar to the earlier games, with one important exception: they've replaced a bunch of lovable (if slightly creepy) little girls with a single grown woman, and this is arguably where things become most different. Say goodbye to the oddly endearing task of liberating and/or baby-sitting 'Little Sisters', and say hello to a sassy, would-be 'romantic' interest who's constantly torn between despising our (anti-) hero for his 'brute'-like behaviour, and being strangely attracted to him for, well, basically the same reasons (hmmph...women)!    Not only does this change the tone of the piece quite significantly - call me a sap and/or misogynist, but I was actually quite moved by all the 'take care of the cute little gals' antics of parts 1 and 2 - but in effect also makes this a much more linear experience than the first two games. Our only reason to 'backtrack' now is to get more goodies hidden behind doors which our female companion can helpfully pick the locks of, rather than the far more involved task of harvesting 'ADAM' required in the first two games.    In short, we've lost a bit of tiny bit of strategizing along the way, in favour of a more straight-forwardly arcade-y experience of moving from location to location and killing lots of things and picking up a bunch of stuff. Again...personal preference will decide for the individual whether this is a good or bad thing. I myself found it all a bit repetitive and 'draggy' towards the end, and found myself mainly using only two of the eight 'vigors'/special powers on offer, but y'know...that's just me.     Whichever way you look at it, this is still a pretty smart, classy game. It boasts some of the best graphics in video game history (think an ultraviolent 'Disney' cartoon, and you're getting warm), and a pretty interesting storyline to boot (though I gotta say, the people who made such a huge fuss over the supposedly 'controversial' ending...you people really need to read more, or at the very least stop watching all those ♥♥♥♥ing Michael Bay and Marvel movies, 'cause it really wasn't THAT much of a mind-blowing revelation at the end).    There's every chance I'll even find myself utterly adoring it the second time around, but right now...frankly, I'm a little 'spectacular'-ed out. Which is a way of saying this game isn't exactly anyone's definition of 'subtle', so if that's what you're looking for...I dunno, maybe try Gone Home or something instead. But if it's slam-bang action and jaw-dropping scenery you want, with just a pinch of cleverness and mind-♥♥♥♥ing thrown into the narration to add a bit of spice, there's not much risk of finding disappointment here.    Verdict: 9/10.

Visually intriguing, but otherwise a generic shooter, with cliched writing.   The game has a few good concepts, but it never truly utilizes either of them, or in some cases, they just fall too short of being interesting. The world is set up to be big and explorable, but then changes direction, and ends up being a literal horde fest, with little to no user interaction. You can collect things, and that's about it. Most of the weapons are horrible, and you'll find yourself constanly looking for ammo. Even though you're able to buy them from dispensers, It's just never enough, and you end up running back and forth in search for it.  Because of this, and the linear 'hit-n-run' objectives, the gameplay quickly becomes boring and repetitive. The game tells you at the start, that it's not always the best option to fight, however, you can't do much else, seeing how sneaking is either practically impossible, or it goes overboard and your enemies won't notice you, even after you repetadly stab them in the back.  The 'Story Rich' tag is ridiculous, as the whole plot can be summed up within 2 sentences. Character development is forced, and badly timed, with idiotic symbolism, that just feels out of place. An example would be making a character randomly cut her hair, for the sake of showing a personal 'change', which is laughable and weak. A woman won't suddenly become more masculine and reliable from a change in hair style, nor will that show any determination. It's also painfully obvious, that the inclusion of such and similar tropes were for fetishistic reasons, and lazy writing. The creators tried to justify all this with a wannabe 'artistic' ending, with make-belief deepness, which ends up being half-♥♥♥♥♥ and totally out of place.  All in all, it's clear that this was made for a more casual, and child like audience, who's only reference for comparison is COD.  ##############################UPDATE#############################  So I came back to this game after half a year, and replayed it, thinking that I might have been too harsh on it. What I came to find, wasn't that big of a difference.  The thin plot not only makes me cringe, but manages to have more holes in it than an empty shopping cart. There's numerous things that don't even make sense, I bet the lead writer just thought, that using transdimensional time traveling will just 'fix itself', and 'oh well but it's just a different dimension' will be a good enough excuse for bad writing. Albeit I have to admit that one or two supporting characters are indeed interesting.   The guns aren't as horrible as I remembered, but they're definetaly bad. It doesn't help that the game misleads you either, it constantly reminds you that short bursts are more accurate, and effective against enemies, which is not true at all. If you've ever played any FPS games, you would think like that statement, and would certainly approve it, but in this game, that's not happening. Simply because there's literary no recoil on anything, and it doesn't matter how you use your weapons, the accuracy will be the exact same thing. Using small amounts of bursts against multiple 'tanks' is practically suicide in most cases, it's a lot more effective to just camp and hold down your fire button, and spam your enemy with bullets. So yeah, go and trust the game, and you'll be constantly seeing the revive animation.  Vigors help you a lot, but again, the game eats your ammo as fast as a Mortal Kombat arcade machine. There are instances where it's impossible to even stock up on any ammo for any weapon, and you'll be facing a horde of enemies without any. Relying solely on your generic 'melee'' attack, makes surviving a pain in the ♥♥♥, I tell ya.   It also doesn't help that you sometimes can get stuck in an object lying on the ground, or hear enemies, but can't see them, until you use bucking bronco, pushing them afloat in the air, because they decided to bug into the ground. In some cases, the amount of projectile, and effects makes it literary impossible to see anything, rendering you practically blind, until you somehow manage to get onto a skyline, or in a safe cover. Civillians also just randomly disappear most of the time, but I guess that's just me nitpicking too much.   Oh yes, shout out to the people claiming that BI is ballsy for having 3 instances (literary that many sentences) of reference to racism: It's not.  I wouldn't say it's a bad game, it's decent, and somewhat replayable, with an interesting world concept, but there's a lot of room for improvement, especially with the combat system, so my review stays negative. It could have been easily better with a coherent writer, and some gameplay elements could still be post-fixed with a patch, but I don't see that ever happening.

I love the original Bioshock; I played the original one on the Xbox 360, and it was one of the best single player game I have ever played. It was so cleverly made... the morality elements and story was the most compelling part about it. In Bioshock Infinite, they refreshed these factors very well much like the original (I haven't played Bioshock II yet). This game feels very, very much like the original Bioshock, but at the same time, it feels like a different game. The team that made Infinite completely redesigned the game; goodbye plasmids, we now have Vigors. No more 'hacking', but there's possession, which does something similar. No more carrying an armory of weapons (Which kind of saddens me; you can now only carry 2 guns now), but you have an amazing partner (Elizabeth) that tosses you ammo, health, and salts (Which replaces EVE and powers vigors) when you need it. The story is very indepth, even more so than the original. I would highly recommend taking you're time while playing this game; If you just rush through it like a regular shooters game, you are TOTALLY missing the point of Bioshock. The audio logs and story just makes this game feels so complete. Not just that, the combat mechanism is fun as well and balanced. If you really enjoyed the original Bioshock, then this game will not disappoint you.   PS. Elizabeth is the best NPC I have played with in a game... I think I'm in love with her.

The third in the Bioshock series, Bioshock Infinite is the latest from the mind of Ken Levine. This game had a lot of hype going on about it at release and, I must say, it's all true. This game is an amazing work and can truly put to rest the 'video games as art' debate. Infinite is easily on the top 5 games I have ever played list, and this is factoring in the age I was at when I played it. What I'm saying is playing this game was a better experience than playing Super Smash Brothers or Goldeneye was when I was 8 years old and they were top of the line games - Infinite is one of the greatest gaming experiences I have ever had the pleasure of going through in my lifetime. It is a modern marvel of genius and inspiration and the world building utilized to construct Columbia somehow outdoes the already incredible world of Rapture.   Bioshock Infinite is an adventure that grips you from start to finish and doesn't let you go even after you've completed the game. It is easily my Game of the Year and I honestly believe that it will be looked at for years to come as a shining example of the true power gaming as a medium has to convey narrative, emotion, action, and immersion to the viewer. The characters are memorable, and you develop real attachments to them, compassion, anger, fear...I thought April Ryan from The Longest Journey was the most well-defined female protagonist in video games. I was wrong. Elizabeth is a character that will stick with you in your head, and her dynamism is only outdone by the change in emotions she can provoke within the player.  While my review is glowing, the game is not perfect. There are several things that could have been improved on; however, these details are so minor when compared to the overarching entity that is Bioshock Infinite it would detract from the experience to even shed light on these mere inconveniences. How can one detract from greatness because, for example, cloth doesn't move when you run into it? None of that matters when a game like this can sink its claws into you from the moment you begin and pull you so deeply into itself that you never want the adventure to end.  Pros: Narrative Story World Building Immersion Characters Character Development Gameplay/Mechanics Polish  Cons: Only saves at checkpoints, I wish there was a quicksave feature  You know how people still look back at Half Life 2 as an example of gaming excellence? Bioshock Infinite not only meets that standard, but I feel exceeds it. This game deserves its high praise, and can easily sit in the company of such classics as the Half Life series. Bioshock Infinite is the new benchmark, and is a game that must be played by anyone and everyone.  A+

As much as i mourned the death of rapture, the backstory, scenery and overall feel of bioshock infinite more than makes up for the loss of our much loved underwater paradise.  Amongst the many improvements between the games, one of the more admirable features - which i am so glad the dev team decided to implement - was a vocal main protagonist. Booker is responsive to the situations/discussions he finds himself thrown into, which helps attain that sense of immersion developers strive to create. It does the job far better than any Gordon Freeman character ever could. Can't really talk about Booker without mentioning Elizabeth too :- the best AI companion i have ever seen in a game. The lengths the designers went to to make her feel as if she were a real companion, it's simply amazing. Cant really go into detail about the characters and storyline otherwise i'd be spoiling the game, but both are great and are fluid such that you just want to see what waits around the next corner...    Most likely a bloody turret.     My only general complaint about Bioshock infinite is that the worst thing about it is also one of its biggest strengths - it's completely different whilst being more or less exactly the same. Rapture? plasmids. Columbia? Vigors. Big daddies? Rapture. Handymen? Columbia. Rapture? Atlas/Eleanor. Colombia? Elizabeth. Civil war? Colombia & Rapture. A lot of the core elements feel as if they have just been reskinned and repackaged as something new - though ultimately they are pretty much some of the reasons i fell in love with the series. So if anything, it refreshed the franchise while retaining what i really held dear to it. Don't mistake the similarities as its only content however, as there are a fair few scenarios that you would never have expected to see in a bioshock game. Lets just put it like that.  As far as the little details are concerned, the top end graphics are beautiful, the combat is often mixed up in most situations and there are a few places you'll visit which will give you a hint of nostalgia. With the graphics though, its a killer for lower end machines even on lower settings. At least have the reccomended stats to have a reasonably enjoyable time.  To sum up, i'd definetely reccomend it to anyone thats played the previous games, even to the newcomers to bioshock (though you may not understand a few references hidden in the enviroments). Cant wait for the next installment ^_^  *EDIT - No longer waiting for next installment. Irrational Games is dead.

BioShock Infinite trades the gloomy city of Rapture for the sunny city of Columbia. However, that does not mean that things in Columbia are bright and cheerful. The combat in Infinite is very similar to the previous games. Mixing plasmids (in this game, they're called vigors) with guns was fun in the first two games and it's even more fun in this one. Many of the vigors can be combined for extra damage against enemies, such as dousing an enemy in water and then shocking them.   I really liked how the environment of BioShock Infinite was much more open than that of previous BioShock games. Unlike the cramped corridors of the first two games, the environments in Infinite allow you to be a lot more mobile as you engage enemies.   The story is phenomenal. I don't want to say much of it for fear of spoiling the story, but the story is the best part of the game by far. That's not to devalue the gunplay -- it's fun and engaging. But, BioShock games have always focused on delivering a great story and Infinite certainly does not falter.   Unlike other BioShock games, you have an AI partner (don't want to say any spoilers about her name) for most of the game. Most games have really poor ally AI, what with them always running into enemies and other frustrating mechanics. But your partner in Infinite is amazing. She gives you health, she gives you salts, and she even gives you ammo. But best of all, she doesn't run into enemies and she can't die. So many games force the most crappy allied AI upon you, but Infinite does a great job of having an AI partner be fun and useful (for once).   Lastly, I'd definitely recommend picking up the Season Pass for this game. Most developers tack DLC on their games to make a quick buck, but the DLC really adds to the game and the overarching story of the BioShock universe. Clash in the Clouds is a little lackluster -- it's a fairly fun but also fairly frustrating arena style mode. But Burial at Sea Episodes 1 and 2 add so much to the story from Infinite and the BioShock series as a whole.   If you haven't already purchased it, I recommend buying BioShock Infinite with the Season Pass. It has great gameplay and an even greater story.

BSI isn't a bad game but it falls short of the original Bioshock. The graphics are nice and stylized. There are a lot of varied settings, but the game has been streamlined to the point it misses greatness. While I appreciate shooters with wide open spaces, it is rather hard to do well from a combat mechanic perspective. You can only carry two weapons and rather little ammo. The weapons are not very interesting either. Some only serve to be replaced by other weapons. Scrounging for ammo and heath is rather stupid as you can't carry med kits and the ammo is very limited so you always have either have full ammo or no ammo. This is the opposite of what Bioshock did. The AI is either a critique of religious zealots or just bad. To make up for the bad AI enemies sometimes just have 10 times the HP of other enemies. Plasmids have been marginalized and are not used for puzzles. Instead you can ride a kind of roller coaster or open portals. Both of these aren't very interesting from a gameplay perspective. The boss fights aren't interesting but then again they never really were in the series. While I am criticizing it I will also add that you can’t save the game manually and you just get resurrected when you die. There are certainly plot twists but they are much more cutscene related. It may sound like I hate the game, but I don't. It could have been much more though. It has great atmosphere, excellent acting, and the first side kick character I don't find annoying. It also solves the original’s lack of NPCs that are trying to not kill you or not behind a glass wall. It is a much less lonely game that the original.   I am not sure how critics can give the game an A with the combat faults (I played on hard until the last level where there didn’t seem to be enough ammo so I switched to normal)  Anyway I paid about 10 dollars for the game and I got my money's worth.   Grade: B

'Bring us the girl and wipe away the debt'  From the get go: Bioshock Infinite is NOT a game for everyone. If you prefer games that focus purely on gameplay and don't focus on the story then you should not get this game. But if you like games with an complex story,beautiful architecture, great level design and insanely well-written characters then this is the game for you.  Graphics: 9/10; You will be stunned of what the unreal 3 engine is capeable of when you first enter Columbia. The world in Bioshock is filled with so much details that it warmed my heart because most developers don't care for them in games these days. Although the overall picture is sometimes dulled by some muddy textures this game still looks great.  Sound: 10/10; not much to say here. The Weapons sound great, the sountrack is phenomenal and the dubbing actors are some of the best I have ever heard in a game/movie.  Gameplay: 9/10; This is clearly Bioshocks biggest 'weakness'. The gameplay in itself can get repeteitive because there are not many different types of enemies, but because the story is so great you feel like having a reason to fight. Throughout the game I had much fun combining the different weapons and vigors and some gameplay elements like the tears or the skyhook give the game an extra kick.  Level Design: 10/10; Not only is Columbia a beatiful place to look at, but it is also a great place to explore. Allthough the levels are not as big as in Bioshock 1 there are many details hidden in every place of the city. If you take your time you will love this game even more. It just feels so original and not a single place in the game was recycled. Every level feels different.  Story: 11/10; The story of Bioshock Infinite is a gem. From the beginning till the very last minutes of the game you will ask yourself 'how will it continue? how will it end?'. The whole game long it will keep you entertained on a level that I thought wasn't even possible. The characters are amazing. In some situations I allmost forgot that it is 'just a game'. Infinite will create emotions like fear,sadness,rage and hate with such ease that it will leave you wondering why other developers can't do this. And I can promise you 1 thing if nothing else: After finishing the game you will remember every single chapter of the story. It will burn into your brain and won't let you go.

How many First-Person-Shooters did you already play? How many vivid memorys do you still have of them? Maybe 2 or 3 each; beginning, favourite weapon and the final battle?  Bioshock Infinite is different. When others try to impress with never ending explosions and proclaim that as highlight, Infinite sows brilliant, but sometimes confusing, ideas in your mind mixed with deep emotions and complements it with a good dose of gunfights, high speed skyrailing and more or less supernatu...biogenetic powers.  First of all, the game is a thought experiment...a thought experiment with quite good graphics and amazing sound as well as music. The developers from Irrational Games (quite fitting name, right?) will send you and Booker DeWitt (the Hero) through atmospheric and panoramic landscapes...cloudscapes, maybe? Because except for the beginning the whole story takes place in Columbia, a town in the clouds with bright sunshine and never before seen technology. Speaking of story...where the bright sun dwells, it casts long and dark shadows... To speak more detailed about the plot and its twists would ruin the experience playing it, so I will leave that aside.  Just two words:Unfolding ingenuity.  But what stands out most is the Lady in blue and white, Elizabeth. It isn't even her fantastic voice actress or her animations, which are on a enormously high standart, rather it is that A.I. of her. In battles she takes cover, shouts the position of dangerous enemys, is never in your way, supports with ammunition or with some abillitys of her, reacts to your actions...etc.. In more peaceful moments she gives additional information on the environment or on her life so far, picks locks like Houdini, searches places for useful items nobody would even consider to look for...and hands it over! Moreover she feels complete. It is the way she moves around or idly stands, the way she brings a smile on your face or most important: She talks to you in situations, you would talk to her in real life. She is a companion done right...and that is rare.  One tip along the journey I recommend you, with this review, to take: Play on hard difficulty... in nearly every situation DeWitt is superior to his foes, so in order to die you have to do it deliberately (most of the time...yeah I know there is this one...you will see).  A last question to start the thought experiment... ...bird or cage?

If walking through a motion picture is your thing, this game is for you. The story and progression is quite linear, but that isn't to say it is a bad story. It's quite good. The game looks gorgeous, comes with gruesome kills and a whole bunch of find-it achievements that were designed to cause your inner OCD child to have a meltdown, seeing as you can't backtravel if you missed something.   My biggest complaint is the bland combat. While visually exciting to watch the effects of certain vigors on the enemies, you're really only fighting them to progress the story and watch the violent outcome of your light gun. There is no grit to the combat. There's no rush from escaping impending doom, no real penalty for dying (even played on hardest difficulty, which I highly recommend to anyone who has ever used a mouse before), and with the exception of one obtusely difficult enemy which you only see a few (3?) times in the game, it's a walk in the park. Not including the one boss, and counting different colored grunts using a shotgun versus a machinegun as one type, there are only five (5!) enemies in the game. You're shooting things to watch them go boom so you can listen to Elizabeth discover the outside world.  If the exploration factor and the storyline wasn't as good as it is, I'd have put this down and been upset at my purchase. Really the only thing that made it difficult was trying to get all the achievements in one playthrough, a choice I decided upon as my own difficulty modifier, because the game was simply too easy.  Buy it on sale, or wait for a sale. Also so far, season pass has Burial at Sea pt 1 (took me 2 hours, and that was turning over every stone and attempting all achievements), and a wave mode where you compete for high score with CiTC. Unfortunately, a wave mode is only fun if the combat is entertaining.  Tips:  -Play on hard. -Once you leave an area, it's gone. Do your searching, side questing, and loot hording before you leave the area (you're prompted yes/no). -Upgrade the items you like. You will not obtain enough money to upgrade even half of your items and vigors. I died maybe 6 times (the only way to lose money, even then it's VERY minimal, almost trivial) through the whole game, and I'd like to think I hoovered every inch of everywhere. -You'll have enough lockpicks. Open it. It's always worth it. -If you buy the DLC, the only way to get your infusions is at the BEGINNING of the game. Don't try the game, then buy the DLC. You'll miss out on half of your early bird bonus. -If Elizabeth stops to look at a random pile of junk, you probably should too. 75% of the time, there's something there.

Beyond any shadow of doubt, Bioshock Infinite is a top contender for GOTY.  Being my first time entering the Bioshock world, my opinions on the game weren't biased or influenced by how it held in comparison with the previous titles. While I'm unsure how the game stands with the last two games I can say with the utmost confidence that this game is a blast from start to finish, and you would be missing out if you choose to ignore it. The combat is open, giving the player a shield for defence, a multitude of fully customizable weapons and powers called 'Vigors' to dole out pain to those in your path. Certain enemies are annoying to fight, like the Ravens and the Handymen but for the vast majority the combat was enjoyable, even if the shield was as strong as wet paper. Throughout the game the player is accompanied with an NPC ally, Elizabeth. Unlike other NPCs Elizabeth isn't the kind of character who needs excessive hand-holding, and when she's introduced a message informs the player that she can take care of herself. She doesn't get in the way of gameplay and actually contributes greatly by locating ammo, health and Salts for the player when he runs low on any. The story is the kind that if I mention a single bit of it then the entire game is spoiled, all I'll say is that it is well written and flows magnificently, weaving in with itself throughout the game to form an intricate pattern.  However, I can't say that the game has much of a replay value. While the combat was good it was far from memorable and didn't have as much of a lasting effect on me as the story did (except for the fast-paced Skyline riding, that was a lot of fun). As well the game suffers from FPS drops and stuttering, as a side-effect of being a near direct console port.  All things considered, Bioshock Infinite is an unforgettable experience with a story that will have the player immersed and invested from start to finish.

With the release of BioShock Infinite, developer Irrational has delivered a bigger story, more polished experience, and created two similar-yet-separate games that can co-exist and remain equal in quality. This is my favorite game I have ever played, hands down.  The storyline is intricate and enthralling, with characters who are believable with their own flaws ad virtues. The Elizabeth character is the most lifelike npc companion I've encountered to date, and her presence makes exploring the world even more enjoyable. The setting is fantastic, and together with all the posters, lighting and npc/voxaphone dialogue, it really feels like you are in a vibrant living world. The music in the game is also fantastic, with many songs from the 1910s and 1920s era. Furthermore, they flawlessly produced many modern songs in the old fashioned styles (eg ragtime) which was a massive highlight from the game.  The game must be appreciated for its artistic genius first, and as a game second, which is possibly the source of the disappointment and negative views. The combat is passable but nothing remarkable. It serves merely as a tool to keep players exited, and to break up periods of exploration which many players in the target audience would tire of without the adrenaline rush they've come to expect in a shooter, and does not add to the plot. In fact, the most exhilarating parts of the story contain no shooting at all. The periods of peaceful exploration, such as at the start of the game, where there is no threat were my favorite parts in the game, and I really do wish there was more of this. There are so many snippets of dialogue, hidden audio tracks in the background and interactions with the game world in these short periods of the game, that I found I spent much less time fighting in battles than simply exploring every nook and cranny of this vibrant and fully fleshed out world. Truly a rare gem in today's game industry. Morrowind, Telltale's Walking Dead/Wolf Among Us and The Witcher 2 are the only other similar artistic games which come to mind, and these fall far short of the bar raised by Infinite.

I’ll admit it; I was not a fan of BioShock. Back in 2007 when the first BioShock game came out, I admittedly didn’t give it a fair chance. Even when BioShock 2 was released and all my gamer buddies were chomping at the bit for another foray into Rapture, I was more so “le meh”. I know, kind of troll-ish but that was how I approached it. I remember when I first saw screenshots and footage of BioShock Infinite and the original debut trailer, I was blown away by this new art direction the series was taking. In place of the bleak solitary horror film-esque tone of the first game, this new world was bright and vibrant with an air of vaudeville sensibilities. Before I continue with this review, I have to mention that it takes a lot for a stubborn bloke like myself to just “change” his mind from something I was so convinced of. I did not like BioShock, and I just put it away much like how I wrote off many other things I didn’t give a fair chance to. BioShock Infinite did for me what many of my friends couldn’t convince my stubborn ♥♥♥ to do, and that was give the first BioShock a fair playthough, and while a few of the things that turned me off a bit still persist, I have to say already being half way through, I am enjoying myself. BioShock Infinite was a memorable gaming experience that I will hold near to my heart, that reason alone was enough to load up BioShock again.  Welcome to the floating state of Columbia. BioShock Infinite takes place in the early 1900’s in a city floating above the United States. Columbia has seceded from the US and rather than still sharing the land, they float above it with a holier-than-thou gaze, a theme that seems ever present throughout the game’s narrative. You are Booker DeWitt, a man down on his luck with debt to his ears. He is tasked with infiltrating Columbia to rescue Elizabeth, a girl who has been kept under lock and key since she was an infant, and take her back with him to New York. With that, Booker satisfies his employers and his debt will be paid. Rescuing the girl isn’t that simple though, Booker will have to face down the leader of Columbia, Zachary Comstock, and a giant beast called Songbird. Booker and Elizabeth’s adventure quickly spirals into a story touching on themes of politics, religion, racism, classism, and of course quantum mechanics.  Despite some incredibly heavy subject matter, the game’s narrative never leaves you wondering “WTF” too often, a few moments may leave you perplexed, but this isn’t like your typical boy meets girl story. Speaking of that, I am so glad that the story didn’t all of a sudden melt into a melodramatic love ballad between the two protagonists. I love a good love story but it would feel incredibly out of place with the narrative. Comstock is an almost perfect villain for the story with Songbird being a truly terrifying monster. What makes Comstock so perfect is how his influence in an effect will turn every resident in Columbia against you; you are the enemy of the state, the false shepherd meant to lead his flock astray. The grand religious undertones are more than evident through most of the game. Songbird is a massive beast, ever watching and searching for Elizabeth, its main directive is to protect her and return her to the tower if she is ever to leave. Some of the best moments of the story come when the pair is forced to deal with and confront Songbird.  One of Elizabeth’s powers is her ability to open “tears” in the space-time-continuum. These tears lead to another world (or version of the world). The tears stand as the main driving force of the game’s narrative. Are you familiar with the theory behind quantum mechanics? One simple explanation is that for every choice we make, there is the possibility of another choice that directly contrasts. It theorized that if you go left, immediately another world is created where you make the choice to go right instead. This creates a seemingly “infinite” (see what I did there?) possibility of worlds. Elizabeth’s power allows her to access these worlds, interacting with them whether it is an item that wasn’t there before or (eventually) walking into them entirely. It takes a little bit to wrap your head around it, but this leads perfectly to subtitling the game “Infinite”.  This isn’t 2007s BioShock. When you trade a city under the sea for a city above the clouds, the scenery changes drastically. Gone are the dark corridors and glass pipes connecting one deck to the next. Instead, we have beautiful scenery and bright vibrant colors. One of the reasons I was so turned off by the original BioShock was the overall ambiance of the level design. While Rapture felt incredibly isolating, I never felt alone while traversing Columbia. From the buildings to the beaches, Irrational Games paid close attention to all the little details. Levels are designed fairly linear with some encouraging the player to deviate a bit, mostly for scavenging or side quests, been never too far off the beaten path. At times, Elizabeth will stop and mention that you can either continue the story or take a detour for some supplies. Generally this is a good chance to stock up on salts, bring your health back up, or scrounge abandoned crates for ammo and money.   I was not a BioShock fan when I first bought this game and my purchase was driven solely by the artistic choices the developers made, BioShock Infinite is a great choice for the person who wasn't a BioShock fan At some point in the game, they mention that stealing from folk or provoking the authorities will result in some unsavory consequences, but these are rarely explored. Personally I felt that was a bit of a missed opportunity, they could have implemented a simple morality system into the overarching narrative. Some points do allow a bit of choice, but never beyond a glorified heads or tails. Columbia feels huge, and if it wasn’t for the fairly linear and direct quest path, I feel like I’d be lost most of the time. Though I wouldn’t say this is a bad thing, as I stated earlier the scenery is beautiful, every extra minute I can spend admiring the world in this game was well worth it.  A final thought that comes to mind, in reflection of my time playing BioShock Infinite I feel this sense of regret. It's a bittersweet feeling mind you, this isn't regret from disappointment in the game mechanics or story, based on my review it's obvious how much I loved this game. My regret stems from that fact that never again will I feel the same way I did when I first played this game, never again will I get to experience Columbia the way I did when I first saw that vibrant skyline. I do intend to replay this game sometime down the road mind you, but it won't be the same as my first... There's something inherently beautiful about that.

In retrospect, nothing truly stood out for this title as compared to other titles, except for maybe its unqie presentation style, consisting of a story told via a not-very-well-done shooter, although the decent storyline compensates for the FPS element. (Let's face it, who plays Bioshock for the shooting? GO VIGORS! :D)  Setting of Columbia is charming in its own right, bright but enigmatic, as opposed to Rapture's gloomy atmosphere in previous Bioshock titles.  Vigor mechanics is quite beautifully done to say the least, I had fun trying to figure out the various Vigor combinations, such as the 'Fire' and the 'Crow', when use simultaneously, spawns flaming crows instead.  Redundant 'shield' component gets terribly annoying after awhile, since your screen will 'break' when your shield is depleted. Without actively expanding the capacity of the shield, it breaks 3-4 times in an average firefight, and the shield break animation (that takes up half of the screen) is unbearable when playing for long hours. (Imagine getting a pop-up every minute or so when you're engaged in firefight)  Gameplay lasts around 10-12hours for an average playthrough, shooting mechanics isn't spectacular, and it lacks in replayability due to story-centric game presentation style. (It's like reading a book again, which not everybody would(and could) enjoy).  Definitely a good title for a single clean playthrough for its story, but at its price (even on sale) you can probably find many other titles that have similar storytelling impact and gameplay.

This is probably the best game in the Bioshock franchise, it takes place in an entirely new location from the first 2 games, and introduces a ton of new gameplay mechanics  The combat in this game has been heavily enhanced, making it superior to its counterparts in almost every way, including the story  The story in Bioshock Infinite turns away from Bioshock 1 & 2, but manages to keep the same Bioshock feel. You start off in a lighthouse, which is becoming a gimmick for the Bioshock series  The characters are very well developed, and you get to see more of who they really are as the game progresses, you also find out more about their back stories and what lead to them being in the situation that they're in when you take control  The story in this game can be confusing at times, so I highly reccomend you watch a YouTube video explaining the story once you've completed the game, but you can pick up on the important things quite easily  The campaign itself typically lasts 7-8 hours on easy-normal mode, beating the game on one of these modes unlocks 1999 mode, which makes the game much more difficult with the added risk of having to restart the game if you run out of money (you can find out more about 1999 mode online)  This game also has a good range of DLC taking you back to rapture, I've read great reviews about the DLC but unfortunately I haven't been able to play them for myself so I can't give a detailed review  I would highly recommend that anyone try this game, even if you aren't a fan of the series and haven't played any of the Bioshock games in the past, it's an amazing game with an incredible story  I personally rate it 10/10, one of my favorite games

Bioshock Infinite follows its roots in the franchise of making both a compelling story and a new world to explore. As per Bioshock tradition this game comes with an amazing twist that leaves you senseless for a couple minutes after the credits start. The story is well written and they give enough teases to continue playing longer and longer than one had intended. You play as Booker DeWitt, a man sent on a quest to find a girl. At first a bland character, you soon see him become a very caring friend to Elizabeth. Elizabeth is a strong independent and very clever supporting character who you may fall in love with. The Lutece twins who always serve to make a break in the action and make the players think. Lastly, Father Comstock, a tyrannical dictator who seemed to have rewritten history to serve his prophet inspiring goals. Each of these characters are memorable, but the best one in my opinion is Elizabeth because of her growth.  When it comes to the gameplay it follows the Bioshock 2 formula of dual wielding weapons and 'tonics' which does cause a very fluid combat. The biggest weakness is that they only let you carry two weapons, so low ammunition is a larger reality then before. In hindsight this would be a good feature to help in thinking proactively, but some enemies are really bullet spongy which makes the fight a bit too frustrating. In order to level your weapons and tonics, you use money which makes having to pick an choose a problem because you may not always have bullets for those specific ones. No hacking so all turrets are enemies, but it is balanced out with Elizabeth's power to spawn some turrets in certain location, but was still dissappointing. Even though this is a very long escort mission, Elizabeth is anything but useless. Adding the mechanic that Elizabeth will find anything useful and give it over to Booker and at any given time. It is useful with the ammo system and health can be a moment of miracle when your close to dying and she svaes you. Overall the game isn't anything hard and gameplay wise doesn't break any new ground escept for having a competant npc being escorted, but the main point is the storyline and the gameplay does hold water, just a bit frustrating at times.  On a mechanical level this game will be hard to play if your graphics card is 4-5 years old( I actually had this issue). Otherwise this game funs well, but maybe not constant(mine went 90-110 fps on all ultra). The game itself doesn't look too amazing, but it is definitely is a beautiful world to look at just not too close. Never had a fall in framerate or a crash. Has multiple sliders for sound and an abundant amount of graphical options.
