i feel bad because i know people just looooove the bioshock series. and they waited so impatiently for this game to come out and when it did it got met with the highest praise. all the reviews are 10/10 and 9/10 and no one dare say a bad word about it.  but actually it's not all that special.  PROS- the world looks nice in 1080p ultra and the game is probably one of the most stable games i've played on ultra. oddly the only time the frames ever stuttered was away from combat walking in a darkish alley. so it really had no effect on the game. combat was always locked on 60fps.and everyone raves about the world bioshock created and it sure it's nice.  CONS- I know people will destory me for this and give me fanboy thumbs down, but the game just isn't that great.the story takes a minute to pick up, and then when it does the game trys to pad it as much as possible. there's soooo much padding in this game. There's really only maybe 4 or 5 'missions' or 'chapters' in the game. all of which shouldn't have taken very long but they make you backtrack CONSTANTLY!! if you dissagree with me, play the tear part of the game. you fight your way to a gate, oh no you cant get in, go dig up mom, defeat ghost mom, go back to the start of the chapter to find the first tear, defeat mom, find second tear, defeat mom, third tear, back to the gate, defeat mom finally, open gate.that part of the game should've taken 15 minutes, it was like 2 hours!!!! and that was like right in the peak of the story!!!!! speaking of 2 hours, i was convinced the game was over at around the 6 or 7 hour mark. but it just kept making you do one more thing one more thing. it really dragged its feet on the way out. not that the ending was bad persay, but betime i got there i was so jaded by the backtracking.  the biggest con is the legacy issue. the first bioshock came out at a different time in gaming.games were simply made differently. and i could feel bioshock infinite struggle between being linear and non-linear.it's either a non-linear game with a very tight scope, or a linear game with ADD. i just felt like the identity of the game was never something you could put your finger on and it kind of muddyied the waters as i was playing the game.  all in all i give the game a 6.5/10 i would reccomend playing it for the right price and for the $7-8 i payed, the price was totally right. there is some good content in the game, and the world is enjoyable until you're sick of doing circles in it. i just wish the backtracking didn't have me banging my head against a wall. one of the very few games i've ever played that would have gotten a much higher rating if it were 5 hours long.

Bioshock is one of my all-time favorite games, and although Bioshock 2 was not quite up to the same standard (while still being really fun), Bioshock Infinite is in many ways superior to the original.  Like the first Bioshock title, Infinite features an incredibly well written story, which is not something you can say about many FPS games. The main characters are simultaneously heroic and flawed; they are complex people in a way that feels more real than characters typically seen in gaming. The visuals are stunning, creating a world both fantastic yet fully realized and believable. I simple LOVE the soundtrack, made up of brilliant instrumental pieces, punctuated throughout by vintage-style takes on moden classics. As for the much talked about, somewhat infamous, ending? I feel it's perfect for the story being told, and is satisfying in a way that a typical 'and they all lived happily ever after' ending would not have.   Bottom line: If you haven't played Bioshock Infinite yet, you really should. I got it on sale, but would have happily paid full price for it. 5 out of 5.

Wow. Just wow. I played and enjoyed the first two Bioshock games, but always felt they recieved a bit more credit than they deserved. Bioshock Infinite makes the previous games feel like prototypes; this is a true marvel in game design and storytelling.  The combat may not be groundbreaking (you now have a regenerating shield ala Halo), but it's brutal, every weapon and tonic in the game is varied and useful, and for the first time in the series it's just plain fun. That doesn't mean it's now a mindless shooter; the multi-layered, biting, emotional narrative makes just about every other video game plot look like amateur hour. The highlight is Elizabeth, one of the best written and useful companions to ever grace a game; she'll toss you ammo and health in the middle of a fight, open tears to another dimension to turn the odds in your favor, pick locks for you, never needs babysitting, and quips, 'Oh my god!' when you grind your skyhook into some poor sap's face. She's awesome.  I won't get into plot specifics, partially to avoid spoilers (the less you know going in the better), and partially because I couldn't even begin to do it justice without breaking the game down scene by scene and analizing every visual cue and line of dialogue, and I'd probably need a degree in quantum physics. It can be enjoyed and absorbed on a multitude of levels, from a simple father/daughter parable to the dark history of The United States to the folly of Patriotism and Absolutism, and a whole lot beyond and between. I really cannot reccommend this enough; it's so finely crafted and carries so much weight I'd tell anyone who doesn't even like games in general to buckle in and experience something special. It's just so good.  *Quick note about the DLC: long story short it's not that good. I played the arena stuff when it first came out and was nothing special. Burial at Sea is a two part story that ties Columbia and Rapture together, but really it just dilutes and over-complicates what really didn't need explaination. The first part returns to the well of Rapture and it's pretty standard, but ends right when it gets going. The second part has you playing as Elizabeth, which going by the main story should be amazing... but it's not. It's poorly done stealth with no other options, and quite frankly it's boring. Unless you get it in a bundle for dirt cheap, just don't bother. Even then it might not even be worth the time and the bad taste it leaves in your mouth after the mindblowing main game.

DELICIOUS) While at first I sincerely doubted this game since it no longer took place in Rapture, once I gave it a shot it became one of my top 5 favorite games ever. This game is one of the most overrated I ever played. The environments look pretty, but why didn't they make more diverse character models for NPCs?   The 'vigors' feel tacked-on and ho-hum and were shoehorned into the unbelievable plot. There's not really any strategy besides gun 'em down when they come at you. The gunplay, and the guns themselves, are largely as generic as they get.   You can tell they had to cut some stuff--the Songbird feels utterly unnecessary to the final game design.   The story is overrated. It's gee-whiz storytelling that you get from Moffat in Doctor Who. That impresses a lot of people and it IS interesting on its surface BECAUSE OF SHOCK PLOT TWIST, but it's not particularly deep and it's not as clever as people will always say it is. Everyone wants those SHOCK PLOT TWISTS but that can be a sign that the rest of the story is lacking. I believe that is true for certain episodes/seasons of Doctor Who, and it is the case here, too. Breaking Bad didn't rely on this sort of story telling very heavily, and when it did, it wasn't unbelievable.  The story, in typical Bioshock faction, is delivered to you in voice recordings you have to find lying around. You have to snip them together in your head and figure out what people are doing and what their motivations are. None of the characters are particularly deep and this game doesn't really allow for deep character development or anything, but many of them seem rather one-dimensional. This is a feature of how they chose to tell the story. It doesn't damn the game, and the method of telling a story this way certainly has its own upsides, but it personally aggravates me.  This game is just so amazingly overrated. Buy it at $5, and don't buy into the hype, other than the pretty environments the central game design is embematic of the sort of cancer that is infecting modern first person shooters.   However, on a positive note, the developers didn't turn protecting Elizabeth into a giant escort quest, which would have made this game a REAL stinker had they gone through with that. Additionally, the second everything changes (anyone who plays the game knows exactly what that moment is) is pretty shocking. A riveting tale that will grip your heart and suprise you in memorable ways. Usually video game stories are crap, but Bioshock Infinite immerses you in a world filled with detail, intrigue, and suspense. The pacing is well done and there were few noticable lulls in the narrative. The superb writing and voice acting really injects life into the characters and for the first time in a while I felt attatched and invested in the outcome of those in the game. Elizabeth is one of, if not the most, compelling character of recent gaming history and should be an aspiring model for all future story-driven games. While the story may seem convoluted at first, the game's detail rewards those who are patient and take their time to understand Columbia and its inhabitants. Aside from this, observant players will find many interesting bits of social commentary about American society, whether it be exceptionalism, religious fervor, laissez-faire capitalism, communism, racial/cultural purity, etc... that add plenty of depth to an already compelling story.   The atmosphere is exceptional for when this game came out. The deviance of the art and ambiance from a strictly 'realistic' look adds a touch of the fantastical that complements the game's setting and story well. Simply put the game looks ♥♥♥♥ing beautiful.   My only complaint about this wonderful game is the combat mechanics. What makes gameplay enjoyable is rather subjective, but personally I felt that the gunplay was rather clunky, enemy movement seemed unnatural, and with the difficulty turned up fights devolved into repetitive cover shooting. While the game boasts interesting and creative mechanics such as vigors and the skyrail thingy, they weren't sufficient enough to cover for the general lack of smoothness and polish of the fundamental comabt system. The devs probably focused a lot more on art design and story telling than the combat and I can't really blame them. Overall I felt like the fights, apart from the occasional, exciting 'boss', were chores so I could progress in the awesome story. It was ok, I didn't mind too much because I was so into the story but if you value gameplay heavily than it could be potentinally tedious to play this game.   Apart from a potentially minor concern, I certainly recommned this truly unique and thrilling experience.

I would like start off by saying, I'm sorry that I pirated this game in the beginning. I was unappreciative back then. Now on to review.   I found out about this game when I was looking through torrents for games to play while I was over at my grandparents' home because over there, there's no internet. I stumbled across Bioshock Infinite. Now, I would like to state that I've never really heard of this game before. I decided I might get a few hours of this game.   I found myself completely immersed into the world this game presented to me. I felt like I was the main protagonist and blocked out everything around me. Every feeling he felt, I felt. Everything he said, I muttered. Everything he did, I followed. I finished the game, and wasn't pleased with it. So, I decided to buy it.   The story was amazing. It worked perfectly with the atmosphere. The characters was a huge asset in the story, each with their own unique characteristics and how their personality complimented each other. The gameplay is alittle bit iffy at some points, but overall it's great. The enemies are also different from each other, meaning you have to strategically defeat them. Some are your normal 'I'm gonna shot you in the face' and some are 'To defeat me, you're gonna have to do vigor combos and plant crits on me'.    Graphics are just.... just MAGNIFIQUE! The amount of detail that goes to everything is just breath-taking. EVEN TRASH LOOKS NICE. The characters fit in every cutscene and basically, everywhere you go. Nothing seems out of place, not even the things that ARE out of place. Lighting is just right, not too much, not too little. I'm no artist, but this game is just a beauty to look at. It's like heaven on earth. (Yes, that's a game referrence)   This game towers absolutely EVERYTHING when it comes to voice-acting. Are they voice-acting or were they just secretly voice-taped during their daily life? Because, I've never heard so much emotion. Trust me, you will never go 'That doesn't right. He's frustrated but why is he talking like he's laughing?'. I would like to personally see each individual voice actor and give them gifts, just to congratulate them.   DLCs are abit lacking but for what it's worth, I'd recommend you getting them, every single one. Burial At Sea explains the aftermatch of the game and will give you abit of nostalgia if you've ever played Bioshock 1 and/or 2.   Overall, amazing game. It is my favourite game of all time, that is, until another one takes it place, but that'll be awhile. The only thing I would like to complain about it, is the eyes. Some cutscenes make Elizabeth's eyes so wide, like they're gonna pop-out. I definitely recommened buying this game.  (You may experience what I call 'Bio-depression' after you finish the game. Totally normal, don't fear. Just... wait it out.) _______________________________________________________________  For the TL;DR people,  Great game. Buy it.

BioShock Infinite is the third game in the BioShock franchise, and it takes a turn. An amazing turn.  Gameplay: The overall gameplay of BioShock: Infinite is very well polished, however the rare NPC and AI glitches can bring you out of the experience. These include: Estatic AI and random body mesh errors, However these can be overlooked as they are rare. The story telling of this game uses way to much emphasis and should not need to be repeated, additionally some key features that make BioShock Infinite seem like its counterparts have been removed. Such as multiple gun carrying and famous enemy types, However all in all this game has a very well polished gameplay value that also contains some replay additive.  Story: It takes players from the beloved city of Rapture, the underwater paradise we BioShock fans know and adore... ...and puts us in another amazing city, the floating city of Columbia. You play as Booker DeWitt, a man who is lost in gambling consequences. (don't gamble kids) You have a simple objective. Bring them the girl and wipe away the debt. Sounds simple? You are very mistaken.  Visuals: BioShock infinite has a different graphics style to the first two, I'm not sure whether its due to graphics technology evolving or they just wanted to try something new. If it was to try something new, they did it right. Everything has a comic-book-like style to it, like if you took the graphics from borederlands and took away most of the thick black lines. (Which is forgivable, they are both by 2K)  Pros: -Amazing and rich storyline -Fast-paced gameplay with many features to give you the advantage on the battlefield -Great character Development -Easter Eggs eg. Hidden music, References to the previous BioShock games, etc. -A wide selection of weapons and vigors -Great and helpful AI (Thanks, Elizabeth)  Cons: -Sometimes gets repetitive -NPCs can bug out and jump around -You can only carry two weapons at a time, so it removes that classic BioShock feeling of conservation of ammo and keeping stocked -Removes some great features of the original BioShock games  Verdict: This, overall is a FREAKING AMAZING game. 9/10 for BioShock Infinite  -credit to DarkBetray for assistance

Never was a fan of story driven games, but this one is definitely an exception to the rule. Logistically, the balancing of story and gameplay is amazing. The pacing is excellent -- gameplay flows into and serves the story. The game has a complete story without feeling dragged out.  The story itself is captivating and keeps you engaged the entire time. I always wanted to know what would happen next. The events that happen in the game are meaningful and contribute to the overall narrative. Your companion, Elizabeth, is a character that definitely grows on you as the game progresses. While the details of the story may be complex and sometimes hard to get, it is ultimately fulfilling once you grasp it.  However, the DETAILED setting of this alternate-early-20th-century-steam-punk-sci-fi-fantasy game is what sets this game apart. Enter a world in which political, economic, social, and religious satire is rolled into one imaginative world. Everything from the dialogue between NPCs to the propaganda on the walls-- to the statues and architecture, gives the player a deep sense of immersion. The game is bold enough to delve into sensitive social questions. If you are interested in this kind of alternative setting, then this game is a must have.   Just a couple of notes:  -The gameplay is linear, as it is a story-driven game. However there are different side areas to go into, and things to see and collect. -There is no save button, but each chapter is saved and there are checkpoints.  -Check out the Burial at Sea DLCs. It continues the story of Elizabeth after the events of this game. (Highly recommended that you play Bioshock 1 first, as the story is connected to both games.) If you liked Bioshock 1 and Bioshock Infinite, the BaS DLCs are a must buy.    Get this game/10

This game... oooooh this game. I cannot express with words how I feel towards this game. This game is the best example of video games as an art form, and I could not pick a better contender if I tried. I could have said any of the Galactic Cafe games, or a Souls game, but this game has lots of engaging gameplay unlike walking simulators. This game has more of a storyt than just tatters of a story strung together by vague dialogue and item descriptions like Dark Souls. This game... it's in a league of it's own. It's in a league occupied solely by Bioshock Infinte.  Bioshock Infinite, like its predecessors, is a FPS developed by Irrational Games. It is about a distopian theocracy where the main character is sent to retrieve a young girl by the name of Elizabeth. A lot of unimportant stuff happens, you get targeted by the police force, everyone's attacking you for a while, yadda, yadda. And then you actually meet the other half of the focal point of this game: Elizabath. I'm going to skip the rest of the plot beacause you really, REALLY need to experience the rest of the plot for yourself. All I can tell you is that the story alone is worth the price of admission. Every character has motivations, goals, personalities, social ties, morals, philosophies, purpose. The characters are amazingly fleshed out to the point of feeling real. And trust me, you'll soon wish they were.  The graphics and music in this game are absolutely marvellous. I (finally) finished the original Bioshock recently, and noticed that, compared to Infinte, which I had played before, Bioshock had a very drab and uninteresting enviroment. With pile of rubble here or there, smeared blood every five feet, whether it be on the walls, floor, ceiling, glass, table, Steve from accounting, you name it. The colors are very dark and often blend together. Both games look stylized, but the difference was that the palettes of Infinte are much brighter, and (most) areas are in sunlight and not ruined. While I still really liked Bioshock above many other games I've played, the enviroment's coloring dragged its quality down for me a lot. But this isn't a review of Bioshock, now is it? The music compliments the enviroments beautifly, and while they reuse certain 'battle music' all the time during gameply, you will probably regard it more as an enemy signal than background music.  And now, for the gameplay. Frankly, I think this is the weakest part of the game. It's still a solid part of the game, but it gets overshadowed by a mile by its other components. I think this is the part of the game that I liked the original Bioshock for better. You can only hold two weapons at a time, and my god are there weapons. I think there are something like 15 or 16 weapons in this game, and you can only carry two. Sure, it makes more sense, but in the original Bioshock (I swear, I'll stop referencing Bioshock now) you carried a wrench, a pistol, a tommy gun, a shotgun, a grenade luancher, a camera, a flame/liquid nitrogen/electric-ooze-stuffthrower, a crossbow, AND THE AMMO FOR ALL OF THAT. I just find it wierd that they limit you to two when you have the oppurtunity to add WAY more guns to the players arsenal. The enemy AI is usually ok, leaning on the side of stupid rather than advanced. That said, even on normal, they can seriously pack a punch. This game isn't frustrating, but it is certainly hard. I'm a veteran gamer through and through, but even I died a good amount in this game. There are definetly parts that I might not have been able to get through without exploiting a few vigors and guns. Oh yeah, plasmids are still a thing, only they're called vigors now. I thought some of them are cool, but a majority of them feel useless. Also, Elizabeth helps you during battle. She isn't a liabilty, because she always seem to find cover and doesn't thow herself into enemy fire like some 'companions' in other games. She throws you ammo, health, and salts (EVE). Like I said, gameplay's the weakest link of a adamantium chain.  10/10 Absolutely my favorite game to date. The story is gripping, the characters feel real, and the ending will blow your mind. The enviroments are beautiful and vibrant, the music is fantastic and compliments the enviroments and story events. The gameplay is plentiful, engaging and challenging. This game certainly has flaws, but you probably won't notice as you are experiencing the game. Notice how I didn't say 'play'.   I know this review will be lost under the pile of words, pictures and sounds that is the internet, but all I can ask for is that this game isn't.

Minor Spoilers: Gameplay: To start, simply moving your character is very smooth and easy. For example in The Elder Scrolls V: Skyrim(great game) moving my character had lag. I didn't have any of this in BioShock Infinite. The weapons were all unique and different, but the real fun is in the salts. I don't know of many games that allow you to shoot vicious crows out of your hands to devour your enemies. A somewhat disappointing aspect to the gameplay is the inability to go back to previous places like in the original, although it would have probably felt out of place to go backwards. More minor disappointments include the removal of ammo types, and the inability to carry more than two guns at once, however, one could easily argue that these changes are necessary in this particular game. Like previous BioShock titles, I had a lot of fun searching for hidden items that either help my character or provide elaborate details to the plot and the city. Overall, the gameplay was great.  Story: This game tells a complex, immersive, deep, and meaningful tale about politics, racism, and religion; family, companionship, and abuse; and perhaps most importantly, choices, consequences, and redemption. It contains some of the most real, lifelike characters I have ever seen in a video game, and when the game was over, I didn't know what to do with myself (well, that's not true; I simply started the game again). The fact that you get a first-person perspective on this story makes it all the more awe-inspiring.   Graphics: BioShock Infinite has some of the best graphics I have seen to date. With that being said, it's not just the quality of the graphics that makes this game so visually appealing. The whole immersive environment is full of bright colors with dark undertones. Even though this game takes place in a completely different environment than the original BioShock, I can definitely tell that it is part of the same series. The developers really went above and beyond when connecting the game's setting to the actual graphics. For example, a city in the sky would see much more clouds than a city down to Earth, right? Well when certain events that call for suspense appear in gameplay, it might be accompanied by an ominous fog. At other times, the sun might be out, and it's as bright as a western. You can tell that genuine artists worked on this game.   Sound: While there are so many aspects that go into the sound of a video game, perhaps the most noticeable was the voice acting. These actors poured their hearts out into their roles. Without getting into detail and spoiling it for everyone, there are parts in the game where I can tell the voice actor/actress is actually crying while recording his/her voice. There is something about the way these actors tackle their role that makes their characters seem so hauntingly real. A less noticeable aspect (but just as important) is the music. The soundtrack for this game sounds like a professional movie soundtrack. The music is a perfect accompaniment to the characters and events that it compliments. Seriously, I don't know how this game manages to do so well in EVERY ASPECT. Just as a side note, the Songbird sounds terrifying and awesome.  Play Time/Replayability: It took me about 16 hours to beat this game on my first run through, which some say is too short. However, adding more play time to the game would dilute it as a whole. It does have a great deal of replayability, such as 1999 mode for the hardcore gamer (not horribly difficult). Overall, I didn't mind that the game was a bit shorter than average, because I was so satisfied with what I got.   Artistic Direction: This is where the game REALLY shines the brightest. Everything about this game contributes to its status as a work of art. All throughout the game there are characters, posters, or even structures, artfully placed to show the dark and sometimes racist intentions of the people of Columbia, trying to create a utopia. BioShock Infinite picks its themes and sticks to them. Perhaps the most memorable aspect of this game is the recurring hymn, 'Will the Circle Be Unbroken'. This song has a subtle presence at important moments all throughout, whether it is sung, hummed, or even fit into the game's music. This hymn perfectly relates to the plot and characters of BioShock Infinite.   Final Comments: This is the best game I have played in a long time. This game shows everyone else in the video game industry the right way to make a sequel. The bottom line is that a great deal of thought and care went into making this breathtaking masterpiece, and it shows.

After a few years and well over 150 hours played, it might seem redundant to write a review, but what the heck. I love BioShock Infinite, but I'm also frustrated by it. This game could have been genre-defining, it could have been a revolution. Unfortunately all the best intentions and biggest budget in the world couldn't achieve the lofty goals they set.   The thematic elements are genius, how they turned their limitation of linearity into a beautiful story and theme of its own, but at what cost? As much as I still enjoy re-playing the game, the gorgeous art and top draw acting can't disguise that the underlying systems don't mesh with what they're trying to do- the mass murder just doesn't feel appropriate to this setting (these are regular cops and downtrodden folk coming at you, not jabbering zombies or mutated monstrosities) and Infinite's gunplay is lackluster compared to even other entries in its own series. Which means some parts are a bit of a slog to get through, and you often have to mentally divorce the moment to moment gameplay from the overarching story.  Like the original games, the floating city of Columbia is the real star of BioShock Infinite, and it's a wonderful place to visit in all its multi-dimensional incarnations, looting every container in sight and picking up audio diaries as you go. While there are indeed moments of quiet, like exploring a sunny beach or roaming the amusements arcade, most of the time you're fighting your way through the place.   That wouldn't be so bad if the fighting wasn't so dull, with encounters being quite frequent and always playing out similarly without much in the way of enemy variety and no ability to plan before battles. I mean, you CAN lay down traps with Vigours, but this uses up too much juice to be very practical for much of the game. All enemies are openly hostile, there's no middle ground like with Big Daddies, stealth is useless and you can't carry around extra weapons or resources like health packs. This leads to frantically scrounging through trash cans and corpses in the heat of battle to find health items a lot of the time. Eventually you acquire enough Vigour powers and gear upgrades that the fighting starts to become interesting, but at that point you're nearing the end of the game. Still, it's all pulled off with a fair bit of pizazz using some seriously cool effects (flaming electrified crows!) and a wonderfully reactive soundtrack that plays little stingers when you get headshots and the like.   Your main goal of course is to rescue Elizabeth from the city, and she is an eminently likeable and believable character that shows real emotion (in cutscenes). Out of cutscenes, Elizabeth is completely ignored by EVERYTHING, even though she's what they're after (okay, with one exception, when she's abducted OFF SCREEN). She rarely feels like a real person outside of very specific interactions during actual gameplay, reverting to a glass-eyed automaton for a lot of the time with none of the dynamism or responsiveness shown pre-release, falling well short of expectations set in the same category by Naughty Dog or Valve. Her story's great, her design is mostly great, the voice acting's great (if a bit breathy), but she's just not very well realized in the actual GAME part of the game. In combat, the mechanic of her randomly throwing you supplies is also pretty awkward. After 100+ hours I can kinda predict when it's likely to happen, but there's definitely some randomness as to when she'll bother to toss you that vital vial.   Maybe I love Infinite more for the dream of what it could have been, than the actual thing they delivered, I don't know. I think back to the original vision demo that Irrational produced, which promised untold freedom of combat and reactivity from the environment, plus a potentially much more interesting Elizabeth whose powers had more variety but were also hazardous to her health. The reality falls a bit short. It's still a very fun theme park ride of a game, held together with some top notch storytelling, but the environment is very nailed down and smaller scale than one would expect and you kinda have to grit your teeth through certain sections.   Although I feel we saw barely half of their original intentions come to fruition, what we got to play through is still awe inspiring, moving and thought provoking. For comparison's sake, if Mass Effect 3 failed due to being rushed out and designed by committe, Infinite is the polar opposite, where years of complete freedom led to a mess of gameplay elements that never quite gel or reach their full potential but still make for a compelling, if flawed, experience.   They failed trying to do the impossible and I find that admirable. Definitely recommended.

Hello boys and girls, step right up and experience Bioshock Infinite - The one and only video game to feature graphics that appear more stunning than the graphics in real life! That's right graphics-obsessed mainstream gamer crowd, get your salivary glands as hyped up as the fanboys of this here game, because you're in for the ride of your lives through the first literal shooter on rails!  Yes, you heard me right - this game is the first shooter on rails to actually involve shooting while on rails! As you glide gracefully through the air without ever fearing for your life, you will find yourself pitted against fellow rail-riders that will also be firing at you as you fire at them. But don't worry! This game is more than ready to account for your lack of an attention span, and will gladly reduce the odds of you getting shot while riding on these rails to next to zero!  Be prepared to be awed by this game's incredible involvement of the theory of relativity, which will leave you, like many fanboys, baffled and confused with its remarkable ending that completely forgets the grandfather paradox! But don't question the lack of thought put into its use of time and space, nor how people can live in a floating city like this without passing out from low oxygen! None of this should matter when you're rapidly firing a rocket launcher, and being hit in the head with a wrench by a girl you just saved!  But graphics aren't all this game features, it also boasts amazing features never seen before in video game history! Features, such as; Racism, skyhook assassinations, firefights on rails (as mentioned before, but it's worth repeating!), classical music, crazy religious people, and most of all: Elizabeth's magical ability to pull weapons and money from thin air!  Mainstream shooter fans rejoice! This game, unlike the others in the franchise, realizes that you're too simple-minded to possibly keep up with multiple weapons, and so it limits you to only two at once! Don't worry about figuring out which two weapons you like - they've gone out of their way to make sure that only a small portion of the handful of weapons available are actually useful in the game, so you'll be just fine!  So throw your science book out the window, forget Einstein existed, and prepare to enter the floating city of Columbia through the eyes of Booker Dewitt, he's just your average ex-military gun-wielding father who is able to immediately go from retrieving a girl for a 100% legit client, to taking on an entire army of soldiers! Become immersed in his epic tale, as he rescues a Paris-obsessed girl named Elizabeth, who shows absolutely no respect for our clearly trustworthy protagonist, and will not think twice about running away, or otherwise physically harming him, despite the fact that he is the only reason she ever escaped at all!  So join the hype train, and buy Bioshock Infinite - your eyes will not regret it, but your mind might!

I'm a gigantic Bioshock fan. I loved the beautiful game world, amazing atmosphere and wonderful storytelling from Ken Levine and Co. After playing Bioshock Infinite and both Burial At Sea DLCs I can tell you (not that you didn't know this already) that this game easily meets those standards you've come to expect from them. Taking the gameplay from the underwater city of Rapture to the skies and it's own city, Columbia, where you play as a private detective sent to rescue a girl being held there. I won't go into anymore details as the journey is one worth taking and finding out for yourself. The city of Columbia, much like Rapture is beautifully designed and fleshed out. The combat is visceral and fun, with the use of 'vigors' rather than 'plasmids' (same concept, different powers) from earlier entries in the series. The variety of weapons is excellent and the upgrades make a difference. Later in the game you'll be able to move around on sky hooks and attack enemies by pouncing on them or shooting them while moving. Very roller coastery and pretty satisfying. The characters are well written and the voice acting is absolutely top shelf. Elizabeth is one of the better characters in video game history IMO. The end is a little odd and wasn't so black and white but I was satisfied with it. Overall I'd highly recommend Bioshock Infinite. It's worth the full price and the sales on it make it a steal. 9.5/10 from me.

+ Powerful story, narration, characters and voice acting + Great settings, environments and visuals + Lots of details and polish, items are thoughtfully placed around and every bit of level design made sense to me  Gameplay-wise a rather brainless shooter. Not exactly a Call of Duty, I guess, but not very far from it either. I was playing on the 'Hard' difficulty'. Lots of guns and powers to use, but I found my favorites somewhere in the middle and never touched the others again. Sometimes you can interact with the environment for example to set an oil puddle ablaze while enemies walk through, but these occassions are rather rare, and timing isn't always easy. It seemed simplier and easier to me to just fire my guns at them right away. The enemy AI felt rather bad. I could be crouching behind a small pillar or crate to wait for my shield to regenerate and sometimes none of the enemies would try to flank me. If they tried they weren't doing it aggressively enough but stumbling around before shooting leaving me enough time to take them out. There was a 'boss' who was harder to defeat because he would constantly spawn minions, and those Handymen kept pushing me around because they are are glued to your tail and hit hard in melee. There is no serious death penalty or sense in struggling harder though.  The skylines are either not always there or I haven't always noticed, so they not necessarily make up for the somewhat lacking combat. Freight hooks you will sometimes find too. But again: Why jump up there, possibly expose myself to enemy fire, to charge at them with my skyhook and dropping into the middle of some semi-open spaces - possibly exposing myself again -, if I can just take a small peek from around a small corner and do a headshot with a sniper rifle from a safe distance instead? I used the skylines to zip around if Handymen were closely behind me, and in some instances because it felt a bit epic doing that with gunboats around to drop on and harrassing their crew close up, but those moments were few and change little about the rail-ish nature of the gameplay.  I've seen the press apparently praising the AI and companion nature of Elizabeth. She is a great companion story-/narration-wise and I liked her a lot, she is nicely animated, her voice actress did a great job and she has an interesting personality (she is neither some stupid damsel in distress nor some oversexualized ♥♥♥♥♥ for men to stare at), but in terms of gameplay she is overrated. Some wrote she would greatly take care of herself. Actually no, she does not. It's just that the enemies pay zero attention to her. Story-wise capturing her should have priority for the enemies over killing me, the player, and yet there were a few instances in which she exposed herself to the enemies in silly ways. There is no real stealthing, but sometimes enemies aren't initially aware of your presence, and one time I was sneaking up on a few of them. They didn't notice me, but Elizabeth 'decided' to run up ahead in plain sight. Nothing happened. She just drolled back to me like these enemies weren't even there. If you don't pay attention to such things you may believe she was controlled by some smart AI, but I did notice and it's just not as fancy as some people put it.  Also, the degree to which she interacts with you is fairly limited. Yes, she throws supplies at you when you need them. But it's just a 'Hit button X' prompt. Yes, you can make her open 'tears' to spawn supplies, cover, freight hooks, decoys, environmental hazards and whatnot during combat. But it rarely matters much. And again: It's just you holding down a button when prompted. And Elizabeth can open locks, but again it's a mere prompt to make her do something that takes like a second. There is no real added gameplay value by her doing it. Booker could have done that himself. It's nice to have her do it instead, it sure doesn't hurt the companion idea, but I doubt it to be the massive edge and innovation in gameplay design as some reviewers or press representitives apparently believe it to be.

It's not bad, but it is somewhat dissapointing.  Now, I know I did say I recomend this game, because it's a fun game with a great story, but it doesn't live up to what it could be. If there was an 'indifferent' option rather than just yes or no, I would have picked that. While I chose yes because this game isn't bad enough to deserve a no, I was dissapointed in the potential it had and didn't quite deliver on, and I'll explain why.  Bioshock Infinite tries to do a lot of things differently than in Bioshock. Is this a problem? No. The problem is actually that it didn't change enough. Bioshock was a completely immersive and consice expeirience. Everything about it - the story, the setting, the gameplay and machanics - worked together to created a single, tightly woven experience. Infinite stumbles a bit in that respect. It focuses a lot more on the story - which is fine, because the story is FANTASTIC - but the pacing doesn't change much from Bioshock to accompy that. The story is, at times, seemingly pointlessly interupted for battle sequences that are not well-justified by the story or setting. Not every battle feels out of place, and a lot of the battles are great, but just as many seemed added in just for the sake of having more action. Bioshock had insane splicers around every corner, so Infinite should too, right? But in the new setting, it doesn't feel as natural, and doesn't add to the expeirnece as much. On the subject of action, this game introduces vigors, which are basically this game's version of plasmids. Strange viles of liquid that give you weird powers. These were a central part the story and world of Bioshock, but really have no place in Infinate and feel as if they're only there because Bioshock had them. Also, looting in Bioshock made sense - the place is falling apart and you need to salvage to survive. This doesn't translate to the new, more utopian setting.  In the end, my biggest (and maybe only) complaint with this game is simply that they tried to do too many new things, but then tried to keep too many old things as well just to be safe. It ends up feeling halfway done, with the story and world changing a lot but the machanics and gameplay unwilling to change to match. It's saddening, really. If they had been willing to change all of it to match the new setting, it would have been amazing. Instead, it's okay.  Now, before you go thinking that I hate this game, it is not bad - just not as good as it could have been. The combat is fine, although rarely adds much, but the story and world are both stellar. Ininfite has a bigger focus on characters than Bioshock did, and thus a bigger focus on story rather than just atmosphere, and the story is really, really good. The setting, while it does seem at conflict with the machanics at times, is beautiful. It's fun to explore and learn about, just like you'd expect from Bioshock, with a different take on the distopian world gone wrong feel, as you arrive while the utopia is still thriving. The world and story does not dissapoint. It's fresh and new, but still has that Boishock charm of wonder mixed with unease.  In the end, I only dislike this game because I wanted to like it more than I could. In the words of a passive-aggressive mother, 'I'm not mad, just dissapointed.'

This review is going to be in two parts mechanics and story, and i will rate them both out of 10.  Mechanics: the gameplay in Bioshock Infinite is rather simple but fast paced and interesting. you make use of guns, your skyhook and vigours which are basically the plasmids from the first two games. most of the action is just shoot, zap, smash repeat with the exception of when you use the skyrails to fly arround the battlezone. the combat varies slightly based on what weapons you get your hands on, for instance the shotgun is a medium damaging close range weapon, while the machine gun does light damage from a distance, while if you get your hands on the rail gun you will wreck untill you run out of ammo. overall the combat is a 7/10 because its fun and fast paced but lacks variety.  Story: You play as a man name Booker Dewitt who is sent to the flying city of Columbia to save a young woman named Elizabeth ( she's kinda a big deal in the game ) who has been trapped in collumbia since she was young. the story contains many jaw droping plot twists and keeps you engaged untill the credits roll. the story rates a 100000/10 for being one of the greatest stories ever in video game history.   So should you buy this game, Hell yeah its freakin awesome and will keep you engaded untill the end. Warning you will fal in love with Elizibeth.

Bioshock as a series is a first person horror(ish) single player shooter. It has an amazing story in every game and the gunplay feels incredible, especially when being mixed with the large variety of supernatural 'powers' (called Plasmids in 1 + 2, called Vigor in Infinite) There's a slight trace of survival in the games, as you're always looking for ammo and looting every little crevice for some health packs and maybe some salt (basically mana).  Bioshock Infinite really was a huge step-up from the previous games. The story was way more driven out and detailed, the movement system changed, along with the gunplay, the graphics, and even the setting. I honestly don't even want to say what these are and describe the world, because it's an amazing experience if you just jump in with no knowledge other than 'first person shooter' and 'good story'.  To this day, 3 years after the release of the game, I can positively say that Bioshock Infinite is one of the best story-driven FPS ever.

We all make choices, but not in bioshock infinite!  All I can say about this game is it is not a bioshock game. It is, a monstrosity created by Ken Levine, that was branded 'bioshock'. During it's development, the game and it's story were changed around multiple times, leading to this mediocre, non bioshock game.  I only recently played through the series, and had high hopes for infinite as the other games were amazing. My friends who had played through it said it was the worst, and i didn't believe them. But, they were right  The Good: It isn't all bad, the game has wonderful graphics which allow the new scenery in this game to be absoloutley stunning. Along with the graphics, a few neat mechanics were introduced such as new plasmids (known as vigors), the skyline system which allows you to slide on a rail (this was very well done), and the clothing system. Theres also the edition of a free roam in the city feature, where you just look at stuff before your an idiot and show you mark of the devil to someone. These areas are some of the best in the game, but are very limited in number    Sadly the good parts are limited  The Bad: Ken levine said himself that he asked your regular xbox dudebros to play through bioshock and he then asked them what could be improved. This is the result.  Core bioshock mechanics: Unlike the other games in the series, there are no little sisters or big daddies. I (and many other people who enjoy the series) were expecting some sort of 'columbia-fied' version of these things, instead they were simply removed. No little sisters, no adam, and no big daddies. You can't upgrade your personal stats such as health, armor, or salts (eve), with anything other than random hidden bottles, any special abilities are unlocked by clothing rather than adam, and out of TEN plasmids EIGHT are handed to you. This may not sound like an issue, but IT IS A BIOSHOCK GAME. Theres also the small issue that half of the plasmids are useless or are exactly the same.  Next we have weapons and weapon mechanics. The weapons in this game are terrible. In other bioshock games, the weapons are vastly different. But not in infrinite! Yes, these weapons are all different, but they all feel the same. There are quite a few weapons as well, but the pistol and the rifle feel the same, the shotgun and revolver feel the same, THEY ARE BORING AND BLAND. In the first two games, you'd have things ranging from a tommy gun to a crossbow. Oh yeah, thats another thing; the weapons don't fit the time period! Every weapon in this game exists 30 years before it was created in real life, this wouldn't be an issue but they are all real weapons! Anyway, in this game you have generic weapons that aren't special in any way whatsoever.   The mechanics are also awful. Ammo is VERY easy to get even on hard mode, and enemies LITERALLY WALK INTO HEADSHOTS. This makes the gun play boring, and also repetitive.   Upgrades are even worse, unlike the other game where there somewhat of a visual difference and usually soem cool gimmick after fully upgrading it, these upgrades are just flat out stat boosts.  Oh, i almost forgot! You are limited to carrying TWO weapons. That's right, two! This mechanic was a futile attempt at making sections harder by making you pick up the appropriate weapon type (make the upgrade system worse), but it doesn't actually matter, as headshots are so easy to get, so a pistol and carbine can get you through the entire game.  Also, forget about set enemies, just fights waves of them off!  Next enemies and ai: The enemies in this game are as bad (if not worse) than the guns. Throughout the entire game you fight the same enemies. Police, tankier police, and mini bosses. These minibosses are what i assume to be the stand ins for big daddies. You have patriots (robots with miniguns), firemen (tanky guys that shoot fire), crow people (i dunno), and handymen (tanky berzerkers). But these just don't work. They are basically thrown out in every few fights, but barely make a difference as they only take 10 or so extra shots to kill. They also have no reason to exist, unlike big daddies. THe only time enemies change is when (spoiler) the rebels turn on you, but all this does is give the existing enemies are nice red paint job.  CHOICES: The bioshock series has always had one core element: CHOICES.You could either be the man that kept his sanity within rapture, or you could become what you were against. Would you do anything to get to your daughter and set a bad example, or be a good rolemodel? In this game there are no choices other than some random attempt at sybolism with the twins. Heres an example: Only 20 minutes into the game, there is a choice. You can either go along with the racism and throw a ball at a mixed race couple, or throw it at the announcer. WAIT NEVER MIND YOU THROW IT AT THE ANNOUNCER NO MATTER WHAT.   Other stuff that doesn't deserve its own section: Hacking=gone. It was replaced with a plasmid thats ultimately useless, as the machines you hack turn on you after a while anyway. The hacking mini games were always a little clunky, but they were just apart of the series. Open worldishness=gone. bioshock was never really that much of an open world game, i mean more free roam. In the first two games, you could roam around an area and do whatever you want. See a big daddy? Put some traps down before you fight it, hack the security, make it your own arena. This game dows have some of that, but because these areas are filled with innocent people that scream if you cough, it just doesn't work.  THE STORY (SPOILERS, obviously):  (lot less spoilers after this section) I'm going to sum up the story really quickly. You play as booker d*uche witt, a guy who owes a debt and needs to find a girl so he can pay it off. She happens to be the daughter of a prophet that is the leader of a giant floating city that broke away from the u.s. because of political differences. Everyone here happens to be racist since its 1912. After breaking thi girl out, you find a way to escape the town, and fool the girl into thinking you're taking her to paris. She ends up finding out about your plan but decides that the both of you two should just team up to get out of dodge. Then portals and deepness and 'look how philisophical it is guys' WAIT A MINUTE SHES actually YOUR DAUGHTER YOU JUST FORGOT BECAUSE REASONS AND PORTALS AIGHT? Then she kills you.   Main Issues with the story:  Racism: At the start of the game you are shown a beautiful, vibrant city. It looks like paradise and it is. WAIT! they ship all the black people to finks place, fink offers them work and they live under ♥♥♥♥♥♥ conditions, because its better than getting lynched, and even though you could just leave at anytime the black and irish population (which from the perpective the game put you though is about half the population) live in slums. Then when they rebel and stop living in slums the paradise turns to ♥♥♥♥.   The racism part also carries no weight because the only reason you help them is because they take your ship.  'so deep man' Everyone says the story is deep and philisophical. But it isn't, at all. It just ends with your genericy alternate universes concept which isn't anything knew, and is done in a stupid way. There is also just a bunch of random garbage spouted about physics and atoms and time threories, but to anyone whos watched an episode of those black hole shows on the science channel will know it is bs.   Conclusion:  Is this game a bad game? No. It is very well done. But in the end, it isn't a bioshock game. It's just a cahsout targeted at dudebros and gamergurls that has bioshock in the name and some bioshock mechanics.

During your adventure, various weapons and powers (vigors) will be available to you. Weapon variability is decent, though not staggering. I got the impression that in the end it matters very little what weapons you use (you can only carry two at a time) because they can all become quite powerful through upgrades. I'm not saying a rocket launcher is the same as a sniper rifle, of course. This can be both good and bad. Good because you can choose weapons based on your playstyle (for example machine gun X rifle) and if the two weapons compliment each other well you won't have to change your mind later. Bad because you probably won't have enough money to upgrade more weapons if you do change your mind. But that's a minor thing that you can certainly plan for. The vigor powers are, well, OK. I ended up using only two or three of the supporting ones. For attacking you're mostly fine using weapons. The final thing I'd like to mention is the story. Even though it's not very original and doesn't actually make sense :), it's presented is such a way that I didn't really care and thoroughly enjoyed it. Overall great game, highly recommended.

An ambitious game that checks a lot of boxes. Some better than others. This is a 'spiritual' successor of the first BioShock. The setup, gameplay, and story is very reminiscent of the first yet manages to be its own unique entity. Even though I enjoyed playing this game more than the previous BioShock, the first one is a more complete game and story.  What's amazing about the first BioShock is how it tells the story in everything it does -- gameplay, enemies, NPCs, environments, etc. The level of detail is amazing. Infinite is similar in scope and scale yet there are many things that go unexplained. The simple explanation of your powers is not covered at all. And why don't any of your enemies have the same powers? There are a lot of glaring omissions like these throughout the game, yet it's only because the game tries to tackle so many things that most games, movies, and even books don't even come close to.  While with its own faults I found the world of BioShock Infinite a world I constantly wanted to return to. The first Bioshock is completely terrifying. I remember playing the first one for 15 minutes and not picking it back up months afterwards because it was so terrifying. Infinite, while sinister, is much more colorful and ideallyic. Your side character does a lot to carry the burden. She's remeniscent of Disney's Belle from Beauty and the Beast. It's an amazing attempt at creating a side character that doesn't get in the way and is also likeable from start to finish. The failings of the side character feel more like the the constraints of the technology and less so than the constrainst of the creatives. Overall it works.  At its best, gun fights are a blast. You'll swing from skylines, have brutal melee kills, and the powers your acquire are more lethal than ever. About half way through the game it becomes a little monotonous and easy the more powers you acquire. While still fun, it never transcends is core mechanic. The environments and set pieces get really creative and exciting. But it feels like the creatives behind Inifinite are tired of this same old shoot 'em as well and are more interested in fleshing out the rest of the world. The burdnes of creating a AAA title.  The most interesting parts are when you're walking through a town and seeing the citizens go about their daily business. 'Social norms' are turned on its head; pulling and blending from historical past and fictional altered futures. The expansion of the world is also executed through many collectible audio-tapes and viewable old timey movie machines. While creative and well-done in their own right, I don't feel like these break up the overall flow of the game. They become more annoying that enriching. That being said I'm glad they're in the game, I just wish there were more scenes that you play through, rather than 'recordings'.  The ending, that I won't spoil, is terrific. It really does save the game from being a rehash of the first. It easily goes down as one of the all time best endings of a game. The ending is enough to replay the game to see it with new eyes.  BioShock Inifinite is a great game that feels shackeled by the confines of AAA pressures and constraints. If only those shackles were released would we be getting a game that defies expectations. I'm glad Ken Levine and company have moved on to new pastures as their newest work is bound to be ahead of them.

A worthy addition to the BioShock franchise; however fails to innovate as gameplay remains relatively mundane.  Strengths:  Bioshock Infinite creates a rich atmosphere and engaging environment, made complete through enjoyable protagonists. Progressing through the game provides a variety of engaging settings and areas in which you're able to learn the history and creation of Columbia. Slavery and religious undertones play a key role in creating interesting world as the player is constantly bombarded with conflicting viewpoints. Also enjoyable was the mixing of United States history in sort of an 'alternate reality'   Weaknesses:  Gameplay. The game does little to further the franchises key mechanics. Plasmids are simply replaced by tonics, most of which are not very exciting.  Upgrades and 'character progression' remain the same and are very bland overall. Typical increased ammo, increased damage, reduced recoil, faster reloads are all included for most guns, but do not present any improvement from prior games. Some upgrades to plasmids... I mean tonics, are fun, and can change gameplay somewhat, but most are fairly typical.  The new addition of 'Gear' in which you equip pieces of that have a variety of effects on your character were a nice addition, however I felt they fell flat. Again, most of the bonuses were fairly typical. Aerial combat was also a new addition, which was ok. I felt like it was supposed to be a main focal point of combat, but in the end, was mainly just used to escape and dodge attacks as your shields recharged.  The 'warping in' of different items to assist you in combat was also just ok. There was no ramifications of choosing to warp in one item over another. You can warp in health packs to heal up, then go back to warping in a aerial turret to assist you, then warp in a hook to provide mobility. Would have liked to see some ramifications involved from choosing to warp in a certain item.... i.e. you warp in that aerial turret, you lose for the entire fight the mobility of the hook for instance.  Final comments:  Overall, despite the relatively standard gameplay I enjoyed the immersion and story of the game and would recommend the game to shooter and Bioshock fans. 3.5 / 5.0

Tentative recommend. I actually didn't enjoy this game as much as the original Bioshock. Why?  I think in part it has to do with the fact that Infinite feels like it's more story than gameplay. The gameplay isn't bad. It just doesn't feel inspired. Bioshock 1 & 2 had about a dozen powers and a lot of sub-powers you could configure, plus hacking/stealth aspect. Infinite drops all of that and gives you six main powers, and about two dozen or so sub-powers which can only fit in four slots. All in all, it just felt rather simple, even with the ability to ride sky-rails, and it didn't hold my interest.  The checkpoint system was rather annoying, and the loss of cash on dying should have been a hard-mode option only. I particularly loathed the fact that the game put me in this fun looking sky-city world -- and then punished me if I decided to take a leap off a ledge and see what was there. Psst: Developers, I would never have this complaint if you implemented a true save/load mechanism.  The story and visuals are top notch. But this game feels like a Hollywood blockbuster to me; All style, little substance.  Despite that: The world of Columbia didn't feel as real to me as Rapture. Rapture was a disintegrating utopia filled with criminals driven insane by their mad desire for perfection. A world of gibbering splicers running amongst the feet of prowling Big Daddies. It was a circus nightmare and you were thrust into the middle of it.  But Columbia? It was a nice, ideallyic 1950s American dream (yes, including the blatant racism). And then you come in and tear it all down. Because of that, I didn't feel sympathy for the protagionist. I guess the devs were hoping for a 'YEAH SHOW THOSE RACIST ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥S, GO IN THERE AND SMASH THEIR FACES IN!' vibe, but honestly I find that far less interesting than entering a world already driven mad by its corrupt philosophy, as was seen in Rapture. I want to see Columbia fail on its own, because of its terrible premise. I don't want to actually be the cause of that failure.

Bioshock infinite deserves all of its awards and praises.   Starting off from the introduction of the game, you are playing as the character Booker Dewitt. As the game goes on, you, the player, will come to discover the true story behind the person you are playing as and the story of other important characters. Taking place in the city in the sky (Columbia), your mission to get this girl will result in your involvment in other peoples' lives, and it'll change the person who you play as, who you'll partner with, and everone else around you.   Unlike many first person shooters, this game comes with a wonderful story, and yet, it maintains its acclaimed gloriness of Bioshock with the classical use of powers and guns.   If you have watched trailers and video introductions to the game, you could notice that one of the biggests accomplishments of the game is the usefullness of your partner Elizabeth. You don't have to defend her from getting shot or crushed to death, for she hides behind walls and pillars that are not to far from you (plus she doesn't appear to take any damage at all anyways). When you shooting enemies either with your gun or shock, Elizabeth will provide provisions such as ammo, salt (the 'fuel' used to provide you powers), and health packs to make sure you can keep on fighting. Also, outside of battles she will occasionally toss a coin to you. In some occasions, you'll find Elizabeth's presence will prove most helpful both in battle and in the sole story line too (I'm trying not to spoil things here. Just look at the trailers. They can explain her usefullness pretty well).   She just isn't a worthless character in the game; she'll one of the greatests partners you'll have.     All-in-all, the game is wonderful, and I definitely recommend the game to all of you. However, the ending is quite confusing at first, which is the only major negative thing I can think of about the game.   The implication of first person shooter with powers, the lovable characters whom you'll not easily forget, and the awesome story line 9.3/10. Get the game!

Short review, Bioshock Infinite contains superficial things (biologically induced powers, unique setting with beautiful scenery, altnernative time periods) that made Bioshock 1 and 2 cool but forgot about what really made them compelling, original, thought provoking, and amazing. It's breathtakingly gorgeous with some unique quirks; but the depth and complexity that made the first two games so satisfying is absent from Bioshock Infinite.  Long review, There are things about the game that are fun and interesting, but much of the gameplay is disappointing. It really is a beautiful game if you have a computer than can run it at full capacity, and some of the weapons are really fun and feel great to use. And the skyrail is amazing; it doesn't make any sense as to why it doesn't rip your arm off and why you can reload and shoot a sniper rifle one-handed while flying through the air -- but it's a really awesome mode of transportation and can be really handy in a fight.  They also changed the maps so that it's more linear and there's less exploration, and the combat system kind of sucks. I like that you can only have a couple guns at any one time because it lets you use some strategy in how you play. But the enemies are bland, like they didn't know how to make the game more challenging, so they just threw in a greater number of enemies, and you don't even have to use the vigours (the plasmids of Infinite). In fact, the vigours don't even feel like they fit in the world at all. There's one that allows you to control an enemy to fight off other enemies -- and then they kill themselves after it times out - which is disgusting and extremely horrible and entirely unnecessary.   Beyond that, though, the story and the characters are very one-dimensional in comparison to the first two games The pacing is very slow in the middle of story, and they just kind of drop major characters from the beginning because they didn't know what to do with them at the end. I don't want to say too much about Elizabeth for those who haven't played the game yet, but she starts out really cool. But then she just gets really annoying and turns into a fetch machine. She also progessively loses clothing throughout the game which is gross for more than one reason considering the relationship between Booker (the guy you play as) and her. Elizabeth is not at all the strong character she's made out to be, and is certainly not a strong female character. She has little to no agency in the world except to be annoying, and continues to be a damsel despite the fact that she has amazing powers which she could use to really kick ♥♥♥ - if they'd let her.  The plot is exalted by some for its stunning originality, insight and complexity; others just find it very confusing. Actually though, the plot, and especially the ending, is a dazzling display of 'let's confuse the player to make them feel like this is a grand and original plot; we went too slow in the middle of the game so if we confuse them maybe they won't see through the massive black hole sized plot holes and paper-thin construction of this story.'  The first two games were really good because they were thought-provoking and provided a critical analysis of important topics (capitalsism vs socialism, power, socioeconomic class, parenthood) while still being fun and not feeling preachy.  Bioshock Infinite tries to approach topics of race, prejudice, oppression, and revolution; but it approaches these issues flatly and, in the case of race, very irresponsibly. Racial discrimination is a complex issue and although they try to show that it is a horrible thing, they ended up creating an offensive environment rather than providing a platform to think about and discuss deeper issues. This is possibly because the team developing the game was likely all or mostly white, and as much as they wanted to, they simply could not explore issues of race in the needed depth and complexity because those are not challenges that they, being white, face everyday.   So, while Bioshock Infinite is beautiful and is set in an awe-inspiring city in the sky, while it has a few really cool things that make it fun (some parts of the story, the skyline, some of the vigours) it's dragged down by its own success in that the developers lost sight of what really makes Bioshock amazing.

I don't normally write reviews but the fact that a mediocre game like this is getting overwhelmingly postive reviews bothers me. I know I'm the minority here but hear me out. I loved the first bioshock. It wasn't a perfect game by any means (repetitive late game) but the atmosphere, large variety of weapon/plasmid options and story were fantastic. Then comes bioshock infinite, a game that takes almost everything the first does right and throws it away.   I'll start off with what I liked: -interesting world -great atmosphere -great voice acting  -shooting feels a little better than in bioshock 1  Now the bad: -Poor story that when crtically analyzed is completely illogical  -Lack of meaningful decisions. There's parts in the game were you have to choose between two options. Your choice doesn't affect the outcome of the game at all.  -The game scraps the multiple weapon options of the first bioshock in favor of a two gun limit that's present in almost every other modern shooter. This is one the worst offenders. There's even a weapon upgrade system in the game but it doesn't matter since you'll probably have to drop the weapon you've spent a ton of resources on upgrading.  -These are more subjective but the vigors aren't as useful, interesting or unique as the one's in the first game. The handyman fights also feel very scripted and aren't as fun as the big daddy fights from bioshock 1.   Conclusion: The game isn't horrible but it certainly isn't the masterpiece the overwhelmingly positive reviews seem to suggest. If I had to score it I'd give it a 6/10. It's mediocre or average at best. There are way better options for both gameplay and story. Save yourself some time and skip this one. I'm about to delete it from my hard drive right now.

Infinite is a great third game to the Bioshock Series. I initially had my reservations with it, at it seemed to take the game in a completely different direction, both in terms of gameplay and storytelling. But it completely won me over very soon into the game.  Gameplay: This game has some pretty major differences to the previous games in the series. Most of these are pretty good.  - You're restricted to only two weapons at a time, which I think gives you a more realistic FPs than one where you can lug around an entire armoury on your shoulders. - New vigours or plasmids. These mix up the special powers into something much more imaginative and magical. - No more fiddling around with gene splicing. This game makes the process of upgrading yourself a bit simpler. You can have as many upgrades as you want active, provided you have enough coin to buy them. There are some 'magic gears' that you can get and wear. I'm not entirely sure I like them, as they randomly generate and are hidden around levels, but they provide extra abilities if you want them. - Sky Hooks. One of the great things in this game is the sky hook. This, with the lines you can zip around on and jump everywhere give a sense of freedom to the environment that takes advantage of the fact that this game feels very 'open', even though it's played fairly linearly. It reminds me a lot of what I felt playing mirrors edge. - Much larger levels. This game has much larger levels and gives you more freedom of movement between them. It also makes good use of 'tears', which allow you to modify the combat field in imaginative ways. - Elizabeth. The game introduces what I think is one of the best 'companions' in an FPS I've ever played. She provides you help in combat that goes beyond just shooting back at enemies, but actively scouts for loot so you don't have to. The game also makes use of some pretty good AI which, even though Elizabeth is just following you around, makes it seem as if she is actively makign choices on her own, and actually feels 'alive'. Given all of these changes, I feel as if the game play in this game is a great improvement on the previous bioshock games.  Story:  This game takes a big departure from the previous bioshock storytelling. Rather than following someone on a radio, you are more directly involved with the events that are playing out before you. This game has a pretty deep story, that I won't go too much into because of plot spoily reasons, but it involves a lot of great themes like   parallel universes, family relationships, and hard choices.   Plus, the characters in the game all seem to be very real, and rather than having your standard villain that you need to beat, everyone is on a spectrum of good to evil. The game also helps to add depth to the story by the use of tape\record\video collecting to tell the stories of some background characters, if you want to seek them out, like in previous games.  Graphics: The graphics in this game are amazing. The environments of all of the structures are beautifully crafted, with buildings that give a real atmosphere of everything from a lived-in 1900s american city, to a civil-war style battleground, all surrounded by steampunk floaty island-ness. The main characters have some great design to them, both from a perspective of their general appearance, and the design of the costumes\clothes\armour they are wearing. I did see a fair bit of copy\paste in the background civilians, but the game did include a few stand-out background characters even though they appear only briefly [like the barbershop quartet]. The post processing was a bit much at times for my tastes, but that can be fine tunes if you want.  The worst part of this game: Checkpoints. Checkpoints are awful. The previous games allowed you to save anywhere you wanted, but this game restricts you to only saving at given checkpoints. This provides a problem as if, like me, you like to explore every nook and cranny of a level, you can spend a long time between checkpoints. And if, for life reasons, you need to take a break, your options are all awful. Quit and lose all progress; pause the game and leave it running, hoping your computer doesn't crash or suffer a power loss; run ahead to the next available checkpoint and miss out on all combat, as when you reload your save next time, the enemies will not respawn. It would be great if someone at 2K games were able to implement this, but unfortunately, you're just going to have to deal with it.  That aside, overall this game is great. One of the best I've played in a long time. Great if you like FPS games, and can be played independently of any previous bioshock games.
