Credentials: Played through Bioshock completely several times, played Bioshock 2 with 100% completion, and now have played Infinite thoroughly taking my time to examine every area, listen to every audio log, watch every video log, and closely pay attention to every plot element in the game.  Bioshock Infinite, I will be referring to it as Infinite from now on, is a beautiful game with very deep and rich lore and plot. The game also runs very smoothly and Infinite's gameplay is very fast-paced and strategic. You can use the various weapons and vigors (plasmids from the first two games or essentially scientific magic for those new) in combination to overcome your enemies.   (DON'T WORRY. READING THIS WON'T SPOIL THE GAME) Infinite's general plot briefly: You play as Booker Dewitt. A man forced to find a girl and either willfully or forcibly return her to New York. Doing so would wipe away his massive gambling debt. Booker isn't your average protagonist. He is a man who lived a crooked life often being hired to scare or attack workers who refused to work do to unsafe conditions, low pay, etc. However, he is also a man filled with regret and depression.   Unfortunately for Mr. Dewitt, he might have bit off more than he can chew. When, he is sent to Columbia, a post-civil war American city in the sky. While this city might be beautiful on the outside, it has a very ugly inside. Columbia is a city consumed by nationalism, a radical altered version of Christianity created by their 'Prophet', and xenophobia. In Columbia, if you are not of Anglo-Saxon descent, then you are a lesser creature. Racism and xenophobia are celebrated in Columbia. They make a game out of showing hatred towards couples of different race and even have attractions of heavily stereotyped cultures to either get a laugh or a scare. This is thanks to their 'Prophet' and his heavily altered version of Christianity that depicts the white man as the pure and superior race. The poor don't fair much better here either as there is no such thing as worker's rights, minimum wage, or unions in Columbia. The poor have to demean themselves by bidding their pay, break time, or hours against others to try and get a job.   Booker faces many hurdles and challenges in order to try and complete his job.  Pro's/Con's:  -World is very immersive. -Combat feels fast and accurate. No bad mechanics to make you scream at the screen. -Amazing voice acting. Booker feels like a real person. All of the supporting characters do amazing as well. -The girl he must find, Elizabeth, is possibly one of the best female characters that I have seen in a game.   Her model is not over-sexualized and her personality is realistic. This is one of the few times the damsel in distress isn't   portrayed as a helpless dainty child-like woman. -The A.I. of your in game ally is actually helpful. They either spot out useful items, pick up things you might have missed   to give to you, or toss you much needed supplies that you can't reach when your pinned down behind cover. -The game's plot is clear and at the same time deep. (SORTA SPOILER?) Only the ending, might cause some confusion.   However, it gives you a lot to think on and if you don't understand something the ending has been explained in depth   on various sites. -Visuals and performance are great. I ran the game on almost max settings with a GTX 760 2GB VRAM and pretty much   never had a noticeable frame drop except in one specific area which is very open and the drop was very small and barely   noticeable (which is possibly the most annoying since they don't warrant changing your settings). -THEY ADDED HATS!! Ok in all seriousness they actually did add hats that you can't see though. Clothing in the game   acts as combat modifiers.  -Tons of secrets and side-quests to do. This game highly promotes exploring.  Con's (Mostly nitpicking):  -(HIGHLY RECOMMENDED SPOILER) There is a scene after the credits you will miss if you skip them. This scene changes   the ending heavily. -One vigor allows you to have an enemy machine become friendly for a short time. You can use this on vending   machines to have some money come out of the machine. This will agro the entire area. Everyone will act as if you just   fired a gun or shot a bolt of lightning from your hand. Doing this may cause you to miss cool in game scenes of citizens. -(NOT MY OPINION) Unlike the first two you cannot carry every gun at the same time. You are limited to two guns that   you can swap out. They probably used this system to allow them to have more guns in the game and I am fine with it,   but some people have complained. -Weapon upgrades are once again present in the game. However, they make no sense. Since, you can drop your weapon   and pick up a new one at any time having your weapon upgraded you just picked up doesn't make sense.  -Weapon upgrades don't visually alter the weapons. -Vigor upgrades use cash instead of another resource like in the others. This presents a problem mostly because they   are so expensive. In my play through I purchased only a few I really wanted and still didn't have enough money to   upgrade all my weapons. Not even close. -Vigors also seem slightly less interesting in this installment the previously and some are introduced when you only have   a few hours left of gameplay. You will probably use a few of them and barely touch the others. -Too many of the clothing modifiers alter melee or skyline combat. If you play on harder difficulties melee often isn't a   choice.  -Some of the secrets in game require you to first learn of the secret before you can find them. Even if you see where a   secret is and find a button or hidden switch you can't use it until you find a recording mentioning it. -No hacking like the originals. A vigor takes place of it.  Overall, the game is a must play. It has an amazing story and visual environment. Unfortunately, my pro's list might seem short compared to my con's list, but I had to be vague to avoid spoilers. Many pro's you need to discover for yourself and like I said my con's are mostly nit-picking. I was never bothered by any of them except for the one about the vending machines. Since, your character is so strapped for cash it sucks deciding whether to get some extra cash or experience more story.

I have mixed feelings when it comes to this game. The gameplay is solid, although quite unrealistic; but this is understandable for Bioshock.  Good things: It was fun, the story was engaging and the world was unique, it gave a nice open-air feel as opposed to underwater.  Bad things: People were too bullet resistant. I think this changes on the easier difficulties, but on the hardest (not 1999 because I hadn't unlocked it) you would be shooting someone from the the Columbia PD 3 or 4 times in the head before they died. The sky hook thing was a nice game mechanic, but I never understood and still don't understand how a spinny metal thing on your arm lets you run and jump 30m through the air and grab onto a hook. Why it doesn't dislocate your arm at the elbow and the shoulder is also a puzzle. When Booker is holding two handed guns, he suddenly doesn't have the massive metal thing on his arm, but when you melee he swings his arm out and there's the sky hook. The front sights and rear sights were way too large on all of the firearms, and realistically you could not shoot accurately with them. The weapons were a little weird, with some of them quite antique for 1912 and others way ahead of the time period. This was explained via the tears though. I've seen the video about how everyone would be throwing up from motion sickness, and I won't elaborate on that. It seems that the only currency in Columbia is the Silver Eagle, which you spend like dollars in the 21st century. All the signs that have fireworks and popcorn at prices like 10c are meaningless unless you have those coins.................you don't. Like all games of this type, there's the ability to carry thousands of coins the size of your palm around in some kind of mega wallet that doesn't make you move like a snail, need I say more? Fink has all of the workers making the manufactured goods, but where does the fresh fruit come from? I see oranges in baskets, and yet I see no floating agricultural area anywhere in game or on the map. There are quite a lot of people in Columbia, but they don't really seem to do much apart from look at the various monuments or talk to each other. There are the shops and businesses, but not much in the way of employment for everyone else. In that time period it was common for the rich to live off inheritance and investments, but it's not like the economy in Columbia could thrive without trade.  Honestly I could go on for a thousand pages and I think I'll leave it there.  The game was fun but the society/world/city would not work. I couldn't ignore the listed problems and it kind of ruined the experience for me, but maybe it won't for you.

I think this may be the single greatest game I have ever played, and it is certainly the best achievement of the Bioshock series. Words cannot describe how much I love this game. I bought it on Xbox 360 and then again on Steam because I loved it so much.  The environments are vivid and breathtaking. Columbia feels like a moving and breathing place from the second you step onto the first brick. Something Ken Levine really excelled with here was atmosphere, you can feel the city watching you, you can feel its emotions. If you are looking for an experience similiar to the original bioshock, you are not going get it here. Bioshock 1 was the anthesis of 'the perfect game' it was, and still is one of the best and complete packages that you can get for 60$.  With it's sequel 'infinite' (and no bioshock 2 does not count, it was amde by other developers) it seems that irrational took out S.P.E.C.I.A.L points in various areas and put them into very specific categories. Where Bioshock 1 was a game where everything was great thus projecting the image of 'the perfect game', Infinite has some areas that are glorious where others are alright.  Bioshock 1 had various elements that made it great. Compelling, Diverse and Intelligent Gameplay, an fantastic open world and a very appealing narrative. And it excells in all of these areas perfectly.  Whereas Infinite has a Different, Diverse but not as compelling gameplay. Infinite plays like DOOM in a way that it is designed so that the player is forced to constantly move. In doom you always have to run around regardless if there is any room to run in. Wheras Infinite is focused on forcing the player on constantly shifing positions.  Firefights in infinite usually go like this. Encounter enemy > take Sky Line > Position in area > shoot guys > Repeat. There is ovbs more meat aound this structure like weapons, elizabeth, gear, vigors (plastids) etc... But unfortunately BSI suffers from the same thing that many fast paced shooters are plagued from and that is, without proper design fast game play is very hard to make compelling. The only franchise that I have played that has succeded in this was the original DOOM and 2016 DOOM.  That is not to say that the game play is bad, but when stacked with Bioshock 1. As a fan it is very distasteful. But as an outsider or as someone who actually has a life it's simply two different ways of play. It was impossible to intergrate BS1 combat into BSI's world. It was not going to work and I think that the decision they made as a good one, although I feel that they should have added more depth to preparation for fight. For example putting traps on sky tracks, etc....  The vigors are also back and IMHO they are very underwhelming. I have never touched charge or undertow. Chances are you will really only stick to Shock Jockey, Bronco and the shield one. As they are very inexpensive and very convenient. Stunning players is very vital in these games and these casts allow it to be done easily. That does not mean there is no place for the others they are accomodated for. But when the game provokes you to constantly shift positions, it would be stupid not to pick the casts that slow your foes down.  The world is subjective. Simply put whether or not you liked rapture or colombia will be one of those debates that leads down to taste and taste only. Irrational has managed to protray these worlds excellently, and giving the player the opportunity to explore them thoroughly. If you are looking for a compelling world with good lore and are openminded to concepts other than what is presented in bioshock 1 then there is no doubt in my mind that you will like this as well.  Lastly story. This is where I think bioshock infinite surpasses Bioshock 1. And by this i mean main story. Both games offer significant amounts of lore content, and we can go on forever about which one is better. But Bioshock Infinite's narrative as a game surpasses Bioshock 1 in every single way. You will see more or less that same elements from the previous narrative, the only difference is that Infinite builds up on those elements. People tend to like BS1' characters and story more because it's a very dark and scary game (for puss ies) and thus it sticks to them more. But Infinite does not have scary thing for it to rely on. Bioshock 1 was very grim, most of it's characters predicated themselives on something really ♥♥♥♥ed up, making them extremely memorable. But when it comes to the actual lore that YOU do as a character, it simply boils down to 'escape rapture' sure there are a couple of other things to care about, but fundamentally the point that the story wants to drive into your squall is that you want to get the ♥♥♥♥ out.  And infinite does almost the exact same thing. But offers me more things to actually care about. Everything is very in your face, its very bold and it's not scary. Character are very ideologically driven and not just crazy and whether or not youl ike the former or the latter more. One needs to understand that Bioshock Infinite predicates its story around a gripping and emotional narrative. In BS1 you are more or less alone, and this was good for a dark shooter. But BSI is a polar opposite and offers a more bombastic duo in the form of Booker and Elizabeth. The dymanic between these characters if fantastic and how they play along together in the game is glorious. There are even the lettuce's which are just a joy to play with. And thne you got your Fitzroy and Comstock which is baiscally Atlas Vs Ryan. Everything in this world is extra and it's great that it's there.  Unline BS1 where it was really only about 'you,you,you' What really drives the narrative home and what makes BSI better than BS1 narratively is that connection you have with Elizabeth. Elizabeth is the main character of this story, you play a secondary role as booker. This story makes sure you know that. Elizabeth is the bread and butter of this story, and she ties everything very nicely. Now this may seem like a bad thing, a narrative that revolves around one person especially when there is such a bit and diverse world, but thankfully Irrational adds outside elements like what i mentioned in the previous paragraph, and in addition how pleasant Elizabeth is as a character.  Although she does provide a small role gameplay-wise. Elizabeth is by far one of the best written characters I have ever seen in a video game. I have been playing games since I was 4, from ut 99 Lan Parties with my dad in 2000-2001 to now. I have yet to see or experience a game with a character that makes me so happy. Elizabeth is by far the most human character I have seen in any game ever. Her voice, her child like composure, her sympathy and slight ignorance makes her an extremely easy character to root for. She interacts with you constantly in the game and it's great, she pokes at you constantly and it spawns interesting dialogue between your character and hers. It's is geunienly fantastic. She leads this game, she is the reason that you should buy this game. It's honestly hard to explain unless you play the game for yourself, but all i can say is that the tension between you and her along with the adventurous tone of the story, works flawlessly. Surpassing BS1 narratively in every single aspect.  Overall, if you are looking for a compelling, dramatic, thoughtful narrative. Look no further. Unfortuneately if the game play was put to such a level as the narrative this game would of blown BS1 out of the water. But im glad that both of the titles have something unique that make them enjoyable. And I love both of the titles for what they are. Just fkn buy this game man,

I'm not entirely sure where to start with this review of Bioshock Infinite. At time of writing (around 10 hours after the UK release on March 26th 2013), I finished the 8+ hour campaign in a single sitting around 2-3 hours ago after no sleep and I'm still trying to mentally process the experience in order to evaluate it. While this might not immediately sound like the best mindset to have when trying to writing a review, I felt now is the best time as this post-game mindset perfectly reflects my feelings towards Bioshock Infinite as a game: breathtaking, awe inspiring, thought provoking, complex, deep and utterly brilliant.   Ken Levine and the team at Irrational Games have outdone themselves once again by creating yet another extremely inventive, inspired and interesting game world inhabited by intriguing and believable characters. As hard as this may be to swallow for some players, Columbia and it's inhabitants are far more developed and enjoyable to spend time around than Rapture, to the point where standing and watching the city folk go about their lives becomes an immersive highlight of the game. The arrival of a wide variety of interesting and developed characters such as Booker, Elizabeth, Comstock and Fitzroy is extremely welcome as the brilliant acting and stellar writing from the first game once again return, just with a much greater focus on personal character development this time around.   If, for some weird reason, you're still on the fence about whether or not to buy Bioshock Infinite, look at it this way. If you're looking for a deeply engrossing and immersive game world with astonishing visual design, fast paced inventive gameplay or an emotionally driven and complex storyline, look no further. While the game would've already been fantastic if it had merely replicated Bioshock 1, additional innovative design elements such as the social/religious/racial commentaries push the game that much further as a powerfully moving and artistic interactive experience, making them the added seasoning which makes Bioshock Infinite one of those few astonishingly high quality games that nobody should miss.   9.7/10 - Very Highly Recommended

If you haven't bought BioShock Infinite yet, do it. Do it now! BioShock: Infinite is slightly less of a game, and slightly more of a critique on early-20th-century American culture and values. It plays like an interactive novel, and doesn't fail to deliver an excellent story, engaging characters, and pathos (ability to inspire emotion). Though the 'choices' the developers offer are more-or-less meaningless to gameplay (choose one design of necklace over the other), if you as a player read into those choices, they can become extremely poignant and meaningful. BioShock: Infinite, like its predecessors BioShock and BioShock 2, is an excellent game to analyze. It's also fun to play, though combat does get a bit repetitive, and you are restricted to only two main weapons and your Vigors (supernatural powers). Some enemies do not properly scale (you will wipe the floor with Vox Populi cannon fodder, but as soon as a Handyman shows up, you will be shooting him for the next ten minutes), and the game DOES get pretty preachy at some parts (because you are playing a character with a history, instead of your own customized hero) - and the entire ending of the game makes absolutely no sense unless you accept the possibility of the multiverse - but these are things you can ignore and focus on the good gameplay and storyline. In my first full playthrough, I didn't use Vigors nearly enough, so I'm looking forward to getting the Burial At Sea DLC and working on that.

How should I put this... The Bioshock series are games where you needed to delve in them with an artistic mentality, Meaning they're all works of art. Bioshock Infinite, while somewhat differentiating in atmosphere when compared to the original 2, still carries the excellent plot and characters (large emphasis on characters by the way) that made Bioshock 1 and 2 brilliant.  The first 2 things that jumped out to me when starting this game was: 1. The music design- My god I swear as soon as I heard a Barbershop Quartet cover of The Beach Boys- God only knows, I knew this game was special as this was intended, not just as a tool but as a foreshadowing technique. Using music to hint at future plot is a hard thing to do and is commendable. 2. The Sidekick- To me, The sidekick of Bioshock Infinite is what Navi from Ocarina of Time should've been; Useful to both the plot and gameplay. Its abillities as a sidekick are varied from giving you health, money, ammo and salts (this game's version of mana) to opening gateways known as Tears which summon numerous equipment into the game's myriad plane.  Anyway if you are experiencing Bioshock for the first time, it is a FPS for the higher class citizens meaning it is free from bland storylines and 10yr old turkish boys who want to get schwifty with your mother. However no prepubescents means no online mode which is a shame as Bioshock 2 has this. What really makes the gameplay interesting are the skylines, allowing for fast-paced traversal and action, and the unique vigors, whick are essentially biopunk spells (My personal favourites being the shock jokey and murder of crows). These features, along with the variety of weapons, make the gameplay very exciting.  But wait, there's more as the story is gripping and littered with twists and turns that will boggle your mind like the peasants you all are. The only negatives I could say about this game is the brutal difficulty curve near the end of the game and the meh graphics.  Overall, I cannot recommend this game enough as well as it's DLC ( especially the Burial at sea story line). This game is best played firsthand otherwise it removes the vital charms this game. Additionally, if you're planning to play the series in its entirety, it's best if you start like this for the best canonical experience: Bioshock Infinite- Burial at sea- Bioshock 2: fall of rapture- Bioshock 1- Bioshock 2- Bioshock 2: minerva's den. Also keep in mind, you need to to keep an artisans approach when playing the series and think of Bioshock Infinite as a work of Picasso's and the rest as art by H. R. Giger. You may interpret that statement as you see fit but for now I'm going back to my whisky and cigars. Ciao.

What can I say that hasn't been said already? Maybe I should just explain a small aspect of my own personal experience with it..... My wife enjoyed watching me play this game so she had just as much invested in it, and was there with me as the story unfolded and we learned the tale of Booker Dewitt and the somewhat convoluted story of Elizabeth. The night I finished the game when I took my hands off the keyboard (knowing of course that this was the moment after the big final epic battle) we both just sat there in stunned silence as the game concluded itself. When the credits had finished rolling and the last tidbit of end-game material was gone, we still just sat there, silent, for at least 3-5 mins staring at the title screen and trying to absorb what we had just been witness to. This game really changed the way I think about what story-telling in video games should mean. This also was one of the rare instances of when I felt that the pro reviewers and journalists were totally justified in handing out 10/10 scores for a game. It was perfect in almost every way.

[If you are wondering about the stats, I completed the game on my alt account, and bought it on this one for the DLCs since the discount was so good]  Gonna have to say no to this one.  Here's what you gotta understand about Bioshock: it's a story-based game with a very specific lore. Lore requires a sort of 'scientific magic' to be present to give the atmosphere it's unique charm and it is also used for gameplay. That's just it: it's used in  atmosphere  and  gameplay . Is does  not  work as a centerpiece of the storyline. Story in Bioshock games has always been about morality. It's been about 'How much is 'too much'?'. Infinite takes a turn in a different direction of pseudo-scientific plot twists (hence the name), in it's attempt to surprise the player, and unfortuntaley fails at is big time.  The story in infinite revolves around the a splified and twsited version of the alternate dimensions theory(ies), and without spoiling anything for you I can say one thing: the big plot twist of the game is basically this:  'LOL all this ♥♥♥♥ you did doesn't matter because the variable x in world 0x62756c6c736869742331 has crossed variable y at location (6,6,6) since rabbit stepped on his carrot that turned out to be a big daddy and eat the coordinate at a dinner party with ID 0x637261636b. I know this all ♥♥♥♥ is confusing and nonsensical, but you, the player, just need to understand that all you did was a giant waste of time. Plot twist! Ovations please!'  The Mass Effect 3 syndrome™ is present in full with this game, where writers tried too hard to surprise and 'mystify' the player and this Elizabeth character and ended up going way over their heads.  The game is also quite linear. Where I was hoping for hubs to explore, side-quests to take, people to help/hinder and affect the outcome of the main story with that, I found chocies that are only forced and meaningless (no effect on the story), no hubs, no side-quests and wholly linear level design and story (which makes sense for the latter since all you do is a waste of time so what's the point in making different variations and giving you chocies?).   The world of the game is great and certainly up to par and Elizabeth is also well-integrated into gameplay in a way that doesn't frustrate you, but also gives her an important role. But due to linearity and lack of interaction (the aforementioned lack of hubs and exploration), getting better aquanted withe the world is not really an option and the bits where you can observe the lore, are mostly set gallery pieces, with very limited interaction, the only exception being the beginning of the game at the festival, that lets you participate in activities (but not properly talk to people and no side-quests obviously).  While having it's moments, Infinite is most certainly a big let down for me due to contrived and over-complicated storyline and linearity. I can only recommend it at a good discount (60% and less) and certainly not full price.

I know I'm a day late and a buck short on this game, but holy ♥♥♥♥ have I been missing out. But at least I waited to play the PC version. Anyway on with the review. Bioshock: Infinite is the third in the series, but takes place in 1912 instead of the 60's and the 70's. You play as Booker DeWitt, a broken man who has to go to the city of Coloumbia to get a girl to wipe away the gambleing debts. Let's talk about Coloumbia, because it's a much better setting then Rapture to me. First: It's floating, so that makes it cooler then a leaky underwater city. Second: It has more color in it, which is always a good thing, and it looks butiful. If you have at least a mid-range PC this game will look good, hell I'd recomend that you turn in to low then turn it to ultra (if you can handle it) because the coding even says low in equvilent to the consoles. Just incase you're wondering, I palyed it on a GTX 760, and it ran fine at ultra, but enough about graphics. On your journy through the city you'll have one of the gretest supporting and female charicter at your side: Elizibeth. Now you may be worried about her being an Esscort mission like Ashly from Resident Evil 4, but fear not! The game actually tells you flat out, don't worry about her, she can take care of herself. Actually I hated the parts where she wasn't there, she helps out in combat too. Every so often an icon will apear telling you that Elizibeth found something usful and she'll give it to you; stuff like Ammo, Salts, and Health, so all in all Elizibeth is a wonderful charicter. While we're talking about gameplay, let's dive deeper into it. You have your standard Plasmid (now called Vigors) and gun setup, but now instead of a dedicated melee weapon like the drill or wrench, you have hook. This hook is not only used to pull off badass finish moves on enemys, but you can use it to move around fast and strike people from the skylines for maximum damage. This time there around as many 'there's water shoot bolts of electricy at it to fry enemys' moments, but you have something that's better. Elizibeth can open 'tears' . These are portals to a different world, and they can spawn things like guns, turrets, and hook for you well...hook. The catch is, you can only open one at a time, and this spices up combat in fun ways to keep from making it dull. If I had to complain about the combat, it's you can only hold 2 guns at a time. This forces into holding 2 guns you really like instead of exspirmenting. I just ran with the burst rifle and RPG as much as possible. The rest of the game is solid, Booker is a really interesting charicter, and he's voiced by Troy Baker who is also Joel from The Last of Us and does a wonderful job. There are also two mysterious charicters that add dry humor to the game. The biggest problem I have with not only this game, but the whole Bioshock series in genral is how much ♥♥♥♥ing sidetracking there is. Can we go to point A? No we have to track down two tears and battle the same boss three times to do that! It's not as bad as the first one, but it's still glearing. The city being built in the air ads a lot of cool set pices like fighing on a huge zepplin. You may have noticed I haven't talked much about the story, because I would be sinning if I spoil anything, so just play it for yourself and have fun! 10/10

After playing through the game I have good and bad things to say so I'll put them in the pros and cons sections then go into a bit of detail.  Pros -  Responsive controls (KB + M) Pleasuring graphics Great sound (game + voices) Pacing Satifying gameplay Various ways to go about combat Narrative Balance  Cons -  Value to play time Difficulty Supplies dump (Elizabeth giving) DLC (not counting BAS 1 + 2)  In-depth starting with Pros  Responsive controls - The game had excellent controls and mouse functionally, I turned Mouse Acceleration off but other than that the game had excellent responsive controls with no akward controls except maybe the 'Show Objective' button was set to N by default so it was kind of akward to pull my hand over but otherwise great.  Pleasuring graphics - I ran the graphics at High, Medium and Low and even at the Medium quality the game still looked great, the color pallatte and bright colors switched nicely with the darker tone near the end of the game. Never felt like a random jump.  Great sound - Audio was amazing, the songs fit the time period and theme of Columbia and always fit the situation. Troy Baker does an amazing job once again as Booker DeWitt making a interesting and believable character. Elizabeth was a great addition and added interesting dialogue based on my actions. If I did something in the game world she would respond with things like 'Oh my god!' for decapitating a man with a tool.  Pacing - The game was paced well and never went too fast or too slow. Making it to Elizabeth on Monument Island felt like an achievement for the hard work to get there. It had a nice amount of exploration, Hordes of enemies and story telling with no fighting.  Satifying gameplay - Gameplay was fun and interesting, It was simple to take out a horde of enemies cause there was always a secret to them that was easy enough to figure out. all the guns were fun to try out but for most of the game I stuck to the Shotgun and Sniper Rifle. I was able to go on the skyhook, air strike someone then take down a patriot without breaking motion. Vigors (Plasmids) were interesting and fun to use while mantaining practicality.  Various ways to go about combat - You never had to stick to one style of combat. you could sneak, go on the hooks or use vigors. you're never required to use Vigors except in certain situations.  Narrative - Story was simple at a glance but had a deeper meaning with the audio logs filling in backstory with historical connections. Characters kept it going and never got bored or un-interested in the story.  Balance - Combat was fun with each item having its own use, I never felt cheated by an enemy cause I always knew it was my fault for dying. Tougher enemies were challenging but I never had to kill them in a specific way.  Value to play time - Being a linear game it does finish in about 8 - 10 hours. I clocked in 11 hours with some exploring, but not combing every area of items or audio logs. It's probably a game I'll play once or twice every couple of months but It's more worth it as a rental. If you wanna buy it I'd say $15 - 20 would do it justice. It's like LA Noire in it's not worth $60. Pick it up on sale and give it a try.  Difficulty - The game was rather easy, I ran out of ammo a few times and died about 5. I never had to use melee only cause Elizabeth would always throw me more Salts (EVE) and ammo. I turned the difficulty up to Hard near the end and even with that there was very little punishment for failing. 1999 mode is better if you want a real challenge.  Supplies Dump - Should go with Difficulty, Elizabeth gave me health, salts, ammo and money when I needed it. but not too often, once I got her I barely had to grab things myself. see Difficulty.  DLC - DLC is dumb, Burial At Sea Episode 1 + 2 are worth it but the others are cash grabs. Buy the Season Pass ONLY for Burial At Sea, like the game get it on sale.  Verdict -  Overall I found the game very fun and enticing. Gameplay, Sound and Story all tied in well and made a great way to spend my Friday. It's a good game but don't think it deserves the perfect scores it got. It's a good game to play if you like the Bioshock series and was worth the $7.50 I got it for. It has problems like it being too easy most of the time and not having much replay value besides doing all the choices you didn't do. Give it a try if you're thinking about it, you won't be disappointed.  8.5/10  Pretty ♥♥♥♥in' good.

Bioshock Infinite is the opposite of the first two games. As opposed to being dark, grim and creepy, Bioshock infinite is bright vibrant and action packed with some dark undertones. The game is shrowded with subtle foreshadowing as you are thrust into a new world with a seemingly cheerful setting, that is until you realize the way it's society works which is when the meat of the game begins. The visuals are easily one of the games strong points, it takes a 1940's setting and throws it into the sky. The world of Bioshock infinite is a work of art, there are many intricate details in it's design and it's fun just to explore... the first few minutes. Afterwards the game becomes a linear storydriven game which is a shame, i'd love to see an open world game with this concept but then again, this is Bioshock after all, Bioshock has always been a linear title but inlike the first two, Bioshock Infinite made me want to backtrack between areas to take in the scenary more but sadly the game doesn't let you do that after certain points. Early on in the game, there are a few open sections but later on, the linearity kicks in. This is where the game became less about the visuals and more about the action.  The story is a little convoluted but it's there. It gets a little crazy later on and the game kinda changes it's pace half way through. This is after a particular event in the story which is not necesarrily a major event but it does change the pacing of the game considerably. Afterwards the game feels like an adreniline rush all the way up to the end.  Gameplay wise, Bioshock Infinite takes it's RPG elements a tad lighter. Unlike the previous game, weapons and ammo are a lot easier to come by and plasmids are replaced with vigors which can be found throughout the game an upgraded at vending machines. I didn't mind the gameplay, it wasn't groundbreaking but it was good enough to be enjoyable. The two weapon limit kinda got annoying but it's not really a big deal in the long run since you'll find the weapons you like and stick with them.  All in all i reccommend this game as it's definitely worth your time.

An extremely dumbed down version of previous Bioshock games. The combat is extremely boring/repetitive, and the battles feel so artificial and staged; it really removes you from the game. The game is way too easy (on hard difficulty), until you get to one particular battle towards the end where you will die a bunch until you figure out how to corner yourself where you're not vulnerable (terrible game design). The rails aspect seemed like it would be fun, but I found myself rarely using it. Not a lot of depth in terms of the vigors and combining, although this was probably the most fun aspect of the game. They changed the weapon system to only give you two at a time, which is fine. However, because you pay to upgrade particular weapons, you either use those weapons you paid to upgrade the whole time, or spread your invest in upgrades because you'll get bored (or run out of ammo, though this didn't happen much) and keep switching weapons anyway. It definitely seems like all the effort went into leading you through a particular experience. The game is set up to just basically lead you through a scripted story. Fine...  So was the oversimplied combat redeemed by the story? No... This was one of the most convoluted plots of anything I have ever seen or played. Why did it have to go down the philosophical rabbit hole? Silly me, expecting them not to abandon what made the previous games great. This game story-wise was so close to being great. I guess it's just me (from seeing these positive comments) but I like when my actions in the game matter and amount to something. Especially in a game like this where you get emotionally involved in the characters. But the ending ruined this completely. It was very clear (especially from the clip after the credits) that your actions mean nothing. Why have a game with (minimal) choices at all? A game is not the right medium for this story at all.  Don't get me wrong, I applaud game developers and writers for trying something new. But the end was just as bad as a Deux Ex Machina, but for the game series I loved. Anyone who says this is a good 'game' hasn't played a good game before. You might as well just watch a movie like Looper or 12 Monkeys and save yourself about 8 hours.

Columbia makes an astonishing first impression, as the floating city setting of Irrational's Bioshock Infinite, built off the wonder and exceptionalism of 1912 America. Everything seemed possible thanks to industrialization. Almost immediately things sour, as the player is confronted with a deconstructed look at Columbia's hidden underclass, and astonishing racism. Citizens of Columbia pay tribute to their leader, Zachary Comstock, a religious fanatic who believes himself to be a prophet. These prophecies set the game into motion, as Private ♥♥♥♥ Booker Dewitt is drawn to Columbia in search of a girl. He is singled out from a crowd, launching Booker into self-defense that will carry him through extreme violence. The first hour can be spent enjoying the sights and sounds of a place that could not exist. One sequence takes the player through a carnival with playable games, others include a boardwalk with merry-go-round, and a beautiful beach. By contrast, another level is a horrifying museum. The art style is bright and energetic with bold character designs. Irrational's world-building is perfect, including compelling in-game ads, soundscape, and placing a player in the historical moment.The story is anything but light, taking classicism head on, as well as themes of violence and quantum destiny. Conversations help fill in the backstory as do voxophone and kinetescopes. Booker's first weapon is the skyhook, a gruesome melee weapon. Once you meet Elizabeth, a powerful and highly intelligent, yet innocent woman, she reacts to the player's violent actions. Elizabeth is integral, taking care of herself as well as throwing useful items to Booker. She has the latent ability to open and manipulate tears in space and time to pull in objects from other dimensions. Booker is equipped with turn of the century gun archetypes (revolver, shotgun, etc.) and Vigors, the Columbia version of Plasmids. Gear is also invaluable: it can have offensive and defensive attributes. Vigors include a fire grenade, crow attacks, the bucking bronco, and others, that can all be combined in amusing and creative ways pertaining to the elements and physics. The effect of Vigors on enemies can often be realistic and graphically violent. Prepare for head pops and bloody skeletons galore. Weapon upgrades can be readily purchased this time around. Much of the hacking type gameplay has been turned into button presses, with the possession vigor used to take over turrets and automatons.  Automatons modeled after Presidents are the largest threat to Booker, rivaled only by the Big Daddyesque Handyman, a lumbering behemoth of a mechanical man. Truthfully none of these opponents is too challenging one-on-one. It is only due to some excellent enemy scripting that combat comes alive.  On the hard difficulty groups teams engage in realistic fashions, rushing the player and forcing precise on the moment decision making. Skyrail combat introduces a whole new element to combat, and feels like a gameplay breath of fresh air. Irrational has crafted vertical arenas in which players can leap amongst opponents, transitioning to upper or lower levels. Bioshock blows the roof off standard shooter design. Inifinte is perfectly paced, and extremely compelling, better experienced than told, with astonishing developments and interesting characters. At its heart it is a love story, with Booker and Elizabeth linked and compelling protagonists. Side characters like the Lutece twins add shading to the narrative. Bioshock Infinite could never be the game Bioshock was. But like that title, it is a beautiful and moving game about legacies, fathers and daughters, idealized authoritarian societies fallen into chaos, and many thoughtful, well-considered gameplay elements. As class warfare begins to rip Columbia apart, the player can feel certain that this is due both to Booker's action and his inaction. It is a fine title, and although it clearly positions itself for a sequel, could series director Ken Levine truly have places to take Bioshock, beyond Infinite?

Perhaps this game should be called Bioshock Limited. The first half hour is stunning but, like Bioshock 1, it runs out of ideas very quickly. Just when you're starting to loathe the crazy religious nuts, it plays the racism card to convince you these people are really evil: it's like gilding the lily and effectively removes all ambiguity from the plot.  There are two choices in the game, neither of which make any difference to the plot. You know your character is a cold-blooded killer because it keeps telling you every few minutes. You meet the girl, she runs away, you catch her, she runs away, blah blah blah. You search for a gunsmith, go up the stairs, go down the stairs, enter a portal, go back up the stairs, back down the stairs, up and down and back and forth, wicky wicky wicky, stop the delikabate misberate. Did we mention racism was bad? Near the end everything goes strange. You go forward in time, you go back in time. Everyone keeps talking about choices, but you don't get any. All the plot and explanations are crammed into the last ten minutes, which may as well be one cut scene. The summary is (spoiler alert): you are the good guy, who turned bad, and also the bad guy, who just got worse. You kill the bad guy, then go back in time and kill the good guy (yourself) before he ever became bad or worse, thus the entire 8-12 hours of gameplay never actually happened. How satisfying.  If only I could go back in time and drown myself before I played this game.  3/10.

Bioshock Infinite has a great a story, great art style - but its combat system is sluggish. It also seems to suffer of 'Rapture' in the clouds' problems. If you have played Bioshock 1 and 2, and are a fan of its combat system and dystopian society storyline you should get it. If you want fast paced sharp combat and aren't much interested in getting immersed in a story I would look elsewhere.   On a sidenote, the save system is an attrocity. There is no way to manually save, neither quick save nor menu save. The checkpoints are often times spread out, forcing you to keep playing or lose sometimes 20 minutes worth of progress. Put a huge damper on my fun, as I absolutely loath checkpoint systems like this. Nowadays it should not be a problem to add such a functionality, but I suspect it might be related to consoles. The good thing is, there is a fov slider, and they seem to have put a modicum of effort into the PC version. (2013)

Aah yes, Bioshock Infinite. The 'game of the century!!!11' and the gr8st game of our generation, amirite? Not really, no. For an FPS shooter, it's only decent at best. But the story? Holy hell is it good. And the game looks good as a newborn baby. The reason why I'm not recommending it is simple; if you know from somewhere how it ends, there's no point in playing it, it has nothing revolutionary other than its story, so unless you buy it from a sale at a reasonable price, (10€/$/£ or less) there is no reason to buy it.  The main aspect of a shooter is to have fun with guns and the games' unique combat mechanics. But when the shooter has guns that are ♥♥♥♥ poor in damage, no real challenge and bullet spongy enemies, there is nothing left to redeem it. Vigors? A poor mans Plasmid. There is no reason why Columbia, a flying city, would have supernatural drinks just for Booker, since the citizens are too full of 'The Prophet' to use them themselves. I went straight for Hard since the previous Bioshocks were not hard either, hoping for a change in Infinite. Boy was i wrong, running out of ammo because a single enemy takes about a clip? Super hard indeed. Good thing I have an portable dispenser called Elizabeth with me who just happens to have the salts I need, or the ammo I desperately need. The last 30mins of the game consists of the game shoving down its story down your throat and you get to know about everything in the last minutes, which is super fun and subtle. Weapon upgrades are boring and there is no more hacking like in previous Bioshocks, Elizabeth just needs a handful of lockpicks to crack a safe or a door, and you just snap your fingers to get a person/robot on your side for a while. I also ran into 2 gamebreaking bugs which made me lose a total of about 20~ mins of my time because a 'must have' Vigor fell through the ground and an enemy just dissapeared and made it impossible to continue without resetting and killing everyone twice. The game is not perfect, it's not an 10/10, but it is a pretty strong 8/10. It's pretty overpraised to be honest. The sidequests consist of finding keys and looking for codes and that's it, don't expect a lot of freedom outside of the small transit areas with infinitely spawning enemies. (puns ahoy) If you can, borrow the game, or, if you've seen the ending, just pass it up, there's no point in wasting 8H grinding through enemies just to see yourself going: 'Huh, well that was sudden and- OH WAIT WHAT' *credits roll*

The game has really good visuals. Amazing visuals even. The sound is good too. But everything else is just a big fat MEH. The story is bad, Elizabeth as a charachter is flawed (She is like a Disney princess after being locked up in a tower all her life) and the gameplay is mediocre at best.  The skylines were one of the best parts of the game, allowing really fun manouvering around the arenas you are placed in, but the abilities the players have are not very fun to use, making the combat boring when the skylines are not present. Tonics feel misplaced in this game. I feel like the only reason they had them was because the game was a Bioshock game. In Bioshock 1 the tonics are there to exemplify what happens when science can advance without the moral boundaries we have in our civilization. But in Infite they are simply there. Only some special enemies use Tonics to fight you. No one in the general populace is shown to use Tonics.  And the moments that stand out the most is in the start of the game and the end. At the beginning there are posters showing a mark on hand, indicating that the person with that mark is to be arrested or killed on sight. The playable character has that mark on his hand. What does he do? Nothing, just blatantly waltz around with the mark plain in sight. This was so incredibly stupid it left a sour taste in my mouth for the rest of the game.  And what to say about the ending then? Just know that the ending is so unimgainably stupid it made me question the game writers intelligence.

Based on the reviews, I expected to have multiple 'wow' moments during the game - i didn't have one, I didn't actually even have much sense of achievement from completion, or even a section which significantly raised my heart rate! Otherwise Bioshock infintie is a great game, it's just not the game i was expecting from maker of one of best games ever made, it's good but totally different. This game is a disappointment in comparison to the previous ones. If you play mainly for the combat, that might be alright, but there's a few things to note. The game has no manual save; it just uses 'checkpoints' and a resurrection system where you lose stuff. Which is very annoying unless you're so good you never lose, or into frustration and tedium. It has its supporters but there's nothign FORCING you to use a manual save if it's there, and there could be a trophy for completion entirely using checkpoints, if you're in to that sort of thing.  Also, you can only carry two weapons at a time. More realistic perhaps, although some of the heavier ones probably weigh more than two light ones, and you have a completely separate ammo budget for each one. And if you're going for a bit of realism, you'd have to lose the skylines with their seventy-foot leaps and drops altogether.  The plot roars along for a while, but at the end it deteriorates rapidly into a mystic muddle rather like a certain Mass Effect game I might mention, utterly unlike the exemplary plotting of Bioshock one and two.  So I would say the game is diverting, but not worth it at this price. If you are going to play it, probably worth reading a strategy guide along with it.

let's talk about what I enjoyed first: the story is well done here, the art direction is incredible and the music sets the tone so well. As a fan of the previous two Bioshock games from a story perspective this game is icing on the cake but it all falls apart when the shooting starts. While the previous games had you build your own private arsenal of weaponry with all kinds of different ammo types, this game allows you two guns at a time with a single type of ammo for each weapon. The previous games in this series allowed you to administer your own life and energy replinishment items, this is now handled for you automaticallly on pick up or tosseed to you by an AI. Most offensive of all though is the addition of an overshield and regenerating health. These modern conventions took an extreme toll on the core gameplay and as a result his game essentially became Modern Warfare steampunk edition. Additionally, the powers here are mostly retreads of the powers from the previous games and the underutilized skyhook mechanic is a disappointment as well. If you have played the other two Bioshock games I would say play this for the story but otherwise skip this as the gameplay is tailored to the lowest common denominator in the worst possible way.

It took me a long time to finish this game. Not as in many hours, but that I played it half way and then stopped, and didn't have a ton of motiviation to come back to finish it for like a year. Don't get me wrong the overall story is really really good, but it didn't get me hooked enough all the way through the middle, I only came back because several friends told me the ending is really really worth it. And that is pretty much the same thing I would tell you.  So I think the world they've built in Bioshock Infinite is absolutely fantastic. The architecture, people, and whole atmosphere just felt perfect for what they are trying to portray. The art direction in this game is just phenominal. Elizabeth is a wonderful character and every appearance of the Lutece twins were entertaining.  Adam Sessler does a great review of this aspect of the game on youtube using much better words than I can come up with.   My main issue with the game is the combat, the controls are a bit clunky and extended combat felt repetetive. The combat is fun in small doses and there are certain battles in the game that are memorable but overall they felt like hinderances to the next part of the story. Playing around with the different vigor power is fun for the first couple times but you eventually find a combination of power and guns you like. Part of it is that switching between more than 2 vigor powers wasn't very fluid control wise and you can only carry two types of guns. If you ran out of ammo you just improvised on whatever you could pick up. Usually the most effective weapon for an area is available through a tear anyway. If things got overwhelmed you just run around and take cover until Elizabeth offered you full heals, mana, and ammo. Overall the longer battles felt tedious rather than difficult, and I didn't want to switch up the difficulty because I already wanted to get to the next part of the story as fast as I can. Many of the fighting parts of the game also felt jarring to the rest of the story.  But I do have to say, the ending was quite good. And looking back there were a fair number of hints sprinkled throughout the game that supports it. I think the game does great job at creating a sophisticated, immersive world and a intriguing story to discover, interrupted by these less enjoyable combat areas that didn't feel like they quite fit with the narrative trying to be told.

Bioshock Infinite: The review  Bioshock infinite starts off at a lighthouse. It then proceeds up in the skies, where you get greeted by amazing scenery up in the sky.  You will encounter: Hummingbirds, a shinign sun, rose bushes and people who seems to be happy.   You approach a society where racism is more strong than today, it is noticable in the beginning by several posters hanging on the walls, but other than that, everything seems so perfect. The racism part becomes more clear further into the game.   It goes from this Idyllic phase into a dark and more deeper phase. I love the originality of all the enemies and characters, I love the envoirments, I love all the extra-things you can find. Instead of just following a straight line in the game, (from the beginning to the end) you get to find power ups and other secrets.  It is a nice change from being under water to be able to travel around in the sky.   I love how well polished Elizabeth was, it all felt so real somehow.  If you love FPS with fun fighting scenes, great story and plot twists, this game is for you!

A Religious Experience  Bioshock Infinite is one of those games that sticks with you long after you’ve completed it. It’s a compelling experience and a moment of contemplative bliss rarely grasped at so strongly in the gaming medium. And yeah, it’s a lot of fun. It never quite manages to completely coalesce all of its narrative intentions and gameplay conventions in the same way the original so deftly accomplished, but it comes fairly close. A flawed masterpiece, its high minded material soars while its integral gameplay doesn’t seem to be able to get off the ground; so firmly rooted are the mechanics from the original game. Still, it’s fast and fun and if you are interested in a wonderful world, story, and characters, Infinite will not cease to amaze. Colombia is no Rapture, but it’s certainly worth visiting on more than one occasion.

This game plays and feels like a proper FPS...Almost. Some of the control designs could have been improved, but it's not like the controls were downright aweful. So, lets take a look at them. Alright, so we start of with your average controls, wasd to move, shift to spint, ctrl, or c, to crouch, space to jump, f to pick up...Alright, not unheard of, but not usually used, e to switch guns....Ok, that's new, still not complaining. Q to switch vigors, which is also alright. RMB to cast a vigor and Z to aim. What? Look, you should have mapped the vigor swapping to the number buttons only, and had Q to switch guns, E to pick up/interact, F to mele, and V to cast vigors. However, despite this major flaw in control mapping, the game was still fun. You could even hit things while hip-firing, which makes up for the odd Z to aim thing.  So, lets move on to the story. I ♥♥♥♥ing loved it....until I hit the ending. I seriosuly think they got M. Night Shyamalan to write it because they were running out of steam, and the game suffered for it. {{{{{WARNING THERE ARE SPOILERS BEYOND THIS POINT}}}}} So, we start off shrouded in mystery as to where we're going, why we're going there, and who is sending us there. There's no real tutorial, but since the controls are fairly intuitive, you're going to be alright. The game also makes up for a lack of a proper tutorial with giving you little hints throughout the game, which I always find helpful. They also were helpful hints, not those cryptic hints a devloper gives you like 'There seems to be a crack.' or 'Try not to die!' Seriosuly, if you're a devloper that gives useless hints, stop making hints, or stop making games. So we move on to some small amount of character and plot devlopment as we climb the lighthouse. However, when we reach the top, we're presented with a fairly easy puzzle. Once we solve it...Well, now the fun begins! BASHOOOOM! Up and up, higher and higher until....SHIZAM! An entire floating city! A bit religious, which I would have considered alright if it wasn't a massive rip on christianity. (NOTE: I do NOT follow any religion, nor will I ever follow one. However, I don't think it's OK to build a game that jabs a religion as a main element of the plot. We're all free to believe what we want, and so long as we don't try and force others to accept our view as the right view, you're fine. Seriously, don't be a Comstock.) Now that you're in the city blahblahblah, plot devlopment, and then SHAZOOM! You're killing a guy with a fancy new toy that you'll come to love for the rest of the game. Then you get a gun and it's all downhill, or uphill, from there. You're never going to leave this flying city, ever, so get used to it. Sure, you're gonna try, but you're gonna fail. So get used to it. So, as we move on, Booker fights his way to the tower where he liberates its captive, Emily, and then fights his way to an airship where he attmepts to set course for NY and fails due to getting knocked the F**K out by Emily who is livid about being duped. Blahblahbalah, more plot stuff, fighting through a city, VOX, yahddah yahddah. Then you start to learn about how Emily can travle through dimensions and proceed to do so to get your airship back. It's pretty much one incredibly long cresendo of story climaxes with little to no falling action. The ending, of course, follows this and presents you with so many twists you're left confused on what just happened. Basically, let me break down the ending for you. SO. After having fought through so much crap you literally feel unstoppable, that brid-thing just tears you a new one and leaves you thinking 'Oh I did not just fight through hell and hellfire to be stopped by the damn liniar story!' SURPRISE MOTHERF**KER! You just did. So the bird takes Emily back to Comstock and for six months they work on her, which is confusing to the player because you've only been gone for about FIVE HOURS. TOPS. You get to see NY burning, but you're sent back in time to stop it from happening, and so you free Emily, and go to find Comstock. Now, you fight your way through hell and hellfire again to get to Comstock, in which you see he's putting on a show of being a loving father to Emily, which is then dropped as he goes mad and tells Booker to tell Emily what happened to her finger. Are you confused yet? Yeah, there is nothing that really abates this emotion. At all. Ok, so you go over and remove Comstock from Emily thinking 'Alright, yeah! I'll keep him at bay and make sur-...Oh...' And then proceed to watch Booker kill Comstock with no remorse, even while Emily is yelling for him to stop. I'm sorry, what? This is a pivital point of the story and we don't even get to show the ♥♥♥♥er mercy? Just kill a defenseless old man by drowning him? By the way, drowing, Booker has a lot of experience with it. Afterwards, you get attacked by the VOX again, and then you summon the songbird to help you fight them. Alright, yeah. That's actually pretty neat. I seriosuly just didn't want to touch that ♥♥♥♥ because I felt that there was no point after being M. Night Shyamalaned. Seriously, can we get a disclaimer on ALL videogames with a massive plot twist from this point on that says 'There is a massive plot-twist at the end that will leave you very confused.' I'm not a fan of Bioshock, but this one was actually pretty good. I've played a fair bit of Bioshock 1 on the PlayStation 3, but always got bored of it. It was an incredibly dull game. I'm wondering whether that's just part of the console experience after playing Bioshock Infinite on the PC.   It's not a challenging game. It stilll has the repetative elements of Bioshock 1, but just less off them. The levels are well designed for combat, with interesting use of interactive fixtures through tears and rails. The enemy AI is dull, and you won't find them circling around you or making good use of cover. They seem to move along set paths, repeatedly, as in A>B>A>B and will stay in the same spots. So if you fall back for cover or to lure them into a trap, they won't follow.   In contrast to the dull grunts who make up most of your cannon fodder, slightly larger enemies like fireman and handymen deliver a very large amount of damage while soaking up bullets. They're also very mobile, have long range weapons that can pin you down, and will generally be the biggest challanges you'll face.   The story suffers quite a bit. Like in Bioshock 1, when you first start the whole scenario of why you're there just doesn't make sense. I suppose this is to prompt you to explore and enjoy discovering parts of the backstory. Things become more apparant the further you go, but this makes me start out the game with little motivation. I found the ending boring and pointless. I was very disappointed.    Overall, it's a fun, quick game to play when you just want to loose a few bullets to let off steam and relax. It's completely undemanding on normal difficulty, and something you can zone out while playing.

Bioshock Infinite Review  (Story) There's always a chance to make things right. Bioshock Infinite is set in the early 20th century, just before World War I. Rather than a city under the sea, the game takes place in Colombia, a city the floats in the sky. You play as Booker, a Pinkerton agent who finds himself in debt to his superiors. He is given a chance at redemption and sent to Colombia where he must rescue Elizabeth, a girl born with special abilities and subsequently idolized there. Naturally, people do not take kindly to Booker's presence and thus the main conflict is created. As the story unfolds, you discover the origins of the city, learn about people who inhabit it, and discover it's wonders. The plot can be a bit confusing at times so it's important to pay attention. I had to play through the game three times before I understood everything, or at least believed I understood everything.  (Gameplay) Again, Bioshock presents itself as a first person shooter. This time around however, long range combat is just as relevant as close quarters combat. You can only carry two weapons at a time. Weapons can still be upgraded, but the upgrade no longer changes the appearance of the gun. There are only eight vigors (plasmids) for you to use this time around in the base game. You can equip two vigors at a time, switching between one or the other with a hot key. Vigors can be upgraded for efficacy and also charged up for a secondary fire functionality in combat. Combat is not as deep as Bioshock 1 or 2, but it is certainly not boring and can get intense at times. Collectible clothing gives you passive abilities and the tonic system provides you with a rechargeable shield. Health does not recharge, nor do your 'salts', the new Adam. There is not as much to do in between fights. Hacking is gone (though I guess it fits with the time period) and there is little exploration to do. You are presented with choices again since this is Bioshock.   (Design) The detail of this game is incredible. It might be the best looking game I have that runs the Unreal 3 Engine. The sounds and sights are something to behold. Each environment feels different though the music is not as emotional. There were no overlapping sound issues this time around too.  (Final Comments) This game left an impression on me, and there are not many games I say that about. While I consider it a departure from the series, I still highly recommend it based on its design and plot. Your first 30-40 minutes are some of the most memorable you may ever have in a game. The ending ties up the plot nicely and will get you thinking as well. Catch some coins and make the pilgrimmage to Colombia if you can handle the truth.

I can't quite recommend BioShock Infinite. Its technical execution is phenomenal and it is excellently polished in every way and has a number of highlights, but ultimately tries to tell a story in a setting that all have so many contradictions that they don't gel into a coherent experience. The clash between Columbia as a functional society and Columbia as a BioShock-style dystopia of endless combat doesn't really make sense; there's a lot of window-dressing going on that ends up irrelevant. In an effort to be dramatic, or possible to cover all of their angles on the story, the game takes you through a number of plot twists that are extremely arbitrary and seem designed just to make sure that a lot of different dramatic things all happen during the story. It ends with an appeal to time travel to try to either 'blow your mind' or wrap everything together but doesn't really succeed.

From the first battle to the final cutscene, this game is a masterpiece. Though the game itself is fairly short (10 hours at most,) Bioshock combines an unmatched story and solid action with several interesting mechanics (namely, the skyrails.) There are countless items hidden throughout each level which contribute to the story (recordings, movie clips, etc.,) and a few playthroughs are necessary to find everything. The environments have distinct atmospheres down to the background conversations of the NPCs, and the levels stay fairly linear while managing to feel oddly sandbox-like. Definitely worth trying for the story alone; the rest is icing on the cake.

I wont say I was disappointed with Bioshock Infiinite, nor will I say it was in any way a bad game - HOWEVER, in comparison to Bioshock 1 & 2, it certainly appeared lacking in all areas aside from graphics (which of course, being so many years later in production would always be technologically superior)  Whereas BS 1 was named as a spiritual successor to the excellent System Shock series, BSI is more a direct sequelisation despite having amore unique setting and a storyline whioch only touches on its prequels (further development via the expensive, but worthy DLC) This meant an entirely new gaming experiencve, but still held a p[ortion of homage and something recogniseably familiar for those who wanted more Bioshock. However, despite introducing Sklines and the new combat, tactics and movement methods associated with this, the majority of the game itself was little more than a repainting and name changing excercise. Tonics and Eve became Vigors and Salt etc. Although many new weapons were interoduced, the majority of these were effectively either of two factions' particular versions of the same firearm. Minigames such as the hacking were removed altogether and the upgrades to weapons, whilst numerous, seemed to target a more 'preferred weapon' focus. The ability to use tears and scenery props although introducing more of a preferential gameplay style and some embellished tactics, it didn't have the impact for me of a truly innovative addition. The storyline was typically Levine, and darkly risque with some shocking revelations and cutscenes as one would expect, halthough the ending did contradict the premise somewhat (but this is largely irrelevant and a debate which has been discussed enough elsewhere) as with any fictional accounts with certain thematic or plot aspects based on scieentific endeavour there must always be an element of suspension of disbelief and an acceptance of ignoring 'real worlod contradictions' in order to allow the story in the first place, yet the boundaries of the world given in BSI are pushed much further and harder than ever they were in BS1 and 2. I also found the story to be less engaing and intriguing, perhaps due to their being so many motifs and world-elements introduced throughout that whilst making Columbia a larger and more complex world than Rapture, it also alienated any real morality and reality from the main characters encountered to an extent in which there was little true empathy or sympathies invoked. In all, I think I found the game just had less gameplay substance than the likes of BS 1 and 2, but perhaps this may be due to changing trends in videogames overall and the demands of the console market consumers. This 'review' has been a lot more of a comparison between BSI and its prequels combined with my expectations. Whilst this may have lead to any objectivity being forcibly redundant, I believe that most playing this for the first time whill have also previously enjoyed BS1 at least and maybe also BS2. At the end of the day, I certainly enjoyed playing BSI and it still deserves a replay in the near future.

Ah, Bioshock... I never really got into the first two installments of the game. Being from the 'old school' sci-fi System Shock 2, going backwards never really worked for me, but I could see the appeal. However, the steampunk-ish look of Infinite was appealing, not to mention colourful (unlike the first two, which were mostly blue and green, which got old fast). And colourful is it ever!  Graphics aside, the game is a rather standard shooter - nothing has been reinvented here. It's very linear, very straightforward; had it held your hand any more than it did, I'd have called it a rail shooter. But the gameplay is solid and certainly fun.  However, the shooting aspect is not why you play this game. The narrative is what really keeps you going. I can't praise the writing of this game enough. It is convoluted at times, but it makes sense... in an odd, screwed-up sort of way. And hopefully opens the door to many more iterations within this universe.  Long story made short, it's a really awesome game. However, worth at most 20$ as the game can be rather... short. You may be looking into Bioshock Infinite because you liked Bioshock. That's understandable, Bioshock was a masterpeice, however Bio-Infinite is not quite like Bioshock.   It's not BETTER, not WORSE, but very different... it is this difference that has allowed it to grow into something which is equally fantastic. You won't get quite the same experience, indeed the gunplay is vastly different for a variety of reasons. But if you are willing to except change then Bio-Infinite is a fun ride.  The gameplay is challenging... encounters with even minor enemies are deadly if you are not careful, and major ememies are a particular challenge. Yet no section is impossible if you know what you are doing and change up your tactics a wee bit. Victory is very satisfying because of this challenge. Bio-Infinite does not ♥♥♥♥ around.  The story can be hard to wrap your mind around, but I think it was pulled off quite well. Additionally, your 'sidekick' (whom the story revolves around, and thus why I hesitate to call her a 'sidekick') is one of the more believable and human-seeming characters in gaming.   And besides looking good, the game runs amazingly. I only have the minimum requirements and I have no problems whatsoever running the game. Seriously, smooth as butter.  So, if you like well-crafted singleplayer experiences with good stories and gameplay, buy this and support games like this! Even if you don't, buy it anyway! It's a blast!

Just bought this game during the Autumn sale last week as it was too good a deal to resist.  Now, just finished playthrough and I was immersed in the story from beginning to end. Exploring EVERYWHERE gave real depth to the world with the aid of voxaphones, conversations and general background. Don't just blitz through the game if you want full storyline value as I imagine you will quickly become confused by what is happening. Note: This isn't a completely 'open' world, so you won't get too sidetracked going through all the doors on your journey forward. I found myself making sure I went everywhere the game was NOT trying to get me to go before I would move forward.  The graphics were well polished for the most part - I had them set on high which caused a bit of stuttering upon entering some new areas, but overall very smooth despite my system being on the old side.  The actual gameplay which was interspersed with the story was relatively generic FPS. Set the difficulty higher for a greater challenge and use of strategy, or lower if you want to have fun messing around with vigor/combat combos. Doesn't matter as the storyline was really the main focus for me in this game.  A note on autosaving: I have seen a few comments complaining about the lack of save feature in this game. I get what the game is going for here though: They want you to face the consequences of death (loss of a bit of money and small health regen of enemies) rather than have you quicksave right before facing a harder battle. It's a bit annoying for real world timing trying to figure out if you will be able to quit the game in the next 5 minutes or not, but as long as you pay attention to when it is saving (rotating circle in the corner) or when it tells you the time your last quicksave was before you quit, there shouldn't be any nasty surprises when you log in again to find you lost 20 minutes of progress.  Lots of fun - will definitely have to play again in 1999 mode once I've worked my way through other games =/.
