This review is after I have beaten the game multiple times, read up on the lore of the game, watched other people's gameplay and various commentary on the story. I have had this game since it came out.  This game was over hyped by far. The hype is the biggest problem I find surrounding the game. The game play is average at best. The story telling is phenomenal, though the story itself is shoddy. Other than the hype, the game is decent.  The only thing this game had that was good was the art style, game sounds, and presentation. Otherwise everything else was just pure hype. The story took a turn, but it was only shocking because it makes no sense and is irrational. The way the game presented the story was great, but the story itself was weak and full of Deus ex machina at every turn. The story just has too many plot holes, and it just expects you to go along with everything without questioning what is happening. Its exactly like the Lutece's quote 'The mind of the subject will desperately struggle to create memories where none exist…'. People desperately try to make sense of the story despite the fact that it doesn't make sense.   The game's themes were really nice and atmospheric. The whole hype about how 'deep' game was due to its biblical/nationalism/racism/sexist themes and stuff was just pure fluff. The game was rather intellectually shallow. They used the themes extremely well but the game offered no real thought or commentary into these matters. Of course it probably seemed deep to the people who are woefully ignorant of history and politics. Don't get what I am saying wrong. The game make great use of these things, and made it seem extremely authentic. Its just not deep or thought provoking as all the unintellectually sheltered people would make you think it is.  The game play was woefully stale. Generic FPS game play with no innovation. Difficulty levels don't do anything other than make the enemies tank a few more bullets, and hit a bit harder. Enemy AI never posed a real threat other than the Handy Mans, Firemen, and Zealot guys... but they weren't so much of a threat because they were good enemies, they were just bullet sponges that hit very hard. I never really felt the need to do anything in this game but just stand in place and just blast everything that came my way. Never really needed to take cover, move around etc against most of the enemies. Not only is the enemy AI overwhelming boring, there isn't even enough enemies to kill to even enjoy a fire fight due to how dumb they are.  My other gripes are the fact that you can't actually pick up and store anything that you find around the world. Trash can with money but I can't pick up the money due to the fact that there is a valuable medic kit in there... because you simply can't only pick up one thing. Everything you find is instantly consumed if you chose to pick it up. The game also ruins the sense of immersion in other little ways like for instance if you use the possession vigor on vending machines, you see it pop out like 20 silver eagles, but when you actually pick it up ends up being only like 1 to 3 silver eagles. Also possession is a useful vigor, but I hate how it constantly gives you the 'Don't Attack Allies' message, and reduces the damage you do to what you posses by like 95%. So if you posses something that is hard to kill, after the vigor wears of its still very hard to kill if you're not willing to waste all your ammo trying to kill what you possessed when its under your control. Not to mention the abominable auto save function. If they wanted to only let you save at certain points, then that is fine as long as they let us manually save at those points... but instead this game auto saves for you and overwrites your previous play throughs. Not to mention how far and in between the save points are.  So yeah the game has great story telling which I would recommend, but the game play isn't worthy of a recommendation. So what I would do if you wanted to just see the story is just go on youtube and watch a youtube video where someone spliced all the important parts together into a Bioshock Infinite Movie. That way you save your time and your money.  Overall the game is just a generic FPS game in term of game play. Pretty sub par in my opinion. The game has more story telling/theatrical value than actual game play. The game play is playable... just not very fun. The plot line is Deus ex machina, pseudo-science to the max, but the story telling is great.

The Combat: 7/10 The combat in this game can either be really fun or really frustating. Most of the weapons are decent, but only being able to carry two means you've got to really plan ahead. Ammo runs out very fast and before you know it, you find yourself using whats left of your vigors or trying to melee which usually doesn't go very smoothly. The shield is a nice addition, but you can only use health packs. No carrying spare health packs or vigor bottles. The vigors are somewhat fun to use, but not as much as the other games. However, I like the early vigors/plasmids. My favorites were shock jockey (electricity), return to sender (basically telekinisis i think i spelled that wrong), and possession (only used to get money from vending machines lol). The others were cool but definitely went underused due to them being somewhat underpowered. The enemies are fun to kill, especially with the sky hook ('OH my God!' Elizabeth voice*). However, the boss battles are more frustrating than fun. I won't spoil anything, but people who played the game know exactly what I'm talking about. The weapons lacked in variety and were missing the visual/cosmetic upgrades that the other games head (i'm obsessed with customization and vaierty), but I still enjoyed getting important upgrades like extended mags/clips.  Graphics/Visual Style: 9/10 Visually this game is amazing. Its a very styled (but not cartoony) world and the aesthetics feel very real (for that time period, I was there, I should know).  Audio/Dialoque & Voice Acting/Music: 9/10 Now before I didn't like the voice acting this game has. The voice acting sounds like a script for a Hollywood version of an amazing book. Some of the story is very rushed. However, I will not deny that the voice actors are still incredible and skilled so i will give them their props as it still felt like it was coming from a movie and not a voice actor wearing headphones are reading a script (fallout:new vegas matthew perry *COUGH*). The dialogue is still great, it just has too many cliche things, although that doesn't always mean bad, just a tad overused. The score is very well done. The loading screen song that plays is stuck in my head and I immediately recognized it when I was watching The Sting the other day. Everything fits very well.  The Story: 7/10 While the story starts out very interesting and engaging, when it's over, you feel like there's a big chunk you missed. The clues and twists are very rushed and teased in your face almost instantly. I think that they were rushed to release this considering the number of times it was delayed in the past. I would take a delayed game that was worth the wait over a rushed game any day, just like basically every gamer out there. Take your time developers. Anyways, decent story, but really short.  All in all, I think you should play this game.  Overall: 8/10

I've mentioned in my review for the first Bioshock that I'm a huge fan of the series; it's one of my favorite games honestly. So after 1 and 2, I was super pumped to play Infinite, and I am not in the least disappointed.  As Bioshock is a narrative shooter, much was expected of Infinite's story, and BOY DID IT DELIVER. The story is extremely well written and layered, with great use of twists and symbols galore. The characters also felt real, rounded, and furnished, I loved them. This game pioneers video games as an art form.  One common complaint in Bioshock 2 is that Rapture had outstayed its welcome, and was awesome, but less awesome than the first time. Ken Levine certainly kept that in mind while developing this game. The city of Columbia is amazingly new and beautiful, and I found myself taking screenshots left and right. It felt to me, though, that the environment was less of a weapon in this one. But the skylines and open areas made up for that change.  The combat is the best of all the Bioshock games. I had a lot of fun using Vigors and shooting people in the face, and aiming down my sights was convenient and useful. Infinite plays more like a straightforward shooter than the other two, although that is not at all bad.  Infinite was also the most well optimized of all three games on Steam, I had no issues running the game whatsoever.  I would recommend this game to people who have played the first two games or even people new to the series; it is an experience like no other.

Ok, so finally came around to complete this game.  Bioshock Infinite, created by the same people that made the first game, the story takes place in a city in the skies, I won't explain much of the story itself, most people already know the setting of this game.  In BioShock Infinite, you spend most of your time in the flying city Columbia. It is an very well designed city, with alot of stuff going on there, and it feels like a real city. The only downside is that it's not as open as I would have wished for. There is side missions, and stuff to look for and extra places to visit, but the game itself is pretty linear, so there is unfortunatly not much to explore of the city itself. The side-missions, I do have a problem with. Most of them includes backtracking, but the fustraiting part is that you don't really get a clear indicator of where you have to go, or where the side-mission is, there's no waypointer, or map location, you have to backtrack and blindly look for it.  The graphics in this game is good. It's very pretty in it's own style, Dx11 effects, it bears the Bioshock style, but it COULD, have maybe been a tad better on some areas, but still, the graphics are good.  The gameplay is fun, it has alot of action, and experimenting with all the different 'powers' you find through out the game, few weapon choises, well, technically there are a fine number of weapons, but many of them are 'super' versions of each other. The skyrails brings with it some fun tactical advantages you can use during battles, and combining it with weapons and your 'powers', it's a fast phased fun gameplay.  The only complaint, is that when you die, you respawn, with half health and with the same ammo you had when you died, so if you died with no ammo, you'll respawn with little health and no ammo (or almost no ammo), but the enemies you failed to kill before you died, will regain some health, so if you died because you ran out of ammo, you will respawn close to where you died, with little health and no ammo, while the enemy has regained some health. So this brings up some fustraiting situations which at times might seem like a paradox and impossible to progress through.  The story of Infinite... Here I really can't say much, but the story manages to capture your interest, it is one of the main things making you want to see how it all ends and see the final conclution. But there are some aspects of the story that, after you've completed, you'll think 'Why did I have to do that? What purpose do this serve?'. So some 'side' stories that don't really have much to do with the main story can feel like something put in there to make the game longer.  But the ending is a cluster ♥♥♥♥ of plot twists and surprizes. A true Bioshock ending. It is one of the most suprising endings I have seen in a long time, and it's really worth playing this game because of it.  But I do advice, the story of Bioshock Infinite do have alot of elements from Quantum Physics/Mechanics, so if you really want to understand the ending, go read up on Quantum mind ♥♥♥♥ first.  ---SCORE---  Graphics: 8.5/10 Audio: 8.0/10 Gameplay: 8.0/10 Story: 9.0/10 Value: 7.0/10  Score: 8.1/10

Contains no spoilers.  Not at all what I expected. In many ways, much more and in others much less. 2k took a risk by catapulting you from the bottom of the ocean to above the clouds, and I must say that after some skepticism, I am glad they did.   Actionwise this game also took a big step forward and managed to make the mobfights a lot more interesting, faster and desperate. A wider arrange of weapons than in the first two games, limited by the fact that you can only carry two at the time (no changeable ammunition like in the second game, though I don't miss that at all). At first I was kind of annoyed by that fact, but the game managed to integrate that in a manner that made it much more smooth and realistic than it was ever before.   AI-wise you may not see a big difference in comparison to the first two games, but companionwise they took it to a whole nother level. Elizabeth is one of the few companions (much like Alyx from Half-Life) whose company I genuinley enjoyed and who I found, is pretty much irreplaceable in fights. She brings a whole new dynamic to it, while staying independent at the same time, somehting that I wish more developers put into thought when creating female characters. It might sound ridiculous, though I guess that people on a gaming platform such as this will understand, but in the course of this, admittedly, short 10 hour adventure (hardcore mode and a second playthrough to discover everything I missed not included) I really started to care for her and her story.  Columbia itself was a little bit to superficial for me, leaving me with a lot of questions. There's an ongoing fight between two groups, inspired by political uproars and racial segregation. I don't know why, but to be honest, amidst all the fighting and the main story you try to understand I....didn't really care. I don't consider myself an insensitive person, not at all, but it felt kind of out of place, though it fits the time setting (tough to explain). There's also the handymen,  who...What?  Why? How? Columbia is cleaner and happier than Rapture (no suprise there) and the chilly, angsty atmosphere from before is replaced by 60's charme and steampunk metal horses.  The story might be a bit confusing at first, assembling itself mostly from made up theories through voice recordings, though they didn't have the grim charme I remembered from before, but in the end everything fits together in a way that'll make you gaping at your screen.  TL;DR: I hesitated with this one, because there are a lot of changes one might disagree with if they played the first two parts. Try it. You might be suprised at how much you won't miss Rapture at all.

Bioshock infinite is an amazing fps and is a must-play game.   Graphics- The graphics are not realistic, however, they are designed in a pretty and colorful way. It feels alive and there's amazing atmoshpere to it. Even if it's not realistic it's still easy to know what is being seen and not you won't be left wondering what is on screen. The framerate is never below 60fps and will sometimes climb to 100. That just makes the experience better.  Sound- Beautiful. The sound has people conversating, yelling, insulting, singing, mechanics working, guns shooting, bells ringing, and there's a very high level of voice acting to express emotion. There is battle music but it's the sam one for every battle scene save for a few final battles. It is tolerable at the least.  Layout- More focussed but not linear. There ares still different paths to take and alternatives routes. It's not rapture layout but it doesn't entirely take away the bioshock feel to it.  A.I.- The enemies have varieties such as runnning up and hitting, sniping or shooting with guns behind cover. Even when there's A.I vs A.I, both sides act like they're fighting the player. Some enemies use vigors and even skyrails.  Vigors- Theres a total of 8 vigors and they all help out. There are specific areas where they can be very helpful, especially with elizabeth and some vigors alone are good against bosses. Like using crows to get a chance to get some distance from the handyman.  Skyhook- The skyhook is impressive. There's certain areas where the hook is essential to reaching supplies or circling around enemies. Since you can wield a gun while using the skyhook and control your velocity, you can really make manuvers in an area. It's also fun to punch people with it. Of course, it's doesn't always make it easy kill weapon since when doing air strikes on heavy armor enemies won't kill them and the handiman can make it where being on the rails will hurt/kill you.  Guns- You can only hold two like in C.O.D but there are upgrades and abilities to pick up/buy ammo. And with elizabeth's help, when running low on ammo, she'll give you more letting you continue shooting. There's also a large variety to use and each one has a unique purpose.  Elizabeth- Most helpful companion. She has real expression and emotion. And during battle, she is so incredibly helpful that when she's not with you, you will wish she was. Plus, the tears are the best since if certain ones don't kill the enemies, it will distract them long enough for you to attack them.  Story- Mind blowing. Of all the stories I've known, This is a combination of plot twist, surprising, amazing and saddening. This is like the F.E.A.R series where, if you don't pay attention you will be confused.  Fianl rating 9.5/10. My only gripe is the same battle sound, but that didn't stop me from enjoying it and playing it again 4 times.

I played both the previous Bioshock games on XBOX 360 and decided to pick this one up on Steam. All three games in the series are absolutely fantastic! I often bemoan the lack of complex storytelling and believable characters in modern games, particularly first person action games, but this series absolutely excels in weaving a believable yet fantastical world populated with wonderful characters and with its own unique, beautiful aesthetic.  This third iteration has a very different setting to the previous two subaquatic worlds, as it is set in the floating city of Columbia. I don't want to give any of the plot away, as it is a joy to experience; suffice to say, Elizabeth is now one of my favourite ever characters in a game. I really felt myself caring about her and wanting DeWitt to be the hero. Of course, nothing is quite as it seems in Bioshock... the ending has a great twist, which I'd partly anticipated, but not in quite the way it eventually went down! The 20 minutes or so leading up to the finale is really trippy, riffing on multiverse theory in a really cool way.  My only minor criticism might be that the combat can feel a little clunky at times, but I could definitely overlook that given how fantastic it is overall. At 16 hours to complete the game on my first playthrough, during which I explored every nook and cranny of each area, I'd say it's not exactly the longest game ever either; but I'll take this kind of quality over quantity any day!  If you love games with bags of character and are looking for a plot which will suck you in, you have to buy this game!

I want to hate Bioshock Infinite. Gameplay-wise Infinite is two large steps backward from 2 and 1. The two-weapon loadout is directly at odds with combat design that still calls for managing your limited health, ammo, and (basically) magic resources in battles that often involve a significant number of high-health enemies. It's not uncommon to fight mechanized bullet-sponges who will burn through your bullets far too easily unless you have an explosive-thrower taking up a slot (and that's even when compensating for any limitations in your arsenal with magic). Combat is simultaneously broken and generic, and this is most obvious when you try to do something interesting with your weapon loadout or are separated from the excessive health drops and the item-dispenser named 'Elizabeth' (her role in combat really isn't more than a crutch for broken design).  However, Infinite easily has the most compelling world when compared to the 2 previous games. Bioshock 1 was good, but the lack of opportunity to see the world in a coherent state (before the fall of sanity) made the denizens of the underwater world about as interesting as gibbering monkeys can be. Bioshock 2 was all about the gameplay; development of the world relied too heavily on the first game and the main villain seemed out of place. Infinite gives players the opportunity to see more of the people of its world, and is all the more compelling for it.  The writing of Infinite isn't perfect. A few too many fights felt like pointless set-ups to waste the players time. The ending itself was poorly thought out. However, almost every other aspect of the story telling for this game is of a quality I don't think I've ever seen before in a game. It's worth experiencing.

The outlook wasn't brilliant for poor Booker D. that night, While sitting in a lifeboat, with the lighthouse gleaming bright; And when the rowers vanished, and the surface did the same, A sickly silence fell upon the hero of this game.  And in the rocket pod he sat, bewildered,yet impressed, As he drifted past the Monument, and as 'pilgrim' was addressed; He thought, though much befuddled, 'I can swing this rescue yet -  Bringing them the girl, to wipe away the debt.'   But Booker's fame preceded him, as did the prophet's hate;  And the former was a mystery, and the latter was his fate. So upon our calm protagonist, grim melancholy lay, As he wandered through Columbia, one pleasant summer's day.  For there were weird anomalies, awaiting on this trip: An odd predictive telegram, and a coin that he must flip; When he came upon the fairground, a baseball in his grasp, The telegram proved Prophetic, and the 'Shepherd' was entrapped.   The policemen sent to fetch him, though, emerged in fearful shape, As DeWitt procured his skyhook in a bloody quick escape; He killed the hothead fireman, and the soldiers' onslaught checked, As the presence of the Shepherd began to have a mass effect.   And he struck a blow for freedom, put the Ravens in their place, Stole Lizzie from the statue, with a grimace on his face, Endured the propaganda, so veiled and ornate, And in the halls of history, found cause to clean his Slate.  Ten thousand Founders fought him, and found that fighting hurts; Ten thousand Vox applauded him in another universe. Fitzroy had incited them, the Prophet's rule to end, And Comstock wouldn't tolerate this Columbian-mocha blend.  For now the Vox Rebellion was heady in the air, As Booker and Elizabeth chased gunsmiths through the tears; He found himself a martyr, the rebels’ hero dead; 'That ain't my style,' said Booker, as in a blimp he fled.  From the working town of Finkton, though, the city fell to storm;  And through Emporia's empty streets, a trail of blood was worn. A strange and spectrous spectacle was born from daughter's hate -  And through the touch of mother's hand, they opened Comstock's gate.  Our hero passed through time and space, by silent boys forlorn, And through the future's meddling, a self from past was warned; One mountain drowned in fire; one spared from Prophet's rage -  And the note was found to be the key to break the Songbird's CAGE.   The bird succumbed to atmosphere, as was his destiny, As the pair both stood enraptured, in the city beneath the sea; They saw the timestreams branching through a million lighthouse doors, In a world most Irrational, where futures are restored.  But the memories stored in Booker's mind were all subject to change, In this universal chess game that the physicists arranged; For to save himself and Anna, a destiny is faced -  And at the river delta, his parallels erased.  Oh, somewhere in the multiverse, the stars are twinkling bright, And Jack is fighting Atlas, 'mid Rapture's neon lights, And always there's a city, where twin Luteces pout; But there is no more Columbia...  ... for mighty Comstock was struck out.   - ZeroKelvin & Ernest Thayer

After countless debates in the industry concerning whether or not video games can be considered art, Bioshock: Infinite has come along to silence them. An accomplishment in story telling and the crafting of a world so imaginative in terms of originality and intrigue, it should rest proudly amongst any collection of games (along with the original Bioshock) as the ending to a series of pointless arguments. Not many games can be considered as such, but this one can hold its head up high and know it’s definitively so.  A rather grand departure from Rapture, Columbia is beautiful, sunny and filled with racist albeit, happy people. Rapture was a special place too but it was a deserted wasteland at the bottom of the sea, littered with as many ideals as bodies. A complete shift in atmosphere, Infinite trades dark, lonely and claustrophobic for an effulgent and spacious place with a creepy sense of community. The micro-interactions you encounter with the hundreds of lively people walking around and chatting about Columbia are mind blowing when recalling the hours spent alone in the corridors of Andrew Ryan’s sunken utopia.  There’s a moment for everyone with a pulse. Maybe it’s when the wind pushes a lonely beach umbrella across the sand or even one as obvious as when the doors open, exposing a sprawling and floating city landscape. Regardless of how or when, it will come and when it does, it will devastate you. After all, Columbia feels lighter than air.  A man with a debt is barely a man at all. Desperate for the opportunity to escape his burden, Booker Dewitt takes a less than favorable job, his deal: “Bring us the girl, wipe away the debt”. Before he knows it, he’s on a boat in the middle of the ocean. A lighthouse stands cloaked in solace, a storm rages above. The darken clouds scream and weep at his arrival. Atop a chair awaits, whisking him above the angry effervescence to the gleam of perfect blue skies and sunshine.  A somber yet delightful patter of keys roll over, a tune of emptiness plays as he floats down upon the city of Columbia, a place that itself is made of more empty spaces than concrete or brick. A burgh gliding all around the world, a shining example of American exceptionalism, powered by the word and will of demagogue Zachary Hale Comstock. His title of “Prophet” is a dangerous one, every time his visions come true his following grows in size and belief. Subsequently, they perceive Comstock’s prejudice as yet another prophecy.  As Jeremiah Fink tells us in relation to all this “prophecy business”, belief is a commodity. It’s apparent just how popular a product it is to the people of Columbia when it’s plastered on every wall, hanging from every ledge and shouted from the voice of every citizen standing at street’s corner. Comstock knows he won’t be around forever the same way he knows belief isn’t cheap, so he’s planting seeds that will influence them to follow another. “The seed of the Prophet shall sit the throne and drown in flame, the mountains of man.”  Elizabeth like any Disney princess is beautiful, clever and highly capable. Years spent locked away from a city that desperately needed her haven’t been wasted. She prides herself on knowing a great bit from all she’s read. Among those piles of books and the heaps of knowledge she ascertained, she’s read enough about lock picking to pick any door in Columbia. Coupled with her ability to create tears into reality, which allow Booker to select a tactical option on the battlefield, whether it be an automated turret or a weapon or a med kit, she is an incendiary addition to your already stunning arsenal.  As for your arsenal, it’s very punchy. Every vigor is colorful and brimming with power. Every weapon is finely tuned and accurate, all while delivering that explosive punch. The weapons aren’t overly original, mostly following the familiar tropes of shotgun, rifle, machine gun and RPG, but it was clear the intention was that originality be left to the vigors. The guns are the constants and the vigors are the variables. Coupling variables can be awfully fun, whether it be the lifting powers of bucking bronco and devil’s kiss exploding them mid-air or activating return to sender’s shield and going to town against some founders with undertow, blasting them off many ledges or knocking them down with the sole intent of purchasing more time to re-activate your shield, the combat is pure and fun though hardly the selling point of Bioshock: Infinite.  Anyone who came expecting a revolution to First Person shooters will be greatly disappointed and while grinding against sky-rails, firing upon deserving enemies can be seen as revolutionary, the true revolution of Bioshock: Infinite is it’s story. Nothing here feels like game filler, if you lose a character or the figurative ground you were standing on crumbles, it feels earned. The only derailment that occurs is whenever Booker detaches from a sky-rail, hanging over his destination.  Stunning visuals, an excellent cast of characters and an intensely arresting concept are the recipe for most great pieces of art and Infinite is no different. Not every video game is art, the same way not every movie or book is; the only difference is that in this medium, the occurrence of art is a lot less common. Which makes Infinite a welcome sight. Floating just out of the reach of perfection, Bioshock: Infinite tells a grand and masterful tale with greater consistency than the original. Columbia may seem far away to most but to any true gamer, a charter will always remain a permanent fixture inside their heart.

The third entry in the BioShock series goes from sea to sky, exploring the airborne city of Columbia. Many of Infinite's basic story elements will be familiar to series veterans - a protagonist in over his head, a high-tech city led by an enigmatic man, a utopia rotting from within. Game elements will also be familiar to many; the Plasmids of Rapture are reimagined as Vigors, character-enhancing Gene Tonics are now pieces of clothing called Gear, and vending machines dot every corner of Columbia. Without spoiling any major plot elements, Infinite's story starts off a little more hard-hitting than its predecessors and only gets moreso the farther you get into the game; the big reveals at the end are at the same time obvious and unexpected.  Gameplay-wise, Infinite is somewhat more modernized that its predecessors. Your melee weapon is built-in, and you can only carry two guns at once, and the game expects you to swap out frequently rather than hang on to one or two. This unfortunately doesn't play well with the game's weapon upgrading system, forcing you to think carefully about which guns to spend money on. Large, open areas combined with a shield system makes combat more about quick, localized firefights than the brutal melees of Rapture. Alternate ammunition and hacking are both gone entirely.  Ultimately I came away from the game feeling almost like Irrational Games had too many ideas to really fit smoothly in one game, and ended up trying to make it work with a handful - the game was rebuilt in development several times, and it shows. While I don't feel like it hits the same peak the first BioShock did, Infinite certainly isn't a bad game. The turn-of-the-20th-century aesthetic makes Columbia both nostalgic and beautiful, and the shortcomings aren't so bad that I didn't enjoy playing.

For the most part,  Infinite  does not disappoint. The gameplay takes a cue from Bioshock 2 and doesn't turn power use into a chore. The writing is more consistent without an entire act of the game being filler.   Infinite's  own worst enemy is itself. Elizabeth is an extremely compelling character but anyone who saw the previews was waiting for her to start helping directly in battle, only to be disappointed. It's a shame that so much effort went into her and the end result is little more than item retrieval and scripted environmental effects. Having her actually tag along with Booker so she can progress as naturally through the story as he does is amazing in its own right, but in gameplay she falls flat. As simpler as it was, calling Eleanor to my side in  Bioshock 2,  basically summoning the game'srecurring miniboss flagged as friendly, felt far more satisfying. Also, why have we gone to a two-weapon system? I find it hard to believe Ken Levine looked at the last two games' inventories and said 'Needs more  Halo, ' yet here we are.  Elizabeth may fall flat in gameplay, but it's a joy to have her around for the entire game simply because she's a brilliantly realized character. Her interaction with Booker feels natural. The Lutece twins also steal the show whenever they show up.  While the writing doesn't have the first game's pacing problems, it has an entirely  different  pacing problem; the ending is incredibly rushed. The vague nuances of it that have seen so much discussion is really the result of this, not the result of actual depth. The ending is obtuse for the sake of being obtuse. At a certain point, the ending stops being about the characters and starts being about how long the characters can talk about quantum mechanics. Additionally, the setting and the conflict set up is very quickly thrown into the background, given only cursory relevance as an obstacle preventing Elizabeth and Booker from leaving Columbia. American exceptionalism is never explored beyond the fact that Comstock is absolutely crazypants nanners. The KKK substitute that one will spend all of ten minutes seeing seems shoehorned in. This isn't just dissapointing for players who kept up with the game's development, it's just sloppy storytelling. As a fan of the first bioshock, I was fairly disappointed with this game. It starts off very promising, the visuals are great with a few set pieces that really give the environment character. The story seems to be leading towards a certain direction until you finally meet elizabeth. From there the story takes a bit of turn. From then on the story becomes more and more convoluted, until the game finally ends. It seems as if the writers thought a baffling ending meant a good ending. All the while the gameplay begins to feel like more of a chore than fun. there are only a handful of unique enemies that are sparsely used throughout, making each fight feel like the last. Though the vigors and the rail system add a bit of diversity, they really cant overcome the rinse and repeat feel of the encounters. Meanwhile elizabeths special power seems very underutilised.   For being able to tear through time, space, and alternate realities   all she provides for you is extra ammo, and a friendly turret here and there. Even in terms of the story, elizabeths power is mainly used to skip over events. I felt that this was a very lazy move on part of the writers. Rather than have the player achieve their goal, the writers say   'elizabeth tears into an alternate reality! so now you dont have to do this objective! Because that would be totally boring, right?'   Overall the game is fairly mediocre. It begins with such promise and then stumbles and falls until the credits roll.

In this modern age of gaming, there is nothing sadder to me than being forced to pull out a gun and shoot someone in the face that you'd much rather have a conversation with. Such was the case with Bioshock Infinite.  The world immediately grabs you and immerses you in a bold and unforgiving story of betrayal, power seeking, delusions of grandeur, and denial. It's beautiful, and I expect nothing less from Levine, as his writing is always poignant. Where the game takes an odd turn, is the moment you pull out your gun and are forced to start shooting people. There are no real options for avoidance or stealth, it's just a one man (and one woman) murder spree from that point until the end.  The mechanics of shooting are fine, the weapons are interesting though you'll probably pick one or two favorites and stick with them until you run out of ammo. The vigors (their magic system) is also interesting, but again you'll likely pick one or two that works, though I implore you to experiment with combinations, as there are some interesting ones (FLAMING CROWS). That said, there's not a lot of innovation here from the standpoint of what has come before, and why would there be? The market has been flooded with FPS games for the last 10 years.  But it's worth it... Even as you grow tired of shooting people in the face, the story still draws you in. Your partner throughout, the efervescent Elizabeth brings so much character and emotion, as does your own character, Booker Dewitt, that you just can't wait to get to the next scrap of dialogue. It's immersive, and though punctuated by a lot of seemingly needless violence (like, seriously, if Booker had just talked things out with a few of the main 'bad guy' characters, I think they could have worked something out), it's worth playing all the way to the tragic end.

It's like BioShock candy, after the sirloin of BioShock 1 and t-bone steak of BioShock 2. - Feels shorter, but way less grindy as each new area is pretty unique. - Story is linear (not as open-worldy) which helps keep you from ever getting lost (there's even a 'which way do I go?' button you can spam). - Completely fresh plot (alternate history with an imperialist tongue-in-cheek christian america) makes the game worth the money. - In-game companion (and the whole plot) makes the game enjoyable. - Can only carry two guns at a time, but the ammo pool is persistent. It's fine. - Plasmids replaced with tonics (and are not responsible for the chaos of the world), you could almost avoid using them. - New enemies, flying around using skylines (and killing things while doing it), occasional custscenes, and a few interesting collectibles really flesh out the game. - You do not need to have played the earlier games to enjoy this one. You would probably enjoy BioShock 2 after playing it, but BioShock 1 might feel like a bit of a downgrade from a gameplay standpoint. - It's not a tough game on normal.  Bottom Line: I'd value the at about $30, yet it looks like you can do much better in the next big sale.

BioShock Infinite is a decent addition to decent series. Ambitious in its plot and beautiful in its graphics, Infinite is a game that is simoultaneously fun to play and wonderful to look at. Gameplay and mechanics are very similar to the previous Bioshock games, with the addition of the Skyhook, which opens up a new oppurtunity for diverse tactics. The game is heavily linear, and features a (optional) quest direction indicator line, which holds your hand as you play through the story and keeps on track. Those who are fans of the linear style of Metro Last Light would enjoy this game (however, the aesthetic is the opposite of MLL). The plot combines political and personal intrigue with science-fiction and quantum mechanics in an ambitious and entertaining story that false just short of making sense. At times, the concepts left me wondering what the hell was going on, and distracted from the otherwise enjoyable experience. Ultimately, Bioshock Infinite is a solid game with an interesting, if confusing, plot and gorgeous graphics. If you are looking for a linear experience with familiar FPS gameplay, Bioshock Infinite will not dissapoint.

+Summary at End+  So I finally used a weekend to play this after waiting for it to go on sale (caught it at the $15 price) and see what the game was about after all the hype died down, which just took about 4-6 months after release.  The visuals are appealing from a distance, the game uses a cartoon appearance to compensate graphical prowess, something I'd relate to how Warcraft handles it's visuals to keep them from being too dated. The sounds are good, nice and authentic and you don't really tire of hearing or seeing anything.  Visually it's a great game. But that's all I can see it as.  The gameplay is really uninspired. This seems to be what I hear the most complaints about and its true, you're given limited choices in what to improve and you have a large array of weapons and abilities but often you're limited to rock, paper, scissor decision making. Did you bring A with you to fight D? No? Then you'll have a more drawn out battle. Death isn't a factor due to the many checkpoints and revives (when a certain NPC is with you) and the skyhook just felt more like a nuisance than a godsend. I barely used in my playthrough.  Speaking of playthrough, it's a long game, longer than I thought. But in this case it's not a good thing. The game has you back tracking a lot, and if you do the side quests you'll be going through the same areas again and again with respawning enemies. The enemies aren't fun to fight, they quickly begin to be tediuous. Tie in the fact that the only way the game is saved is through checkpoints so you'd better stop playing after a checkpoint or you're going to have to do the whole level again.  So, gameplay could have stood to have a lot of improvement but it's at least decent. If I had to talk about the companion character it's really shallow as well, the game would have been fine without them and their scritped and proximity events (giving items) get old quickly.  Now, on to the elephant in the room, the story. The first part of the game there really isn't much story, all barebones, in fact throughout the game theres barely anything, if you get collectibles it fills in the gap but at face value they really give you the minimum. There's a name to that style that eludes me but given how the gameplay is they've used what they've been given. For all the 'twists and turns' that get thrown at you I found the story to be predictable save one bit at the end that really ended up being a dues ex machina by the writer. During the last few hours (the ending is really really really drawn out and it isn't in a good way in my opinion) I struggled to stay interested, mainly trugging through it because I'd be finished soon and could remove the game from my library. It's much how I felt during most of my playthrough, the parts that were entertaining kept me but those are few and far between. There's just too much filler in this game.  In closing, it's a decent game, good sound and visuals, repetitive and boring combat, and a story that if I had to summarize is really contrived and uninteresting.  In summary: Graphics - Good Sound - Good Gameplay - Boring Story - Bad and Boring  I can't recommend the game.

Going through the campaign is a joy, as well as finding and using all the weapons, powers, rifts, and collectibles. Graphics is a huge plus, as I was literally dumbstruck by the amount of detail that was put into this. Rain seeps through the cracks of the pier, light blooms off of appropriate objects, and the particles of the salt recharge machine are glorious. Gameplay is standard run and gun, but you can use vigors to pull enemies in, float them up, electrocute them, light them up, catch their own bullets and throw them back, and skyrails to move wherever they take you and strike from above. I completed this in 10 hours on normal. 1999 mode, which is extra hard, is added after completing the campaign. The sense of scale is amazing, but it can get you lost at times, even though the game is primarily linear. One more downside to this game is that the ending had me questioning if it was an actual ending, I felt that it took the Borderlands 2 ending route, (people who have played both should know what I mean). By all means, buy it, but I'd wait for a sale, as i feel anywhere from $30 to $10 is a good price for the amount of content alone.

Although the nonsense ending with its cohort of plotholes and lazily scripted beats effectively diminished the latter half of its story, Bioshock Infinite still succeeded in telling an interactive story worth playing. One could easily criticize the game for its lack of variety, its near-complete linearity, or the fact that it gets half its guns by slightly tweaking the other half in a 'mirror world' effect. Enemies are too often bullet sponges when shot with weaker guns, yet possess a weak AI that leads them to either charge the player en masse or simply stand still and spray.   Despite the fact that the story fell apart in the third act, I still recommend it as an example of strong storytelling in games. It can also be looked at as a how to on making games with uninteresting mechanics play well because of externals, like audio and visuals.

general info: bioshock infinite puts you in the shoes of a private investigator, who is assigned to find a girl. that girl is said to be within a city that floats up in the air. you will soon find out, that your task is much harder as you anticipated. the game is set into the 'real world', but history took other turns and one could say its a parallel universe. unlike the other bioshock titles BS:infinite is quite 'bright'. BS:I is primarly a shooter with slight RP elements and a compelling story.  what you get: you get around 20 hours of gametime for a playthrough. tho the 'into-part' is quite long. for about 30-60 minutes you only get to explore and investigate until you really get into the action. the game is designed quite linear, so you will kinda direclty follow the plot as the programmers intended. you advance from district to district and unlock areas as you progress in the story. you get the standard collection of shooter weapons like pistol, shotgun, MG, assault rifle, sniper rifle and rocketluncher. like the other bioshock titles, you also get to wield some kind of magic powers, which vary from pure destruction with fire, to controlling and manipulating powers. during the game you will find stronger weapons of a certain kind to keep level with the increasingly powerful enemies. you can upgrade your weapons and magic abilities to become more efficient. you need to put some thinking into that tho, because its unlikely you will be able to unlock all powerups you want to have. all in all you can play your desired style (i.e. closeup shotgunner or sniper or ...) and upgrade accordingly. the grafic is quite nice and the world got its nice wierd 'bioshock touch' as you got it in the other bioshock titles. i found the story to be quite compelling as you reveal one secret after the other about your arch enemy. also the story got some nice twists and if you are the thinking type, then the ending will keep you occupied for quite a while to sort it out properly.  fazit: BS:infinite is a nice shooter with some fantasy aspects (magic) and some minor RP elements (upgrades). the biggest feature is, that BS:I plays with your mind, as it puts you into unusual thinking patterns and paradigms. you get the kind of 'wierd' that made the other bioshock titles stand out.  so, if you like shooters and have a flexibile mind and enjoy to bend your mind, then BS:I is the right thing for you.

Bioshock Infinite is a flawed gem.... but while there are many issues with the game, in the end it is a title that every gamer should have as a part of their library and play through at least once. The storytelling, central themes, and characters (especially Elizabeth) are all a cut above what most AAA games dare to attempt, and as such this is an important and powerful game in a genre that is traditionally loaded with juvenille pap.   Mild spoilers ahead.  If you're looking for a solid shooter and couldn't give a hoot about a game that attempts to tackle some tough themes, then by all means go and pick up the latest Call of Duty game, however if you're interested in seeing the Video Game Industry actually try to tackle social issues like racism and poverty, or cerebral issues like parallel universes or time loops, then the Bioshock games - and especially Bioshock Infinite - are an amazing place to start.  As far as actual game play goes, Infinite is nothing special - if you've played a previous Bioshock then you know what to expect: your characters spends 50% of his time pouring bullets or psychic powers into waves of generally brainless AI pawns, and 50% of his time scouring through trash cans looking for rotting food to eat, or ammo to restock his arsenal. The shooting is Fine.... but it's not really the point. (And some might argue that there is too much of it, and it gets in the way of the really interesting stuff - namely the story.)  Special mention has to be made of Elizabeth, your 'sidekick' in the game... she joins you a quarter of the wway into the main plot, and if you don't end up fallign in love at least a little bit with her, then you're a cold-hearted person indeed. The game designers clearly wanted the player to emphasize with Elizabeth, and by my estimation they knocked it right out of the park.  All in all, Bioshock Infinite is a 'Must Play' game, and you're doing yourself a disservice if you havent' given it a try yet.

So, I finished this game not to long ago and I really love this game. A lot. It's a game that I had fun exploring the intruging world of Columbia, while abusing the hell out of the skyhook to kill monsters. So what made this game really interesting? Let me just critque it..  Graphics: Testing this game out on a 1920 x 1080 setting on Ultra makes this game extremely gorguous to see and feel. I like being introduced to new places, or locations that are easy to get lost in places like the Welcome Center, or Battleship Bay. I really think it's cool to see floating towns in general! Enemies look really detailed ( and Scary )! I'm more tempted to take down a Handyman than a Patriot, since Handymans are scarier in my opinion. Vigors are awesome. Enough Said.  Sound: I love the sound of this game. The Trilogy of Bioshock has never surprised me with their use of vintage music from the early 1900's. I love songs such as ' Will The Circle Be Unbroken ', or the Barbershop Quartet song of 'God Only Knows' too. I recommend it if you're in search of new music. Shots and the use of Vigors sound really accurate. Troy Baker and Courtnee Draper did a suprerb job as Booker and Elizabeth also.  Gameplay: If you played the past Bioshock games, it's almost the same with the exception of Skyhooks. You can now execute enemies which is gruesome to me. Sky executions are also fun to do as well since you can jump back and forth in any direction to go to any rail whenever you want. Elizabeth herself is the best part about combat. She's a very smart person; she can hand you some coins, some ammo/health, and can even open up Tears to assist you. There's so much different ways to approach combat where I want to experiment if a certain combo works ( example: Shock Jockey and Shotgun ). Exploring is self explanatory; you can flesh out the story if you collect Voxophones which give depth to characters in the game if you're ever curious about their motives. You can also have Elizabeth pick lock doors too; it makes exploring more rewarding and can help you upgrades the things you need for your next fight.  Overall: Just get it. You won't be bored because Bioshock Infinite wants you to enjoy every minute of it, and make you wish that such worlds like Columbia exist. The ending can confuse you, but for such a complicated game like this.. it's very well thought out.

This is one of the best games i have ever played, I highly recommend that you buy it, i got the whole collection for $20.00 During the holiday sale. The game starts off with the protagonist Booker DeWitt who is in high debt and is sent on a job to wipe it away. Things start to get a little weird very early on when you sit in a chair and it launches you high into the sky, into the beautiful city of Columbia, in which indeed is a floating city. A little early on you will find your best ally Elizebeth who aids you throughout your job, and also just so happen to, be your job. You will later find out that time travel (Also known as tears) will take effect into the game and sometimes forces you to think about what's going on, and, or how Elizebeth creates these tears. You can also see that in the game decisions have created the Protagonist's and Antagonist's life. As they have high similarities yet are completely opposite men. (Spoiler alert) At the end of the game it really leaves you thinking, some people might say, (What the hell was that). You later find out that your job is your daughter who has had her name changed from Anna to Elizebeth after protagonist (Booker DeWitt) has a baptism. This choice makes him into Antagonist (Zachary Comstock) Who is the creator and prophet of the city of Columbia. As you see this choice has completely changed Booker's life. You will also see that coming from the games title Bioshock: Infinite. That the reason it was called infinite was to show that for every choice you make, there will be an infinite amount of outcomes from it. This just goes to show how this game will mindf*ck you. I highly recommend this game and if i were to rate it i would give it a solid 10/10. It has a great ending that leaves you thinking and the gameplay is smooth and fluent with the addition of skylines which intensifies the combat. I beat it at around 9 hours but you might be able to get some more because i rushed a little bit. The game has it's share of difficulty and even brings back mini bosses such as Patriots and Handymen to replace the big daddies in it's predecessors. The game is just really fun and keeps you playing to see how this job plays out for Booker and Elizebeth.

Don't play this game for the fight mechanics. I figured I'd just get that statement out of the way before I got into the actual meat of my review. There are a lot of things that Bioshock Infinite is and a lot it's not and whether you'll enjoy it really boils down to assessing what you're actually looking for in a game.  STORY This is the meat and potatoes of this game and it's plenty filling. The world isn't open, but it's easy to get lost exploring little alcoves to find recordings that tell you more and more of the story. It unfolds around you as you make your way through objectives, which are easy to follow thanks to the arrows. I never felt like I didn't know what was going on with the story and even though some characters or events aren't explained right away, they come about in time. My entire first experience was more like participating in a film, rather than playing the game itself. I'd forget to shoot enemies because I was too busy staring at scenery or listening to people talk. The ending blew my mind a little, but then I'm not a philosophical scholar and I'm fairly easily surprised by plot twists even in movies.  GRAPHICS Pretty. So pretty. I don't really think there's a lot of description you need for the graphics, but the world is crafted beautifully. There is some repetition in store fronts and the residents don't have a lot of graphical differences, but you'll be too busy looking around to care that much. Or at least I was. The skies, the buildings, the Songbird, the sky rails, the gondolas - honestly everything is just so pretty.   FIGHTS This is about the only part that I felt was kind of lacking because fights were unimaginative. There were only a couple of instances where I felt like I was challenged, even playing on the highest level. Between chain traps and ammo everywhere and Elizabeth throwing you things, you just kind of blaze through most of the battles. But like I stated from the start - it's not about fight mechanics. They're just in the way of the storytelling.  SUMMARY If you like games with a good plot where you're being entertained more than fighting things, get this game. If you like games with beautiful scenery and surroundings, get this game. Just get this game in general. There's a reason it was such a runaway hit when it came out.

I have only played around 7 hours of Bioshock Infinite at this point and not yet completed it, so keep that in mind when reading my review.   First of all I will say that the game is really well drawn and looks beautiful! The soundtrack and the voices are excellent as well and you really feel like you get immersed into the Bioshock world (Columbia). It's also quite exciting and the story is captivating and makes you want to explore it further to discover what is going on. I like the shooting and combat which is pretty classic first-person shooter. Some parts of the gameplay reminds me slightly of Borderlands but of course Bioshock is a completely different animal.   Unfortunately there are also some not so great things about it, mainly being that it's very linear and won't allow you to deviate much from the path that needs to be followed to move the story along. In fact it restricts you way too much in my opinion and you will find many many doors that are locked and can't be opened and places that can't be accessed. One example is when you are on a beach at one point and there are people playing in the water. If you try to run out in the water you will be blocked as if there was a wall of glass in front of you. I don't need it to be a sandbox game, but I definitely would have enjoyed it better if the developer had allowed me to roam a bit more freely and investigate the game world more freely.  Another thing I don't like much is that many of the characters in the game look exactly the same. It would have been nice if everyone looked different, maybe apart from an acutal twin now and then, instead of using generic characters in so many places (NPCs). Likewise you cannot engage with the majority of the characters in the game. You can step up next to them and listen to what they talk about which is a really nice touch which adds lots of ambiance to the game, but you cannot talk to them or interact with them for the most part. I would have liked to be able to do that to some degree.   All in all I will definitely recommend the game because it is actually really good entertainment and it's definitely one of the best looking games I have played.   Hope this review helped and if I change my mind after finishing the game I will update the review accordingly :-)  Have fun!

But the way that the entire tapestry is woven together is what helps this game to prove that cliches and archetypes can still be powerful things in the hands of a good storyteller.  At first, playing with Bioshock in mind, I felt myself stangely uncompelled by what was occurring in the story, but I continued on. I find it rather funny that Bioshock has demonstrated both the right way and the wrong way to do a sequel. Infinite got it right. A good sequel uses the original as a jumping off point to an entirely unique experience.  You start out as this dude named Booker, and you go to the cloud city of Columbia. You get some plasmids, sorry, I meant vigors, and you have to rescue some gild who follows you around for the rest of the game.  Now about this girl. From a gameplay perspective, it's amazing to play a game where you don't want to bash the face in of whatever NPC you are escorting. Normaly, excort quests are rubbish. However this game is a joyful exception to that rule. The girl never gets in your way, and she doesn't get herself killed in combat. In fact, she's incredibly helpful in combat because she will sometimes 'find' health and ammo if you are running low.  Another bit of gameplay that was added that I find awesome is the sky-rails. You know in Bioshock how there was never a single bit of actual underwater gameplay, in a city that is entirely underwater? Yeah, they fix that here. the skyrails are awesome.  Also the plot is great and these developers seem to have mastered the video game plot reveal. The last 30 minutes of the game is pure brilliance.  This is easily the best game I played in 2013. I've been sitting here for at least 10 minutes trying to think of any complaints I might have, so this review is a little more balanced, and I'm have a very hard time remembering any.

If you played Bioshock 1 and loved it as much as me, and expected this to be as good or even better, you will be disappointed. Bioshock 1 didn't make the mistake of focusing the game on the story, the story was just a very good addition to the solid gameplay. Infinite decides to focus more on its story, and the gameplay falls behind previous games in the series. Plasmids aren't varied (to the point of being reskins of each other), and the survival-horror style of gameplay in the original Bioshock is completely stripped from this game in favour of generic 'shoot lots at bullet sponges'.  There's nothing special about the gameplay of this game. There's the occasional excuse of a puzzle a 4 year old could solve, the combat is generic and there's none of the appealing elements from earlier instalments of the series. So we'll forget about that and look at what the game sells itself on; story and characters. Rather than focusing on key points, it kind of just wanders over an array of ideas without delving into any of them. At times the story is just completely stupid. For example, a group of rebels who look up to you unexplainable try to kill you without a second thought. This is without even mentioning the exposition of the game, but I'll get to that later. The characters aren't nearly as bad as the story, but they're not very 3 dimensional either. Elizabeth is obviously THE selling point of the game and she's quite likable, and they obviously spent a lot of time making her seem less like a typical NPC. However, she doesn't seem to stand by her ideas. She has a go at you for killing someone early on in the game, then proceeds to watch you murder 100's of others without even so much as a frown. Well, it might have gotten annoying if she kept nagging at you. The rest of the cast are really forgettable, or completely misused. Songbird comes to mind here. What a great boss this could have been, but instead it's just used as a plot device, again as an ally in a terrible fight, and then disposed of. A complete waste of an otherwise interesting design. The Twins were the only other memorable characters due to their quirky and entertaining behaviour.   Okay, the ending. It was stupid, pretentious, and pointless. Yes, if you actually understand the nonsense they dump on you at the end, then you will see how pointless it is. Warning, SPOILERS AHEAD. If there are an infinite number of worlds, then Booker has (according to the story) to die in all of them. This simply wouldn’t happen, there will be at least one reality where booker doesn't die, and therefore the supposed reason behind your death is completely void.   Buy it on sale if you wish, but if you were a fan of the original expect to be disappointed. The other reviewers who are praising the writing and story probably haven't read a book in their lifetimes.

Some say this is the game of the year, others say the best game of all time. I just say that this game had a lot of potential to be a lot better.   Firstly, in this game the story is a big deal, since there are plot twists, a lot of mystery around the main characters, which is the main driving factor to continue through the game. The way the story is presented will leave you with many questions as the game progresses, but does not answer all of them. The best experience would probably be the 2nd run, because there are so many little story hints and details scattered everywhere, that you will not have any idea what to link to on your 1st run. Either way, if you do not get attached to the story you may not mind the unanswered questions, gaps, and out of place fantasy elements the story has.  Secondly, the gameplay is between fun, frustrating and repetitive. The frustration could be completely eliminated by either letting you carry more ammo, or 3 guns instead of 2. It is repetitive when you face enemies doorway after doorway, and you mostly use the same tactic to defeat them. Also a bit in the repetitive side, is the need to loot in order to obtain ammo, money, and upgrades. There are many rooms and sections from where you can loot, if you are the type of person that do not like to miss an upgrade, you will spend half of the game scavenging.   Thirdly, Elizabeth. If you have seen trailers from like 2 years ago, you will be disappointed. You are probably expecting a character that can interact with you dynamically and in interesting ways. But what you get here is an AI that follows you around, makes some meaningless comments about random objects in the background, and throws you objects when you need them. It is just the same as any other game, no breakthroughs here.  Last, but not least. The graphics and art. Well, this game is very good in this aspect. A lot of detail and beautiful landscapes. For me it does not make up for the cons, but well, if you take this away you may not even consider this a good game anymore.  There are some other annoyances like being presented with choices that do not affect the game at all, constantly facing racism, high class vs low class and religion brainwashing speeches, but they are tied to the story and to the context Ken Levine wanted to create for his game about Quantum Physics.  In summary, Quantum Physics + Attempt to create charismatic companion + Random Context + Great Graphics and Art = Bioshock Infinite

The latest entry into the BioShock series is a very, very rare sort of game. Leaving the world of Rapture behind, a new protagonist now finds himself in the city of Columbia, a massive floating city comprised of god knows how many floating island.  Columbia itself is an extreme version of an incredibly patriotic American city in the early 20th century, filled with religious zealots, bigoted as you could imagine. These people worship the founding fathers as Gods and following a prophet named Father Comstock.  The gameplay has vastly improved over the other two BioShock games (ie. shooting mechanics, controls, etc.) and introducing several new features, one of the most notable being sky rails.  It feels very familiar in terms of the attempt at an isolated utopia and the way the story unravels, however it establishes itself as its own game early on and sets itself apart in many ways from the first two games.  I won't give any more away, but I can seriously, seriously recommend playing the game. To get the full experience out of it, I would recommend playing the first game. Many parallels can be drawn and it's exciting to see the way a city with essentially the exact opposite ideals to Rapture manages.

A trip to Infinity    After playing the previous BioShock games, I really wanted to play BioShock Infinite. The game drops you in an unbelievable world, the city of Columbia. This setting amazingly decorated in American glory, with a steampunk allure. Best part, the whole city is floating in the air.   Bring us the girl, and wipe away the debt    The game follows veteran Booker DeWitt on his journey to rescue a mysterious girl named Elizabeth. Booker is followed by his past, and all he wants is to begin anew. As you travel trough Columbia, you wil soon discover the dark parts of this new Eden. The story is very well written, and will bring up lots of discussion.   sky-high combat   BioShock Infinite gives the player various options for its combat. Armed with both strong weapons and powerful vigors (comparable to plasmids) the player can wield deadly combinations, both for close combat or the long range. This gives the player more freedom, compared to the previous BioShock games, which focused more on close combat. In the process, sky-lines add an extra dimension. Also, the powers that Elizabeth wields work very well with the flow of the combat.  To me, this game is truly Game of the Year 2013, and really worth playing

Bioshock Infinite exceeds its illustrious predecessors and lives up to the ridiculous hype and universal praise that it's received; in fact, it is *the best* game of this 'generation'... and that is saying something considering the sheer number of classics that have been released in the last decade.  Bioshock Infinite is a genuine piece of art - every aspect is executed to the highest possible standard, from the artistic presentation (somehow steampunk and dreamlike at the same time... not a common combination) to the fast paced and creativity focused combat, to the mind bending plot... but the superb fundamentals are only part of the package. Every aspect of the game is drenched in commentary, character development, and the type of thematic challenges one expects from only the very best 'hard' science fiction. There's more to ponder and enjoy in a single nook of one level than has been served up in the entire Call of Duty series.  Bioshock Infinite is exhilarating, and heartbreaking, and generally worthwhile in a way that most pop culture artifacts no longer even consider attempting. You *must* play this game.

The story of Bioshock Infinite deserves all of the praise it gets. It's presented in a way that doesn't overly confuse the player and when it hits, it hits hard. It tells a tale that mixes elements of both fantasy and science fiction that hasn't really been done in this fashion before. The art direction is stunning and you get a real feeling of place in the world, thanks to the smaller details and liveliness of your surrondings. The soundtrack swells during emotional moments, helping to drive home the fact that the story is not only a mentally stimulating one, but one that can still manage to pull at your heart strings from time to time. It boils into a loud, bombastic clash of strings and percussion instruments that is very reminiscent of Stanley Kubriks 'The Shining'. The major fault of this game is that if your looking for a game with strong gameplay, enough so that it can carry you through it on its own, you might be dissapointed. The gameplay lacks any kind of depth or complexity and while this is probably done to give the player's mind a rest after the more logically complex moments of the story present themselves, it is still only a mindless shooter with gimmicky, if fun, elements tossed into the mix. The skyhooks and elizabeth's tear powers do add complexity, but little do they help to make the player think in battle. The vigors are much less a carefully chosen set of skills the player has with them to deal with specific tasks, as much as they are general use and really used as either stuns, Area of Effect, or damage utilities. While this may sound bad, believe me when I say that Bioshock Infinite is truly a marvelous experience, worth the money and time, just not as good of a game. Certainly better gameplay than Call of Duty, but the quality of the game itself does not stack up to the quality set forth by the rest of the package. I'd reccomend this to anyone looking for a deep and involving story, but not to someone looking for a deep and involving game.

'Ascension. 10,000. 15,000... hallelujah.' This game is absolutely phenomenal in many aspects which define both a memorable story line, gameplay, and visuals. Set in an alternate 1912, you play as Booker DeWitt on a rescue mission to save a girl captive in a city floating in the sky. During the first 5 minutes of the game, the remarkable intro to the vast sky city of Columbia will leave you in awe and welcome you to plenty more stunning scenes to come.   The visual experience is absolutley fantastic. When i play games, i often find myself taking a few screenshots here and there whenever i find the need to, either for a desktop wallpaper or to just show friends. When playing this game, i found myself taking screenshots of EVERYTHING. Every corner, every moment, and every object is a detailed work of art, ranging from breathtaking views of the city, a day at the beach, statues of prophets, specific tonality for every room, or something as a small as a vase or a street lamp. These visual achievements successfully portray a unique time period and deliver something unique and probably something never before seen in a game (during my experiences), all of which works beautifully to present the historical setting of Infinite.   The gameplay mechanics are fun, satisfactory, and exciting. The combination of the new Sky hook and traditional weapons allows for extremely fun and fast paced gunplay. It is a balanced system with challenging boss battles and AI. Whether it's jumping from skyline to skyline, using vigor abilites for protection or manipulating an enemy, or using your Sky hook to land a brutal melee, Infinite delivers a gameplay experience that's familiar to previous Bioshock games and greatly improves on it, leaving the player satisfied and wanting several more play-throughs.  I enjoyed everything this game had to offer. From its stunning visuals, to its memorable story/setting, fantastic musical score, and fun and satisfying gameplay mechanics. I recommend this game to both hardcore and casual gamers, for it has something to offer for both. Take your time with this game, and Enjoy!  AN EASY 5/5 :)

Gameplay: The gamplay is very similar to Bioshock 2 with the ability to dual wield a vigor (plasmid) and a gun. The shooting mechanics are rock solid as to be expected from this developer. The only real new addition to gameplay is the inclusion of the skyrails which you can use to ride on in gunfights to enhance mobility and shoot from. While not much new was added the gameplay is still rock solid and fun. Even more fun to the shooting segments are segments where we are allowed to take a breath and explore and interact with the world. These moments are done masterfully and should be savored as long as possible.  Visual Design: The visuals of this game are absolutely breathttaking. This is a game that realized excellent art direction is more important than graphical capability and manages to combine both with exceptional skill. The game is gorgeous and fantastically detailed. The game bids farewell to the browns and grays so prevalent in modern shooters and replaces them with a world seeping in beautiful well matched colors. The opening will leave you convinced.  Sound: The sound is top notch along with the excellent music choices. The creators cleverly inserted several musical easter eggs well worth finding throuhout a playthrough.  Story: If there is one reason you should pick up this game this is it. The story is fantastically written with an ending that will keep you up at night and that you will never ever forget. Few games can claim such lofty achievments when it comes to story. The story is very much a love letter classic early 1900's science fiction and blending it with the newer more complex ideas of more modern science fiction. The ending manages to turn the story upsidedown at the end making a replay guaranteed almost immediatley after first completion. The world of Columbia is an excellent satire of American nationalism taken to extremes with a focus on American Exceptionalism. The satire is handled masterfully and intelligently just as it was in the original Bioshock. The world manages to look beatiful and reveal itself to be ugly through intelligent writing. This is a high point for writing in games.  Replayablity: The story is the primary reason to replay the game. Sure there are plenty of collectables you likely missed while playing through the game but the true reason you will boot it back up again 5 minutes after finishing the story is to see the story play out fully knowing and understanding the twist. This is a rare game where the second play through is equally as fun a second time through as the first. Finding all the subltle and not so subtle hints that flew over your head the first time you played is a very rewarding experience that makes this game special in its own way.    Recommendation: I fully recommend this game. The only weakness I found was the gamplay changing so little since bioshock 2 but that is a solid system to stand on (and the only thing good about bioshock 2). If you love stories and fantastic beautiful worlds to explore this game is a must own. A Full Recomendation!  Tip for first time players: Play through the game at a slow pace and immerse yourself in the world. There are several non combat segments that you should take your time with. Rushing through the game can lessen the impact of the ending so take a breath take a walk and play a carnival game or two.
