INTRO  Burial at Sea is the first part of Bioshock Infinites DLC series and has you playing as Booker Dewitt back down below in Rapture (nostalgia trip). The DLC begins with a young woman requesting you investigate in the case of missing young girl. After a brief conversation the young woman is revealed to be Elizabeth from Infinite’s storyline.  GAMEPLAY  The gameplay hasn’t changed much from the main game so there’s not a lot to talk about really, but there have been a few minor changes to the difficulty that enhance the experience and give you the horror nostalgia trip back to the first Bioshock. First off, ammo is scarce, at first it may seem quite a cheap choice to create difficulty but once you get into it you find yourself using your plastids (yes plastids – IMPORTANT) more than you would have in Infinite. I’m unsure about anyone else but in Infinite’s storyline I found myself using Vigours/Plastids to enhance my gun play (Bucking Bronco TO shotgun) rather than using them for their own powers. Next we have the weapon wheel, YES it’s back! Yay! Unfortunately you are still restricted to two weapons at once as using the weapon wheel will only switch out the weapon you are holding but it’s still infinitely (no pun intended) better than Infinite’s system. Although not every gameplay aspect has been reviewed, unfortunately the stealth gameplay still suffers from serious bugs or just flat out not working at all.    //  *SPOILER WARNING*  //    STORY  Now, as was the same with Infinite (I felt anyway) the gameplay was the basic rather mundane aspect of the game as I found the gameplay sections boring and simple gateways between the storyline. Once again this is the case. The story is still phenomenal with an awesome ending that leaves us with a cliff-hanger but not SO much that it seems annoying. Without spoiling any surprises the story finishes as you would expect, if you pay attention to what Elizabeth is saying throughout the DLC (and if you actually played Infinite), with a huge reveal and explanation simultaneously, leading into what the next DLC will play as. BUT, as epic as the story was I feel it had some issues. The storyline in DLC (I find) tends to be SIDE stories or what COULD have happened, but this doesn’t feel like that, this feels like it’s actually part of the main story as it is continuing that story. I am firmly against an extension to a storyline that we already paid for; this DLC opened up what we knew would happen and is asking for more money – bad developers. BAD. Also, another bad developer move, why did you give a blurb for episode two? The blurb for episode 2 gives SERIOUS hints of the ending of this DLC.  CONCLUSION  While I agree that the original storyline shouldn’t be continued in paid DLC or not, I can’t deny how epic this DLC was. Again, I personally feel the gameplay sections in Infinite and it’s DLC were simple filler sections to get me back into the epic story, but I would defiantly say the gameplay sections were less mundane than that of Infinite (maybe nostalgia me talking but hey). So here it is, the killer question; is it worth it? No. I wouldn’t say so, it’s fun and all, but if you can get the same experience watching someone play a game, then it’s not worth it in my opinion. Like I said the gameplay sections still felt like filler so simply watching the cut scenes/conversations over someone’s shoulder would be enough to get what was great about this – the story. Whenever I’m thinking about buying DLC I look back at some of my all the time favourite – Dragonborn. Lots to do, new items, NOT a continued story but a side story and a great side story as well. Now considering you can get Dragonborn for two pounds more, you wouldn’t expect such a HUGE difference in quality – but unfortunately there is.

While Infinite has certainly compromised on some areas (advanced or deep combat most notably) to advance in others, it strikes a great balance. I was invested in Elizabeth, I felt concern for Booker and was amused by the simple twists on dying in the game that I didn't feel the rather rudimentary combat was something to complain about. Buy this game. Play it until the end. It's too good to pass up.

Story: 9/10 While playing the other Bioshocks is not a requirement, playing them first will build up to this game. The plot kept me engaged the entire time, and while certain areas did feel like filler (specifically right before the final act) the small plot twists and interesting premise, along with the great characterization, will keep you playing.  Atmosphere: 10/10 Columbia (the city the game takes place in) is beautiful, and the variation between different zones is beautiful. A screenshot from anywhere in game looks like a painting. The music is fitting, the city feels alive, and while you don't always feel like you are miles off the ground, you always feel like you are in Columbia.  Gameplay: 8/10 Solid shooter mechanics, and a variety of weapons. The new plasmids, err tonics, are different enough to compliment a variety of play styles. The action is fast paced and very much -in your face-, so don't expect stealth mechanics, but the gun-play is much improved from the original Bioshock. The limit of two weapons at a time is also a welcomed addition, as it makes you wonder if carrying around an RPG for a boss is worth it when fighting individual units.   Sound: 9/10 The voice acting is fantastic, and while the music is up to par with industry standards, doesn't really stand out all too much. There is only one point at which soundtrack really stood out to me, but even then it was only for a moment. For the most part the soundtrack is going ot be fast paced to match the gameplay, which works. Columbia, however, and the sounds of the machines and songs on the streets, work perfectly.   Pros: Great Story and Atmosphere Solid Mechanics and Gameplay Continues the BioShock story Amazing Characterization  Cons: Certain areas feel like filler Strange difficulty spikes in some areas Low-Medium Replayability Some tonics you get too late into the game  Extra Notes: Looking forward to see where they go with DLC. There are some characters I'd like to see expanded (Songbird).

Bioshock Infinite, experience out the ♥♥♥.  Really though, between the absolutely gorgeous set pieces and badly timed exposition, this game is everything I had hoped for. It's somewhat of a first person adventure game, that focuses on shooting as much as picking apples to eat out of trash cans. Considering that I actually hadn't play Bioshock prior to this, I felt nothing but appreciation for the artistic vision being put forward here. While hating this game now seems to be some kind of farce, with its glitters worn off more than half a year after its release, I cannot help but love it. Before any of you on the hate bandwagon point at me and say I'm just trying to defend my purchase, I did not even buy this game. It was gifted to me by a friend, and I suppose I owe him something, right?  Nah.  In this game, you play as Booker DeWitt, a drunken gambler who happened to, avoiding spoilers, lost something rather close to him. Arriving at a light house (a throw back that is now that I know) after being lead onto by a pair resembling a cross between mad scientists and aliens from E.T, you are exposed to this glorious floating golden set of concrete on cloud named Columbia. It was at this point that the game was starting to destroy my frame rates, but not by too much that would become noticeable. Anyway, you are exposed to this gorgeous intact world of what seemed to be paradise where everyone's really racist. Then again it is the early 1900s so what else can I expect from Americans? Anyways, you are participating in this annual fair for some reasons while kept on getting visually ♥♥♥♥ed by all the shiny and crazies of this gorgeous engine. Suddenly, everything turned all gory and fast paced, after a bearded Catholic (hej) priest told everyone that you're going to destroy their paradise and murder their people, thus you must escape by destroying their paradise and murdering their people.   Underlying all of this is the plot of where you must find this girl and repay a debt you apparently had. After countless hours of massacre and relentless shooting gallery, you are met with Elizabeth, the centerpiece of the story. While I had my own gripes about Booker being on the cover of the sodding box art while Elizabeth was clearly the actual star of the game, or how she had dissolved from a magic-wielding witch whose capable of destruction far surpasses that of comprehension to a girl who occasionally throw you supplies she pulled out of her backside, at least the game isn't a giant escort mission. Elizabeth is a helpful and healthy part of gameplay that blends in rather well with the rest of the world created. Your journey proceeds to an adventure, where your choice dictates the fate you choose for this girl and how the world reacts to it, creating a very dynamic experience that is unique to every player.  Psyche.  No, you're not going to have that. What you ARE going to get though is an admittedly clunky combat system that is somehow weaker than its prequel, and interface so clunky and obviously shoehorned for console that it irks me so much that the 'gameplay' aspect of Bioshock Infinite felt quite a bit tacked on. There's a certain amount of collectibles and exploration to be done in this game, and that is good, but it's still rather linear. I'm not going to go any deeper to this, however, as it would spoil the plot rather heftily. What you do need to know, however, is that you would either come out of the game feeling cheated out of a good ending that actually is coherent and not terribly pretentious, or feel like you've gone through the best 10 hours moral class of your life and now are feeling empty inside.  Have fun.

I'm keeping this quick and brief, because Steam crapped its pants and I lost my last well-written recommendation. But the jist is still there. I liked BioShock Infinite's story. I did not like its gameplay, or its mood, or its atmosphere.  Gameplay was, well, dull. Just a boring wave-based shootybang. The lack of horror or more close-quartered based combat of BioShock 1 was sorely missed, the weapons were kinda dull, and the Vigors weren't half as interesting as the Plasmids from the first game. Plus they're just there, generally accepted, and don't feel as pivotal to the plot. That's disappointing, all things considered. The only reason I played through to the finish is because if I stopped, I don't think I would've carried on.  Its mood was... eh. This harks back to gameplay. It just felt too frantic, which is kind of bland because that's pretty much every single-player shooter these days. *snore* The game just never did much to really make me feel much other than on my toes in a ridiculous firefight, or ignoring the environment to scavenge ammo and money so I could prepare myself for the next bland and unineteresting encounter. I didn't *feel* anything playing this game.  Atmosphere. Hmm. This is where the game fails. Pretty much every area of BioShock felt real; Infinite felt fake and forced. I never felt interested in Columbia once, and the game did nothing to change that. I want to spoil the ending, but there's a bit in the end that elicited the feeling of the first game very much so, and it was pretty much that point that I realised what I'd been missing all throughout Infinite.  And sure, the game covers topics of poverty, racism, religious persecution, American exceptionalism, blahblahblah. But all of these felt like a fart in the wind, and were grossly overblown in the game's promotion. Infinite, whilst relatively bold for a shooter, is pretty tame by most standards.  But boy, did it have interesting characters. And that ending made the whole thing just about worth it. Just about.  The whole package isn't bad, and if you're happy to just shoot dudes then you'll be content, but I feel that stopped the game from being something great, which is what we were promised in 2K's PR avalanche of trailers, making of/behind the scenes YouTube videos, and IGN's hyperbolic exclusive early review.  All told, I won't be playing BioShock Infinite again, which I can't say is the case for the first one. That's a game I'll be going back to many more times to come. Infinite will be consigned to the dustbin of history once this wretched era of the shootybang dudebro videogame monoculture is finally over.  7/10

However, the background history is very confusing in the start and you must keep progressing the game hoping to get any kind of explanation. Columbia is a utopic city like Rapture once was, but this time you arrive during the 'good days'. The game never ever explained how vigors exists and why nobody is interested in them (since almost no one uses or mention vigors). Well, despite that, the game goes on telling you bits of the lore during your play, until you finish it and almost every puzzle piece come to it's place.  The gameplay is fantastic with Elizabeth, I just wish that Vigors were more available in the beggining, I used to play Bioshock 1 and 2 with almost Plasmids only. In this game you're gonna rely a LOT more in your guns, which I didn't like.  If you ever played any Bioshock series, play this game on Hard. I don't think this game has much replay value. The gunplay is less satisfying than most modern FPSs IMO and there isn't much to see after seeing the ending, unless you are a masochist and want to play 1999 mode. And yet. Play this game. You'll be drawn in by the beauty of Columbia and moments of brilliance (the barbershop quartet, a certain song and dance at the beach) and dragging through the combat is worth it, because the story and ending are great.   Also, that previously mentioned poor combat? Yeah, riding on skylines. It helps the setting and gives a bit more needed variety to gunplay. Let's face it, jumping from a rail and kicking a man off a platform is satisfying. Is it a 10/10 game? I don't think so, but it will be one of the best games of this year, if not the best.   I'll end my thoughts with a question for you to discover if you do purchase this game: why is it called Bioshock Infinite rather than Bioshock 3? If you can't work it out, don't worry; you will know by the end.

This game deserves many of the accolades it has received, but not all of them. Infinite is gorgeous, the plot is interesting and manages to keep one engaged throughout. My main gripe however, is how the actual gameplay (you know, that one thing that you generally buy video games for) is repetitive and unoriginal. The combat system is nearly identical to that of the previous 2 bioshocks with some small changes:  1) More weapons. The downside to this is that while you had original, interesting weapons in the original bioshock with varied ammunition, most of the weapons in infinite feel indistinguishable from one another 2) Removal of hackable turrets and security bots. In the previous games, you could take splicers, security bots, and big daddy's and play them off of each other to make for very interesting combat. 3) Introduction of tears. Elizabeth's powers, while interesting, basically consist of summoning cover, grapple points, or weapons into being. While a nice addition, this doesn't make the combat much more engaging. Elizabeth does have the ability to throw you ammunition and health which is nice, but doesn't add much to gameplay. 4) Introduction of skylines. This is the main mechanic that mixes up the combat. The ability to zoom through the sky while eliminating enemies is exhilarating. However, this feeling quickly fades when you realize that you never HAVE to use them to win a particular fight. It's a strange sensation how you have to essentially make your own fun rather than have the game simply BE fun.  In the first Bioshock game, you had a significant variety of weapons, traps, and plasmids to make the game interesting no matter what and each individual component had a specific purpose. In Infinite, it feels like different weapons and abilities are included just for the sake of being in the game. Is this a must buy game? No, not at full price at least (I picked mine up from an Amazon sale for under $20). Instead, I recommend picking it up once you've cleared out part of your backlog or if you're specifically looking for an interesting story, just don't expect anything utterly ground breaking in terms of gameplay.

Bioshock Infinite is the third installment in the Bioshock Series. Story-wise, this has little to no connection with the first two - being set in the world of Columbia (a flying city) instead of Rapture (the underwater city in the first two games).   There are mixed reviews about this game (mostly highly recommended but there are a few who dislike this game). I'm in the middle of the road. Let's start with the negatives because I have a bias on loving everything bioshock.  Cons FPS mechanics somewhat forces the player to play Infinite like a common shooter  - Headshot is properly implemented this game - and with that, there is little to no benefit in using Vigors (this game's version of Plasmids/Magic).   - It's extremely quicker to just shoot them in the head with a sniper than bother doing gun+vigor combos unlike in the first two games. Because of this, I ran the rest of the game with the first sniper rifle handed to me (a few minutes into the game) Vigors are now more of just 'distractions'.  Protagonist now has a shield. Shield is very OP - Shields soak up damage before going to direct damage. This regenerates automatically over time (when not taking damage). The cooldown time is relatively short, making shields very overpowered for a good part of the game. - Shields, though not customizable, are upgradeable due to special 'drinks' called infusions (you can choose between increased Health / Shields / Mana. Fully upgraded, it becomes equal to the starting Health.  Changes in theme / narrative  - I really loved the Rapture experience from the first two games (actually the first one was the best). It was the combination of lonely, creepy, desperate and insane in some ways. Bioshock Infinite took what worked in the first two games and turned it around and took a new path. Columbia is very bright and very spacious (given the floating city setting), but even the indoor environments are bigger (to give way to the sky-line system). The theme now revolves on religion, politics, and racism which is, for me, was not as gripping as a theme compared to what the first one had.  Pros Game implementation/optimization in general  - I played all Bioshock games in my laptop, and this was the first one to 'not crash' during gameplay. It was also weird that this is less / equally taxing to my laptop as compared to the second game. Kudos to the game optimization team  New Skyline system  - the Skyline is a form of transportation in this game. It is the rails that hold the cable cars/gondolas around the floating sections of columbia. It adds a new dimension to combat because you can shoot enemies and perform dive-attacks from the line, and it also gives you a new way of going around the combat area (though you are very vulnerable to enemy fire if you choose the lower speeds)  Implements a 'breadcrumbs'-style of navigation  - they took out the map - a minor Con(s) - and replaced it with a breadcrumbs-style navigation system. You press a button and an arrow juts out from your position on the floor, pointing to the objective.   - Backtracking is harder, but my rule of thumb is, whereever the arrow points, you go to the other way to get the goodies, then follow the arrow.  New equipment system  - The protagonist now has 4 slots for equipment (hat, chest, pants, boots) which give out different kinds of bonuses / abilities. My character has a hat that gives him a chance to set enemies on fire when hitting them with a melee attack.   Long story short, I loved the new improvements, but terribly miss the old setting.   Again, this is a must buy if you liked the first two, but other than that, it's just your average first-person-shooter with a few nifty bells and whistles and offers little enjoyment if you don't like the Bioshock story in the first place.

Beauty and Brutality go Head to Head in BioShock Infinite    It’s always special when you get to witness something that in some way shapes the future of the gaming industry. BioShock Infinite does just that. It brings new life to a genre that many believe has gotten stale. It also reminds us that single player first person shooters are still able to tell good stories. With all of its components working together, Infinite becomes what is arguably the best game in the BioShock series.  The first few moments of Infinite mirror those of the original BioShock. You, Booker DeWitt, are given one simple goal - “Bring us the girl, and wipe away the debt”. DeWitt travels to a lighthouse and is soon blasted past the clouds into Colombia, a floating city. Seriously. The moment I laid eyes on Colombia, my jaw dropped. It is truly a sight to behold.   Of course when you actually do get the girl, the plot is complicated and what started out as a “save the princess from the castle” storyline becomes something bolder than what the average video game is willing to tell. The less you know the better. The ending is slightly confusing but the game as a whole is open to interpretation. It’s a great discussion topic and the story is one of Infinite’s greatest successes.   However, every great story requires great characters. BioShock Infinite does not stumble here. The “princess” that you have to rescue is Elizabeth, although she doesn’t stay that way for long. Her character arch is one of the stories main components. It’s interesting to see a once innocent girl become hardened by tragedy and violence. It’s made even better due to the fact that Elizabeth is so damn likeable. Courtnee Draper delivers a wonderful performance as Elizabeth, giving her an extremely charming personality. Troy Baker is also strong as Booker DeWitt. His character is also tragic and it’s interesting to discover more about his past.  But BioShock Infinite’s greatest character is actually the floating city of Colombia. Set in 1912, Colombia has a relaxing and steampunk feel to it when the game begins. Everyone is happy and the world is absolutely gorgeous. However, Colombia is not at all how it first seems. As the story progresses, Colombia is revealed to be a city of white supremacists and extreme nationalists - people who subject interracial couples to public stonings and force African Americans and Irish Immigrants to work 16 hour days in terrible conditions. And on the other side is the Vox Populi, essentially a more extreme version of the Black Panthers. It’s all a bit too realistic and is frightening to witness. To make matters worse, you are looked at as the “False Shepherd” (Colombia’s version of the anti-christ). Everybody wants to kill you and bring Elizabeth back into captivity. What results is some brutal violence that contrasts beautifully with the environments.  Fortunately, Infinite’s gameplay is as good as its story. As in the first BioShock, the shooting is complemented by Vigors (renamed Plasmids). These range from fire grenades, a hoard of crows that will peck away at enemies, a wave of water that will send enemies flying backwards, and a lot more. You also possess a skyhook, which you can use to either unleash brutal executions or to ride Infinite’s Skyline - essentially a rollercoaster in the sky. You can shoot while on the Skyline and riding above your enemies and then dropping down to execute someone is exhilarating. The variety of Vigors and weapons lends for a large number of strategies and approaches to combat. Elizabeth also is very helpful and will throw you health packs and ammunition. She can also summon certain things into the environment because if story related reasons, which also warrants different approaches. The battlegrounds are all spacious, and combat was always fun. I look forward to replaying the game using different Vigors and weapons. No two people are going to have the exact same experience in Infinite. I do have one minor complaint with the game, and that is the choices you are allowed to make. Occasionally you will be able to choose between one of two actions, but your decision doesn’t change the outcome of the story. When you think about the later portion of Infinite’s story it makes sense, but as a gameplay choice it’s unnecessary. However, as a whole, Infinite rarely misses a beat. The game will likely be praised in the years to come as one of the best single player first person shooters ever made. It’s delightful to see something unique in the gaming industry, and BioShock Infinite delivers.  9.5/10

Being a die-hard fan of the Bioshock series, I was pleased with the latest installment, regardless of some issues I had with the game.  As a fair warning to potential buyers, I'd like to state that this review is in no way professional or objective, as it focuses on my personal experience with the game and its entire franchise. Also, my review isn't weighed by pros and cons, but by the overall experience, presentation, and gameplay of Bioshock Infinite.  Okay...  My overall experience with the game was satisfactory. The story is well-structured and its progression is fluid. Voice-acting is stellar, and the visuals (although not the most demanding on a PC) are incredible.   There are however, a few shortcomings (according to me): the game is short (10 hours to beat it, including exploration/side objectives) and even if the game does allow for some exploration of the city of Columbia, exploration doesn't feel quite as adventurous as it was in the first Bioshock. Furthermore, enemy movement and spawning are both very predictable. The first Bioshock had a more randomized spawn system for enemies, and the area you were in was never actually clear of Splicers. In this installement, combat is more centered on shooting instead of using your environment (hell I even forgot I had Vigors), which falls short on combat experience as areas always become clear of enemies after a predictable ambush.  The game is also quite linear, which contributes to its fluidity, but also to its limited exploration.  But that doesn't mean this game is boring. The game is very engaging, and its replayability value is quite high. It's just not the Bioshock genre I became accustomed to with the last two installements. Obligatory header to the review: I focus on four primary areas whenever I review a game: gameplay, story, graphics, and sound/audio/general things that go into your earholes. Gameplay and Story get a rating scale from 1 to 10, and the AV stuff gets a rating from 1 to 5. My philosophy on this is that there are some instances in which a game may not necessarily have that much in the way of gameplay (take Amnesia for example), but the story/atmosphere/whatever it may be is reason enough to pick it up. Also, take the cumulative score with a grain of salt; it's just a numerical feeling about the game as a whole. That's part of why I do these subscores. Also, keep in mind that I'm not going off of school grade based rankings. A 5/10 denotes what I feel to be an average game. Likewise, 7/10 is a game that I think is pretty cool, and something that gets a 2/10 is near-abomination level. Pinning scores to an even further obfuscated rating scale is kinda senseless, but for the sake of my backloggery, I'll repeat again that 1.0-2.7 is a one-star game, 3.0-4.7 is a two-star game, 5.0-6.7, 7.0-8.7, and 9.0-10 are three, four, and five stars, respectively.  Gameplay: I was never really into Bioshock 1's gameplay, strangely enough. It just never felt like there was any reason why I should give half an ♥♥♥♥ worth of effort, as enemies that seemed (to me) like they had too much health could be defeated by my UT2k4 strategy of 'kinda-zerg-rush-but-not-really.' Because of this, I didn't find myself enjoying Bioshock 1's gameplay all that much. Maybe it was the fact that I played it on console; maybe it's the fact that I had wanted to play the thing for three years, but never had a console/PC that could play it; I don't know. Bioshock Infinite hasn't changed much with regards to the 'you can respawn as much as you want' mechanic, but something feels... different. Better. I've been thinking for a while about it, but I just can't figure out what that thing is.  As implied in the previous paragraph, the basic mechanic of gunplay/mutations hasn't changed all that much. Gunplay feels great and launching a murder of crows at enemies can lead to some pretty dang funny events happening. The big change now is Elizabeth, who essentially acts as another scavenger as well as being able to introduce various tactical elements into areas, such as hooks, turrets, ammo/medkit depots, etc. She can make life a lot easier, since it's not just you having to search through  every stinkin' container in the area  for an emergency medkit. The game still manages to maintain a good level of challenge, though, and I never really found myself running out of ammo (since I often forget to use Vigors 'cuz I'm dumb); a problem I had in Bioshock 1.  Enemies are pretty smart, and the AI seems to have the capacity for group dynamics, to an extent at least. There were a few scenarios where it felt like one enemy was trying to distract me while another tries to flank me. A neat addition would be if Elizabeth warned you about a flanker, but that's not too big of a deal. Bosses are... kinda there and kinda not. There's a trend I've noticed and even a certain publisher stating that video gamers nowadays don't want boss fights in video games. I'm still taken aback by this supposed mentality. It is kinda disappointing that there is no legitimate boss in this game, but there are at least enemies worthy of the title miniboss.  I didn't really have any problems with this game design wise; at least for what was presented. While I would've liked a final boss as opposed to the enemy onslaught at the end, I still walked away from it feeling like I had played a pretty fun game. There is the inclusion of 1999 Mode, but after reading some of the changes, it seems like the kind of difficulty scaling that I don't like at all. Nevertheless, I can definitely recommend this game for just the gameplay, although that's most certainly not all that this game has to offer. 9/10.  Story: Even though the gameplay never really kept me involved in Bioshock 1, the story most certainly did. Ken Levine is a pretty dang good writer, and he  REALLY  shows it here. All of the characters are great, there's pretty heavy topics and symbolism all throughout the story, and the ending... oh, the ending just takes it up to 11. Now that Irrational's done, this really does feel like a swan song for the company, and the lyrics for that song could not have been written better. I've read about some people calling what happens in the ending, but even then, it's presented so stonking well that I couldn't give this game any less than a perfect 10/10 for the story. Man, it's hard not talking about it in depth for the review, but remain spoiler-free I shall.  Graphics: The Bioshock games have always looked good, and Bioshock 1 still looks pretty good to this day. Infinite blows Bioshock 1 clean out of the water, though, and that's not for just the technical aspects. People who have read my reviews know that I'm a sucker for giant, vast architecture. The entire city of Columbia rubs that sweet spot, with one of the most impressive sights (in my opinion) in the game being the mock-up of Mount Rushmore with Comstock's head being at the forefront (also feeding in to the SYMBOLISM!!!!!1). The game most certainly never gets boring to look at. Regarding the technical aspects of the graphics, the game ran pretty consistently at 60FPS all Ultra settings at 1080p on my GTX 760, although framerate tended to drop to about 40FPS when I was around doors, oddly enough. This may just be a thing with my card; it may be drivers; I dunno. It doesn't take away from the experience, but it is noticeable. It ran decently temperature wise, with the highest temperature on my card reaching 65degC. My house is pretty dusty, though, so it may just need a cleaning. Nevertheless, this game isn't too much of a computer smasher, and it just looks fantastic, especially when you turn everything to max and are blinded by THE BEAUTIFUL AMBIENT OCCLUSION HNGNGNGNGNGNGNGNGNG  5/5  Music: The soundtrack is predominately composed of timely 20's/30's music and orchestration. While the orchestra pieces may not be anything you'd listen to in your spare time, they certainly work in game. My only minor issue with the music is the musical sting that ends every combat scenario. I just felt like it would add more tension if they didn't do that every time all the enemies were dead in the area, so that you'd take it much more carefully. Nevertheless, this is a very minor complaint. The 'old-timey' music may be your thing; I thought it was quite alright, but again, it's nothing I'd listen to on my own. It doesn't really need to be, but that can certainly be a point in an OST's favor. Voiceacting is great in this game, with some symbolism being within the voice clips themselves. Booker's VA is the standout in my opinion, running the whole gamut of emotions before the game ends. Everybody else is just great as well. 5/5.  Overall scores are 9/10/5/5; cumulative score of 9.7/10. I knew this game would be good, but I didn't expect it to be THIS good. No, seriously, if you were in the same lukewarm boat as me with regards to Bioshock 1's gameplay, this game will pull you right in. The story will keep you going if all else fails. I can see why Yahtzee said this was his game of the year for 2013. It really is that good.

****MILD SPOILERS BELOW****  This game is amazingly good gameplay-wise, but the ending made you feel like you were chasing your tail all along...  What i usually enjoy from games with a fantasy/ sci-fi genre is the plot and this one certainly made me feel satisfied but confused. Compered to the other endings from Bioshock and Bioshock 2 where in the end you got to choose your ending and feel a bit 'in control' of what you decide (i think), in Bioshock: Infinite you're just forced to follow the main plot with a couple of side quests involving the Vox Poluli and the only choices you make won't do anything to the final outcome.  Some parts of the game give the feel of it being a survival game, scavanging dead bodies and geting rescources (Health, salt, ammo) to keep you going..    You can't always put the burden to Elizabeth to supply you with ammo, salts and health..   There is also a hint of open world since you're able to revisit locations provided you have visited before, but that becomes sort of cumbersome because there are no means of transport, teleportation so it takes a reeealy long time to get there..   Just going back for money and ammo sounds right but you might realise it's not worth it.    If you're a fan of FPS i'd definetly reccomend this due to the immense and frequent engages in battles, the interesting selection of weapons and the sky-hook along with the vigors which give a positive twist onto how the battle will progress. Although the enemies gradually grow tougher and smarter, your arsenal does too. They have also incorporated a logical upgrade shop for your guns and vigors. I thought that the prices were really expensive, I could have just not scavanged everything enough- I'll leave the conclusions to you. There was also clothing involved in gameplay (hat, top, pants etc.) that gave you a certain power from igniting your enemy in fire when you melee him to creating 'ghostly friends' that fight for you when you switch guns(the gun is the 'ghostly ally'). Pretty overpowered if you use them right, that's what i think of it. What i found annoying about the weapon system is that you are only able to hold 2 weapons. Even though it IS logical/ realistic , I believe that due to the wide range of weapons there should be at least 3 slots, but that's just me.    If I rated this out of 10 it would ba a 9/10  , just personal dislikes from the plot that's all        (If you get the season pass you'll get a golden pistol and machine gun along with a full gear kit, really helpful if you're planning to do 1999 mode which is the hardest mode Bioshock: Infinite can offer; The Rupture episodes also are a awesome bonus which is why i bought the season pass in the first place.)

The quiet and calm moments where your weapons are holstered and you're given the freedom to explore, stand out as some of the best moments in gaming history. This world is so rich and detailed, the graphics so majestic (the textures, so amazing!), the sound so immersive, the character of Elizabeth so innocent and beautiful.  This game's largest fault comes with its relentless frequency and complete narrative irrelevance of its combat. You fight far too many people far too frequently, and it becomes far too repetitive and far too bloody. The game fails to provide any significance to the combat and plasmids to the satisfactory level that the first Bioshock did. It contrasts the incredible experience of the game's non-combat sections in an unfortunate way.  The combat can be fun at times when you're not doing it for copious lengths. It just makes the game feel like you're playing a separated, arbitrary shooter in-between a fantastic explorative story-driven experience.   Still worth playing, and still gets a resounding thumbs up!

First off I completely recommend the game due to it's great art direction, gameplay, acting and it's decent pace.  The game starts similarly to the first BioShock Game. The player gets a limited amount of information and is put into this great city in the clouds called Columbia. His mission is to save a girl called Elizabeth to wipe away his gamble debts.  As the player gets confronted by a lot of trouble, the story doesn't develop much. It's basically still about Elizabeth. But this girl is interesting and thanks to the great voice acting - believable. I personally felt the story got in the background as soon as you are running around with new helping Buddy Elizabeth. But don't get me wrong, it was not boring. It was just... nothing special... sorta predictable.   As soon as the story progresses further the game got a lot more interesting and I needed to know what the story was about in the end. I thought it would take a different approach and it totally blew me away. Without going into much detail - the ending is yaw dropping - but REALLY confusing. It seems that I was not the only confused player at the end at the game, according to forums full with questions.  Here is a short pro/contra-list if you really need to know if this game is for you:  + art direction + voice acting + vertical gameplay  -/+ pacing -/+ story  - outdated graphics (even for 2013) - difficulty kind of 'switches'  According to Steam it took me about 10,5h to complete the game on Medium. That's not very much if you count that the game doesn't offer multiplayer. Is this game worth to play? Yes. Is it worth full price? Yes, but not for 10,5h of Gameplay. Since the game is over 2 years old, you should have no problem getting this game cheap. Support the developers, we need more good games like this one.

So I tried to play the original Bioshock but for some reason the game's sound did not work at all. So I was like, screw it, I'll try Infinite. And let me tell you right now, this game is SOOO GOOD! Pros: -Graphics are not the most demanding but the game still looks so good. I always love when creators prefer to have thier games have a unique style over crazy realism. This game will age well for sure. -The story was very interesting and I liked a lot of the places it went, I really could not predict the story which helped to keep me interested. -Gameplay is simple but a lot of fun. Some people may find this as a negative but I personally did not mind. The game does take more of a guns-blazing, action style gameplay which some people may not like because I've heard how the previous games were more horror-like or something. (again, have not played them, but may try them in the future.) --The best thing this game has to offer to me are it's characters, specifically the main protagonists. Booker and Elizabeth are such colorful characters that you really do care for and will probably not forget about. Even other important characters are memorable, but I say who to keep it spoiler-free.  Cons: -While the story is great, I felt that I couldn't always follow it. Sometimes I felt a bit lost because there were a good amount of times where I would think this is what was happening but it turned out to be this instead. Can get a bit frustrating. (this might just be me though) -While there are many interesting and colorful characters in the game, the main antagonist isn't exactly the greatest. I mean, he's fits the role of a bad guy, but you really don't feel sympathy for him, you just kinda think he sucks and that's it. I'm not calling him a terrible antagonist, but I would have preferred to have had him a bit more fleshed out.  Conclusion: Bioshock Infinite is a fantastic first person shooter, argueably one of the best within the past few years. It has fun (but simple) gameplay, a great (but sometimes confusing) story, and some of the most memorable characters within gaming. I really do believe you should a least check it out. (Also, it's a solid port, I had little to no frame-rate drops or glitches.) Objective Score-9/10 Subjective Score-10/10 *Basically, just get the game!!!

Quite possibly the best game i have ever played (with the possible exception of Half Life 2). BioShock infinite is an indirect (besides the DLCs) prequel to the BioShock duoligy. The first two were good, but some gameplay issues and the endings left me dissapointed. This game however has a satisfactory (if confusing) conclusion, and has some of the best combat gameplay i have ever experienced. Let's talk about the plot. In 1912, you play Booker DeWitt, a mercenary who owes money to a mysterious group of people. Tasked with rescuing a mysterious girl from the sercret airborne city of Columbia, DeWitt must find her to repay his debts. However, he, (and the player) have no idea what they're walking into. The plot is well paced, excellently designed, and is overall a lot of fun. Other characters, such as Elizabeth, Fitsroy, Comstock, and Songbird all fit into the tale of religious and racial intolerance, oppression and captivity. And captivity is the perfect word to describe the game as a whole. Its hard to fault a game which has so many good things about it, with great gameplay, story, graphics, voice acting, soundtrack. In fact, besides a confusing ending, there is very little to fault this game for. While the DLCs fail to live up to this game, this is without a doubt the greatest single player FPS since Half Life 2. And that's saying a lot. Also, you kill racist people. 10/10

The fighting mechanics were enjoyable, again for someone who does not often play FPS games, and the ability to switch vigors/weapons and play with the combinations was fun. Let me just begin by saying, I f**king love this game! Albiet, the graphics are dated, it's gameplay is relatively unchanged (from the previous bioshock installments, with the exception of only being able to carry two weapons... WHAT THE HELL!), but the story... oh my god the story. Bioshock has never been lax in that department, whether it be (ahem... SPOILER ALERT!) Jack unknowingly following orders through 'Would you kindly,' or Delta just being Delta, (ALERT OVER!) This game will make you think you know whats going on, only to rip it away and show you how blind you really were. This also applies to the DLC, Burial at Sea parts 1 and 2 (sorry, i have yet to play Clash in the Clouds yet, but when I do I'll update my review of this game). I found the first part of Burial at Sea to be disappointingly short, only taking around an hour or two to fully complete. It was also very linear, but due to the events in Bioshock: Infinite, this new story intrigued me. I won't go into detail, but the ending of part 1, although short, made me instantly go to part two, which quickly caught my intrest. The most notable point in part 2 is that it sees you play as Elizabeth, which brings with it an entirely new gameplay style. Instead of the traditional, shoot-til-you're-out-of-bullets-and-eve playstyle, Elizabeth is far more stealth based, using a combonation of plasmids, crossbows, and other various items to help her eliminate her targets without ever being seen. Elizabeth's arsenal isn't nearly as expansive as Booker's, but what it lacks in pieces it makes up for in versatility. She can get smoke bombs, tranquilizer darts, and bells just to name a few items, and all are equally helpful.   Some of you, however, may have never played Bioshock, and let me elaborate a little on the basic gameplay of those titles. You are given a combonation of guns and Plasmids (or in Bioshock: Infinite's case, Vigors). Guns are just as they sound, but can be upgraded throughout the game to become more effective. Some of the guns that Jack, Delta, and Booker have throughout the series include Machineguns, Pistols, Shotguns, Ect, basically what you would expect to find in a shooter. where the combat differs, however, is in the use of powers known as Plasmids or Vigors. these can do a variety of things such as taking over enemies, throwing balls of fire or electricity, and calling on swarms of various normally harmless animals to rather ruthlessly murder your foe. These are some of the most enjoyable weapons in any Bioshock game.  I realize this review is getting pretty long, so I think I should wrap it up. In conclusion, One cannot call themselves a true gamer without playing all three Bioshock games. It's like saying 'The cake is a lie' and none of your supposedly gamer friends get the referece. I think it goes without saying, all the Bioshock games get 5 out of 5 from me.

Goodbye Rapture. Welcome to Columbia.  Visually a lot of changes for Bioshock series. No more underwater ruins and spliced up people, everything is great in the utopia city in the clouds.  The good:  - Game looks amazing. Maybe it's not the highest poly counts of all time, but damn the art is cool. - Runs great. I think Infinite runs awesome even on lower end stuff. - Sound and music design is great. Not much else to say about it. There's also really hard to find easter eggs in the game when it comes to sounds. Like voices backwards or music slowed 1000%, to make it sound like just random ambient crackle. - Story. I guess some people would be divided on this, me too kinda. The writing is good and the DLC adds to it. Not every story has to be easy to understand and explainable. Things get really complex and there's a good amount of plot holes probably, but it does get you thinking, unlike most stories in games. Even after completing all the DLC I'm still thinking about the story and that's something! - Voice acting of course. The two leads are great. Everyone else too. I don't really mind having voice for the player character. - Level design. Matches the original Bioshock for the most part. Great amount of secrets and easter eggs. I thought I'd find most in one play through, nope, missed a lot of ♥♥♥♥. - Skyhook stuff is off the hook.  The bad:  - Gameplay. There's really no real improvements over the previous games except the skyhook stuff and tears, but while okay the actual gunplay wasn't that great. You are limited to two weapons, like it or not, though in reality there's always extra ones laying next to you. Elizabeth is great sidekick, but she alone can't fix the issues with the combat. - Kinda short. It's filled with content and crafted with love, but if one were to rush it through with no care for backgrounds, locations or story you would find the game too short. - Upgrade system. The permanent scaling from the infuses or whatever is fine, they promote exploration and are in pretty cool locations. The money spending on upgrades isn't that cool though. I liked the original weapon upgrade system from first bioshock and the ADAM system.  - Lack of Choice. No more multiple endings. You don't get to choose between anything at all, fully linear experience.  8.5/10. I think too much content was cut. Going for fully linear style isn't really great for replayability. Gameplay wasn't improved from past and actually made changes for the worse with limiting the guns, making them generic as ♥♥♥♥ and just overall lazy upgrade systems. Visuals, acting, sounds, locations and for the most part, the story, are what saves this game from being very medicore.

If you enjoy the layered the storyline in a movie like Inception, you will probably enjoy Bioshock Infinite as well. The game does a wonderful job at tricking you into following a stable plotline, only to reverse everything you know at the most unexpected times. I can't praise Infinite's writers enough, from the dialogue to the careful way they tie in the Infinite world with Bioshock I & II without tarnishing previously established plots, they really created something powerful. I resisted playing Infinite for about a year after it was released because I was such a huge fan of the first two games, and was worried Infinite would ruin the world for me. However, even though Infinite is a clear departure from the aesthetic and feel of Bioshock I & II, it's a fantastic FPS that absolutely manages to fill the rather large shoes of its predecessors. Infinite offers various difficulties suitible for different levels of gameplay, as well as some excellent DLC. If I have one criticism, it's that Infinite fails to have the scary moments you might be used to from the first two games. Although, Infinite is also not afraid of grim storytelling, which is one of my favorite parts of the series. As mentioned, it's visually stunning and inventive, and absolutely one of my favorite games.

This is not Bioshock 1, 2, or System Shock 2. This is an extraordinarily linear FPS with few oppurtunities to explore. With those negatives out of the way, I can confidently say this is a very well put together FPS with unparalleld world design that manages to fix a glaring gameplay issue that has plagued many games before it, the escort mission. Throughout most of the game you have an A.I. companion named Elizabeth and while I had fears I would have to carry her ♥♥♥ the entire game, I could not be more wrong.  She's funny. She provides information about the world you're in. She finds you health & ammo. She literally reshapes the world around you, and she will be your constant companion throughout the 8-12 hour adventure through Columbia where anything can happen and threats lay behind every corner.  P.S. After you're done with the main campaign, the two episode DLC's manage to pay homages to previous games while switching up the gameplay in some fundamentally distinct ways. Definitely not filler but an instrumental addition to the game's lore.

Plotwise is great like all Bioshocks, and it has a twist at the end that will destroy your brain harder than the one in the first game. Combat is fun and the variety in vigors allows for a lot of experimentation in gameplay styles, until you figure out that there are a couple of them that are overpowered and favour those over the others most of the time.  I can't recommend this game enough, even if you don't like FPS you should still give it a chance.
